It reflects a mentality that is widespread in our community, sadly, that is complacent, neglectful and, ultimately in many cases, uncaring about the question of mental illness generally. It illustrates some of the rather retrograde attitudes that can be found in many parts of the Australian community with respect to problems of mental health. These issues are even more serious when they apply to somebody who is being detained by the state, and they are particularly serious when they concern somebody who is being detained when they have not committed a crime, when they have not been sentenced to any specific period of detention and when the mere detention itself is a significant contributing factor to-indeed, an adjacent cause of-the mental illness from which they are suffering. No matter how cynical any of us may be, we have to accept that there are very serious mental illness problems in Australian detention centres and we have to accept that indefinite detention, the uncertainty about an individual's future that goes with that and the harsh administration of this system by both the department and its contractors are major contributing factors. We can argue about individual cases, we can go into detail about specific individuals, but we have to accept that there is a climate, a set of circumstances and a set of pressures that are all highly adverse to the mental health of individuals and therefore impose an enormous onus on the Commonwealth to ensure, if it insists on continuing with this regime, that appropriate independent assistance is available to people. In the case of Cornelia Rau, we have seen a spectacular example of how that did not occur. It was recently leaked to one of the newspapers that Mick Palmer, who is investigating the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and its administration of these requirements, was concerned about mindless zealotry on the part of officials of the department. All of the stories that have emerged suggest that there is a ture that is highly punitive, highly cynical and almost sinister in the way that Australia's asylum seeker policy is administered. The often extreme insensitivity and arbitrary behaviour to which many detainees are subject is calculated to have a significant effect on the mental health of anybody, but particularly somebody who has committed no crime, who is completely uncertain about their future and who faces the possibility of years in what is effectively a prison situation. Labor's amendment is designed to guarantee access to independent medical professionals for detainees with respect to both physical and mental illnesses. This access will ensure a much better monitoring and intervention process for health and psychiatric problems. It will ensure that appropriate treatment is able to be provided when required and that we do not see a repetition of what occurred with Cornelia Rau. Detention centres are indeed very similar to prisons. Cynicism and indifference to the plight of the individuals who are incarcerated are rarely below the surface. Of course, this is absolutely critical with issues of mental health. We need a revolution in attitudes to mental health generally in our community. It is a huge problem, it is a massively important issue and it should not be considered just in isolated situations such as this. I recommend to honourable members a recent book by Professor Richard Layard entitled Happiness, which is an extremely good book. I had the privilege of meeting Professor Layard in London recently. One of the conclusions he draws is that, when you actually look at the totality of human happiness as a key goal, if not the key goal, of any policy or government approach to governing society, in that framework the issue of mental health is almost paramount. The totality of human misery and suffering that comes from mental illness throughout our society is cul- absolutely enormous. We should see this amendment not only as part of fixing a particular problem in detention centres but as a signal of a need in the community generally. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr BARRESI
Title: NOES
text: I share the concern of many members in this House-not only those on the other side but also on this side-as to the medical, psychological and emotional conditions of those who undergo long-term detention. That is one of the reasons why the Migration Amendment (Detention Arrangements) Bill 2005 has been introduced as a way of curbing the great length of time for which a person can be detained and also providing greater flexibility for the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs to respond. Mr Deputy Speaker, if you listened to the other side you would be hard-pressed to believe that doctors were allowed into detention centres at all. The fact is that detainees currently have access, and are increasingly having access, to preferred medical service providers. They may request a medical opinion from external health care providers at any time. They have that ability; they have that right to do so right at this moment. I am not sure why the ALP feel that they need to put all these restrictions in the act rather than providing the flexibility that is required to manage individuals on a case-bycase basis. The medical relationship between the detainee and the independent medical practitioner needs to be upheld. It is a right out in the general community and is also a right in detention centres. If someone seeks a private, independent medical opinion, they have the ability to do that right now. The member for Melbourne Ports referred to psychiatric and mental health services and the need to address those issues. I could not agree more. It is a blight on our society. There is a growing need generally, not just in detention centres, for governments of all persuasions-state, territory and federal governments-to spend money in this area. We have referred the whole issue of medical treatment to the Palmer inquiry. I know that in the next few weeks or so, when Mick Palmer brings down his report, he will be making recommendations specifically at the request of the minister and the Prime Minister that deal with examining and making findings on measures taken to deal with medical conditions and other care needs during the period. From the unfortunate episode I have mentioned, we will learn things about the role of the federal department and also about the role of the state and territory departments in that particular case. There are moves afoot in that area. I look forward to the Palmer inquiry's recommendations in that area. The other part of this amendment deals with access by the media. One of the things that I noted when I went to Baxter earlier this year was the concern expressed by some of the detainees about their identity and their particular circumstances being broadcast back home. I recall specifically one gentleman saying to me that one of the reasons why he cannot go back-I think it was to Iran-was that his face was on a web site that indicated that he had converted to Christianity and that he was playing a role in conversions within the detention centre. It is that kind of breach of privacy which is at the heart of making sure that the media's access to detention centres does have strict guidelines. The media are not prevented. As the minister rightly pointed out, we have not come across any media outlet or organisation that has made a request to have access to a detainee and has had it rejected. Far from that, we have seen many articles in newspapers by noted journalists who have had detailed interviews with detainees about their conditions. Privacy is an important issue. It does need to be maintained. We do not want to jeopardise the safety of that individual or their family overseas, a fear some of them have expressed to me on a personal basis. That is one of the reasons this amendment needs to be rejected.

Speaker: Ms HALL
Title: NOES
text: Shortland) (12.23 pm)Firstly, I refer to a statement made by the previous speaker, the member for Deakin. I know he is a very caring and compassionate man. He noted that if a person wanted or needed an independent medical assessment they could request it. I understand that he may not be as familiar with mental illness as a lot of people are, but one of the issues surare rounding mental illness is the lack of insight into the fact that you may even need that independent medical assessment. You only need to look at some of the statements made by Cornelia Rau to understand the impact that mental illness has on a person's ability to request that type of assessment when they need it. There is no element of Australian society that causes me to feel more ashamed than the treatment of our detainees, or should I say people, human beings who have the same needs as every other person in our community-treatment that led to Australian citizen Cornelia Rau being held in detention for an inordinate period of time. She was mentally ill. This mental illness was not identified. She was subject to degradation and humiliation when all she needed was appropriate medical treatment. I mentioned that inability to have that insight into the fact that you need that treatment. If there were a regular independent medical assessment by health professionals of people who were being held in detention this would not have occurred. This amendment to the Migration Amendment (Detention Arrangements) Bill 2005 allows that to happen. I cannot help question why the government will not accept this amendment. I probably would argue that the government is frightened to give independent medical professionals access to detention centres because it is frightened of what those professionals will find. There is no argument about the psychological impact of indefinite detention. That is irrefutable. Amnesty International continues to receive allegations of physical and mental mistreatment of detainees held in Australian immigration detention centres. That is irrefutable. There are the hunger strikes, the suicide attempts, the riots and the protests. They are all symptoms of the fact that people being held in detention centres are disempowered. They all evidence of the effect this is having on human beings who are being denied effective remedy to the conditions. Dr Louise Newman, director of the New South Wales Institute of Psychiatry, said on the ABC recently that detention was a very abnormal environment for child rearing and for people to be held in and that the institute had clinical and developmental evidence that shows detention is causing enormous emotional and psychological trauma and stress for the children. This would be picked up if we had independent medical assessments. There is the example of a female held in detention-and this example illustrates the powerlessness of detainees-and the guard would say to her: ‘Australians do not want you. Australians hate you; they want you to go home.' This engenders a feeling of selfworthlessness and it creates an environment where people will develop significant mental illness. I believe the Howard government stands condemned for not allowing independent medical professionals to gain access to detention centresMr MCGauran-They do.

Speaker: Ms HALL
Title: NOES
text: not on request but on a regular basis. Denying this covers up the plight of detainees like the young girl I mentioned and the plight of people like Cornelia Rau. If we had regular access by independent medical professionals this would prevent problems from developing. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Title: NOES
text: Yet again we have an example of the opposition having formed the view that the officials and professionals responsible for administering the immigration system are not doing their job well. Certainly there have been some unsatisfactory events, incidents and practices. There is no question of that. Everyone shares the concerns about the case of Cornelia Rau, about which several members have spoken eloquently and powerfully today. But just because you feel that bureaucracy A is not doing a good job does not mean that the answer is to create bureaucracy B to then look over the shoulder of bureaucracy A. If you feel that the department or officials, professional medical staff or whatpsychiatrist ever are not performing their task adequately then the objective is to ensure that they do. Legislation is not a ready solution for good administration. The amendment that is proposed by the opposition is quite interestingly worded. It says that the House is of the view that medical personnel and media representatives should be given independent access to people in detention centres. I would have thought that if the objective of the honourable members opposite were to be achieved, if their concern were to be dealt with, it would say that people in detention centres should be given independent access to, for example, medical personnel. Are they suggesting that anyone with a medical qualification should be able to enter any detention centre and perform physical or mental examinations of any person they see fit? If the opposition's concern is that people in detention centres should have access to independent medical opinion, that objective is not achieved by the language of the amendment that is proposed. The fact remains that detainees may nominate a preferred medical services provider and may request a medical opinion from an external health care provider. If they request a specialist opinion, a referral should be provided by the detainee's treating doctor. So the ability to get an outside medical opinion, a second opinion, is there. The case of Cornelia Rau, which of course will be the subject of the Palmer inquiry, has been touched upon. I simply observe that in the case of Cornelia Rau there was an independent assessment. The problem was that the diagnosis was incorrect. Again, you cannot legislate to make every medical diagnosis correct, just as you cannot fix a perceived problem in administration by creating a second phalanx of administrators and overseers. its You cannot legislate to ensure that every who interviews a person is going to get to the right answer, any more than you can legislate to make lawyers give the right answer. The most charitable view one can take of this clause is that it is utterly superfluous. The access to independent medical advice is there. The medical staff involved in the detention centres are professionals. They do not always get it right. Even honourable members have been known to make errors from time to time. So none of us is perfect. But the principle of access to independent medical opinion is certainly agreed to and is certainly part of the current process. But the language of this amendment is so revealing. It seeks to give medical personnel and media representatives independent access to people in detention centres, so the people in detention centres are not people, they are objectsobjects that the opposition wants to become the object of inspection and interest by third parties. We believe on our side that the motivation or the instigation of that independent advice should be with the detainee. (Time expired)

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: NOES
text: In accordance with the wish of the House, the question that amendment (1) be agreed to is deferred until after the House has completed its consideration of all the proposed amendments.

Speaker: Ms VAMVAKINOU
Title: NOES
text: I move opposition amendment (2) as circulated: (2) Schedule 1, item 10, page 6 (after line 7) insert “Considerations to be taken into account in issue of visas (4A) In exercising the power conferred by subsection (2), the Minister must have regard to whether a person has a need for temporary protection or for permanent protection. (4B) If the Minister considers that a person has a need for temporary protection, the Minister may grant the person a visa for a period not exceeding two years. At the end of the Secretary has presented evidence to the Minister that satisfies the Minister that the decision to grant a visa be reversed, the Minister must grant a further visa permitting the person to remain in Australia indefinitely. (4C) If the Minister considers that a person has a need for permanent protection needs the Minister must grant the person a visa permitting the person to main in Australia indefinitely. (4D) If the Minister considers that a person does not have a need for permanent protection, but considers son has made, and can continue to make, a long term contribution to economic, social or community life, the Minister may grant a visa permitting the person to remain in Australia indefinitely.” As of February this year there were 6,550 temporary protection visa and temporary humanitarian visa holders in Australia. The majority, some 3,980, are from Iraq, followed by 1,853 from Afghanistan. And there are about 800 TPV cases still waiting for a primary decision to be made. The proposed changes in the Migration Amendment (Detention Arrangements) Bill 2005 do nothing more than speed up the process by which at least these primary decisions are to be made. To date this process has been disgraceful and the proposals in government's bill do absolutely nothing to guarantee any certainty for TPV holders. In particular, the government changes fail to address the numerous people on rolled-over TPVs for two to three years. Those people who have been determined to be refugees should be granted permanent protection rather than having to go through the traumatic and pointless process of reestablishing their status. The government's bill does not guarantee permanent protection and therefore does not go in any way to end the uncertainty that TPV holders are curthat period, unless rently suffering. The original proposal by the member for should Kooyong called for the abolition of the TPV system and for permanent residence to be given to all TPV holders. The member for Kooyong understands the plight of TPV holders who are forced to live in limbo, not knowing what their future holds. It is a shame that the Prime Minister and his minisre- ter have not also understood the folly of this inhumane policy and that the government is only prepared to tinker at the edges rather than address the core of the problems surthat the per- rounding TPVs. We in the Labor Party, however, understand that the handling of TPVs needs significant attention and that is why we are proposing measures that will restore some certainty and dignity to TPV holders. Labor's position is born from our commitment to ensuring that we deal with this matter in a humane and decent way. It comes from a commitment to humanity and to social justice that is at the very core of Labor beliefs. Labor therefore proposes that decisions on protection visas be given within two years, with the onus on the government to establish why a visa should not be granted. Labor's amendments further recognise that even if a person is unsuccessful in an application for refugee status they will have an opportunity to put their case to be accepted as a person who would otherwise be accepted for a migration program. My electorate of Calwell is a welcoming community; we have built on waves of immigration and we have provided a home to many new refugee communities. We are well aware in our community that amongst us there are a great number of refugees living in circumstances of tremendous uncertainty because they are TPV holders. I have seen the frustration and despair that ongoing TPV status has on the lives of these people, people like Mr Jassim Albtat and his boys, Muhammad, who is 13 years old, and Haidir, who is 14 years old, who live in Broadmeadows. After being released from Woomera in 2001 they are still waiting for a detervisa. mination of their application for permanent residency. Mr Albtat has said that he simply wants to stay in Australia. Because of the persecution he endured under Saddam Hussein's regime he believes that now they cannot go back because the situation is still so unsafe and tenuous in Iraq. Only Labor's amendments will bring certainty to the lives of TPV holders like Mr Albtat and his family. Many onerous restrictions are placed on TPV holders, such as being prevented from family reunion migration programs, having no access to DIMIA case management services, no access to accommodation support or household formation support services and no access to government funded English language tuition. But above all there is no certainty for these people as to when their circumstances will change, and it is this that creates hardship and impacts adversely on their emotional and mental well-being. It is estimated that there are 113 TPV holders in my electorate, with Victoria's third largest TPV population living mainly in Broadmeadows, Dallas, Jacana, Coolaroo and Meadow Heights. Local welfare agencies, including the Al-amel TPV Holders Association, have been helping TPV holders. The association's name, Al-amel, means ‘hope'. Labor's amendments provide the only hope for these TPV holders, and that is why this government should adopt them as a matter of urgency.

Speaker: Mr MCGAURAN
Title: NOES
text: Gippsland-Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs) (12.38 pm)-I can confidently predict that amendment (2) will not survive if logic comes into play by the time this is debated in the Senate. It is defective-and this is what happens when you bowl up backbenchers to move amendments that they know nothing about. Amendment (2) refers to temporary protection visa holders in detention-but you are not held in detention if you have got a I stand to be corrected: maybe there are one or two TPV holders in detention at the moment through some circuitous route. But this amendment that the Labor Party has put forward-which the member for Calwell does not understand, nor do the draftersseeks to amend section 195A of the Migration Act, which deals with detention. So the member for Calwell, who is going out of the chamber-she will leave the parliament like everybody else on the opposition side; they stay for their five minutes and then they are gone, which is a measure of their seriousness and commitment to this debate-needs to explain to the House why amendment (2) deals with TPV holders in detention when her speech-and presumably those of everybody in the opposition that follows herdeals with TPV holders more generally out in the community. So that is the first ground on which it is defective. The second ground on which it is defective is its policy basis. The Labor Party would have it that all TPVs are converted automatically after two years. That is a recipe for disaster because it does not take into account the character issues that you need to check, which will take at times longer than two years, nor does it take into account the changed circumstances in the country of origin. So is the Labor Party saying that if democracy takes even stronger hold in Iraq, people cannot be returned to Iraq when there are no longer grounds for political asylum? In other words, the Labor Party wants TPVs converted automatically after two years. The situation at present is that the large number of people who come into the TPV stream quite regularly do need the existing issues of character and country of origin circumstances properly assessed. So I will be very interested to know whether or not the Labor Party truly believes TPV holders should automatically get permanent residency after two years. Instead, I would submit to the House that the Labor Party's amendment is unnecessary as the minister's power to grant a visa under the new section 195A is where the minister believes it is in the public interest to do defining the public interest, protection needs and contribution to the Australian community are factors that are taken into account. The large number of current TPV holders have been processed and assessed over the last couple of years to the point where, I understand, the overwhelming majority of TPV holders have been assessed and that a very significant number of them have received permanent residency. The Prime Minister has set October as a deadline for all TPV holders to be interviewed and assessed. I hasten to add that process is well under way, so the Labor Party is coming to this issue-like with all others-especially late. It would have been interesting to hear the member for Calwell raise these issues in the House previously as to her assessment, because thousands of TPV holders have been assessed and I would have thought that a majority of them had been given permanent residencyand we have now set October as the target for the remainder. So amendment (2) is defective, not just in a policy sense but in an operative sense as well.

Speaker: Mr STEPHEN SMITH
Title: NOES
text: In my contribution to the second reading debate, I said that the Migration Amendment (Detention Arrangements) Bill 2005 made incremental changes and we supported them on that basis, but that if you are really serious about addressing the inequities that have occurred in this area you need to do two things: clean up the backlog and set the system up for the future so that the sorts of terrible things we have seen occur can never occur again. As for cleaning up the backlog, when we look at the cases of the 12,000 people who came to our shores between March 1996 and the end of 2001 we see that we have to make changes to detention arrangements, changes to processing and changes to the administrative and judicial review procedures for asylum seekers' cases. We have so. In also got to make changes to the temporary protection visa system. So if you want to set the system up for the future, then you need to seriously address-as Labor has been arguing since the course of the last parliamenthaving an inspector-general of detention, 90 per cent of processing done in 90 days and for those cases not done in 90 days a 30-day automatic review, access to independent medical advice, children out of detention and better processing and review mechanisms. So far as temporary protection visas are concerned-the subject of this particular amendment-there are two things we have to address. There is nothing in the government's proposals which will effectively address the backlog after all these years of having 8,000 or 9,000 TPV holders who came to this shore and were recognised as refugees by John Howard, on his watch, who have languished with uncertainty, delay and unfairness, other than the government saying, ‘We are going to try to get these things done by October, by processing on the papers,' when that could have been done years before. The second fundamental thing is to set the system up for the future. If you have a TPV system, you need one which operates consistently and fairly, which does not leave people in limbo forever and which reflects, recognises and understands our international obligations. So far as temporary protection visas are concerned, since January 2003 Labor has had a policy which is reflected in these amendments. The rationale for that approach is essentially what I said to the ALP National Conference in January 2003, and it rings true today: So far as Temporary Protection Visas are concerned, John Howard believes that Temporary Protection Visas somehow operate as some form of deterrent to unauthorised arrivals. Well if it is such an effective deterrent, why have we had 8,000 to 9,000 people come here on his watch who are now out there in the Australian community. We say there is a role for Temporary Protection Visas, but only if that role is consistent with the Refugee Convention. The Refugee Convention always envisaged that there would be circumstances where the ongoing protection of the Convention was not required. Under our model, an unauthorised person who comes here, who is determined by the Commonwealth to be a refugee, will go on a Temporary Protection Visa for a one-off period of two years. After which if the ongoing protection of that person is required, and the onus of that will be on the Commonwealth, then that person has a pathway to permanency. The worse of Howard's Temporary Protection Visas is having people out there in limbo for several years. You have to deal with the backlog but you also have to set the system up for the future. I continued: We say two years is an appropriate time to make a judgment. Two years is an appropriate period to give protection, but after that period a different public policy consideration comes into play. ... if the ongoing protection under the Refugee Convention is not required, in the case of those people who have been here on a Temporary Protection Visas for two years or more, you can make a judgment which is, are these people, who have been out and about in the Australian community making their family, community, social and economic contacts, are these the sorts of people who in any event Australia would want as part of our migration intake? If you come to a positive conclusion on that, then there is a pathway to permanency. So it is not, as the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs incorrectly describes, an automatic jump from TPV to permanency. These measures were put to this House in April 2004-a sensible, coherent TPV system, with trigger points consistent with our international obligations, making independent judgments under our migration procedures and rules, together with the right of reentry. Everyone on the other side of the House voted it down, including the members for Kooyong, Pearce and Cook. You have to address the backlog of the 8,000 to 9,000 people who came here during John Howard's watch. John Howard said they were refugees. John Howard gave them temporary protection visa status and now they just roll around in limbo. You have to set the system up for the future so that uncertainty can never happen again. If you adopt Labor's amendment, that will set up the system to treat TPV holders in a fair way, consistent with our international obligations. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: NOES
text: Mitchell) (12.48 pm)There is no way we can wear this proposal to take away proper discretion from the minister and to confine the minister in decision making to basically a single outcome-that is, a permanent result rather than giving the minister the option of assessing an individual's case carefully, taking into account every aspect of that case, including family circumstances, likely problems on return to country of origin and other options that a minister must consider. The Labor Party seek to codify everything. They want rules for everything; they do not want ministers to exercise judgment or to be criticised. They want a minister to say, ‘That's the law; I had to do it.' That is the problem with the way in which the act has been codified. This is a sensible provision which will allow the minister to exercise judgment. The amendment qualifies the power to grant visas and provides for the grant of a two-year visa and then the person must move towards permanency. That is not the government's intention. The government's intention is to provide proper assessment by a minister taking advice from everybody, including members of parliament and other agencies. The Labor Party have presented these amendments in a very interesting way. Instead of going through the bill in a seriatim process, which is the normal way to run a series of related amendments, the Labor Party have gone through Petro Georgiou's speech, picking out the purple patches and graduating them in a process where they think they can get people to cross the floora political stunt. They start with the inspector-general, but they know we are going to knock that out, that we will not wear it. The next one they want to run is the judicial assessor. They do not run them in a seriatim process, the normal process for amendments. The Labor Party have them in a graduated order of concern so that they can make a political point. The grant of protection visas detainees and the 90-day provision are next. This has been purely a political exerciseone after the other. Part of the political exercise is the wish to codify the actions of a minister and to encourage the process of granting permanency-no other options; just change the visa and grant permanency. If we go through the four parts of this proposal put forward by the Australian Labor Party we find that one after the other they remove discretion. Nobody is going to deny that there should be removal of the discretion which the government wants to grant in these circumstances. I believe you cannot argue effectively that that discretion should not be given. The judgment of the minister is exposed to everybody and open to public criticism. The minister is going to make these decisions and it is going to be open for everybody. But, in the view of the Australian Labor Party, the minister needs to be confined. The government do not believe that that should be the process. We believe the minister needs to exercise full discretion and that is why these amendments are hopeless.

Speaker: Ms PLIBERSEK
Title: NOES
text: Sydney) (12.51 pm)One of the enduring features of the temporary protection visa regime in Australia is the government's effort to keep secret the stories of the people who are affected by it. One after another, these stories come to light and we hear not only Labor members but also government members saying: ‘The temporary visa protection system is terrific except for the people in my electorate who are making such a fantastic contribution'-picking fruit in the Riverina or working in the abattoir at Young-‘These people should not be affected by this regime, because they are a special case. They are terrific people and should be able to become Australian residents and eventually Australian citizens.' There is an irrational belief that the refugees for we know are okay-it is all the other refugees who are a terrible threat to the Australian fabric and way of life. Discussing temporary protection visas, I am reminded of the film Molly and Mubarak, which was shown in Parliament House in November 2003. It is a beautiful film by Tom Zubricki about a young Afghan boy, his friendship with a girl of a similar age at Young, their developing friendship and his virtual adoption by her family. It was a moving film and was very light-hearted in parts. It was certainly no great threat to Australian democracy. You might remember that the government tried to ban the screening of that film in Parliament House. The reason I was given for this was that the film is critical the government's policy, selectively quotes the Prime Minister and promotes the theme of widespread resistance to government policy. That was the reason given to shut down debate in this country on temporary protection visas. The film's director, Tom Zubricki, said of Molly and Mubarak: ‘It is a film which I think makes you rethink your position on people who have been accused of being illegals and queue jumpers. It presents them in a different light and that is why it probably politically contentious. It can be seen as subversive, because it humanises these people who have been demonised and vilified.' We should remember that temporary protection visa holders have been found to be genuine refugees. There is no debate about whether they deserve Australia's protection as genuine refugees. That is not the question. The question is: what sort of protection will we give them? Up until now, we have given them extremely substandard protection. We have said that they can never be reunited with their families. They cannot leave the country to visit their family in a third country. In 20 or 30 years time, will they be permitted to meet their family in Singapore and see what has happened to children who have grown up or parents who are almost at the end of their lives? No. This is the regime to which we have subjected refugees who have come to Australia. The member for Mitchell is talking about taking away ministerial discretion in this area. The point of his government's legislation is to give ministerial discretion where it has not previously existed. I do not know how you can possibly interpret our efforts as being aimed at taking away ministerial discretion. Our efforts are aimed at offering certainty to people who deserve it. These people have invoked their right to protection of under international laws. They have come here during the government's watch, as one of the earlier speakers said, and have been granted asylum by the government. We want to say to these people: ‘We will give you some certainty. You need not look forward to a lifetime of having the threat hanging over your head that, any day, you may be returned to your country of origin.' Most of the temporary protection visa holders are from Iraq and Afghanistan. Of the almost 9,000 tempois rary protection visa holders, over 3,500 are from Afghanistan and over 4,500 are from Iraq. I do not see the situation in those countries being safe any time soon. The constant threat that they will be sent home makes it impossible for them to settle into Australian society. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr BARRESI
Title: NOES
text: As the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs pointed out in his contribution, this is an amendment we will not accept. Ms Vamvakinou-Come on, Phil, have a heart!

Speaker: Mr BARRESI
Title: NOES
text: I have full regard for the member for Calwell, having worked with her on committees. But if she really understood the amendment and what it is trying to achieve-if she went back and looked through the legislation it is amending-she would know that it does not achieve what she intends. This amendment qualifies the power to grant visas to detainees and amends section 195A to require that TPV holders be granted permanent visas. I say to the member for Calwell and the member for Reid-who has responsibility for carrying these amendments through the House-that section 195A is purely for those who are in detention. These changes are not possible under this amendment. The issue is uncertainty. This amendment will create even more uncertainty if it is passed. We all know that the United Nations prefers that those who seek and are granted asylum in another country should at a future time be settled back in their original country. Granting permanent protection visas before we have had a chance to see how the situation unfolds back home prevents that United Nations objective from being achieved. It is much better that people be resettled back home if possible. The TPV allows a person's individual case-such as the country they come from, and their political, economic and social situation-to be reassessed to see whether or not it is safe for them to return home. The TPV gives that extra flexibility, including to the minister. The member for Sydney says that these people are going to be prevented from going back to Singapore or Bangkok or wherever else to catch up with relatives in 10 or 20 years time. We know from current practices that the majority of TPV holders assessed as being in need of further protection have in fact already been granted permanent protection. In August 2004 the government introduced amendments to allow former TPV holders to access mainstream visa classes. We have allowed that flexibility for the TPV holders to access other visas. A lot of the cases have been assessed as warranting permanent protection. However, automatically granting TPV holders permanent protection removes the flexibility that any government and any minister would require. This is one of the reasons why this amendment should also be voted down.

Speaker: Mr LAURIE FERGUSON
Title: NOES
text: by leave-I move opposition amendments (7) to (12): (7) Schedule 1, item 19, page 12 (line 2) omit “2 years” substitute “90 days” (8) Schedule 1, item 19, page 12 (line 10) omit “2 years” substitute “90 days” (9) Schedule 1, item 19, page 12 (line 11) omit “2 years” substitute “90 days” (10) Schedule 1, item 19, page 12 (line 15) omit “2 years” (twice occurring) substitute “90 days” (11) Schedule 1, item 19, page 12 (line 22) omit “6 months” substitute “1 month” (12) Schedule 1, item 19, page 12 (line 31) omit “6 months” substitute “one month” We have a stark contrast here. We have the assurances of the member for Wentworth that it is difficult to say whether reporting on people two years after detention and a further six months later is good enough. He says that experience will tell. That is very nice for him, but one has to ask whether it is all that nice for the people in detention. We also have the contribution to this debate from the member for Mitchell. He has lamented the possibility that Labor is codifying, bringing in controls and bringing in bureaucracy. He says that we can trust the minister; the exercise of ministerial discretion is good enough. But I am inclined to look to the other side for this stark contrast: the views of the member for Kooyong with regard to this constant stream from those opposite that the department is, to quote the member for Deakin, ‘scrutinised too much'. The member for Kooyong stated: … no government department has greater unscrutinised power over people's lives thanDIMIAand I do not believe that it is acceptable to decisions about detentions in the hands of DIMIA officials without additional independent scrutiny and intervention. For all the rhetoric and talk opposite that this department is over controlled and over scrutinised, many of us would say that the member for Kooyong is more on the money. We have a situation where, two years after detention, they will start looking at giving a report to the ombudsman's office and then every six months after that. This is at the same time that the coalition comes to this parliament saying that DIMIA will process stages of these people in three months and then in another three months. One would have to question whether, given that alacrity and that move towards swiftness with the devotion of more resources, they cannot be a little bit more proactive with regard to having an early report on these people. I say that a first report after 90 days and further reports after one month is a far more sensible suggestion. I do not need to dwell at length on the allegations and the evidence of psychiatric problems of people who have been in long term detention. The minister has said that she was not prepared to come to the conclusion that the detention system puts patients at serious risk of mental illness. A few days after saying that, in the aftermath of the revelations, she said: Can I give an absolute guarantee that the detention of Cornelia Rauwho was detained for 10 months and not two yearsdid not in any way further damage her condition? Of course I cannot give that guarantee. Those opposite talk about trust and scrutiny et cetera. The member for Kooyong and his allies do not trust ministerial discretion. I made the point earlier that the secret deal, which was not revealed to the public, involves this interdepartmental committee, led leave by Mr Shergold, reporting to the member for Kooyong and the other members involved in this on a fortnightly basis. That is the level of trust their own side of politics has in this process; they have to report fortnightly to see how it is going. This is the same interdepartmental committee which is supposed to be trustworthy with regard to monitoring the department of immigration, which, as anyone would know, is dysfunctional and out of control, as we have seen over the last few months. The complaints about bureaucracy, about paperwork and about difficulties and over scrutiny should be seen in the context of the experiences of the people and the revelations of recent months. Labor puts forward that the background to this is a faster and fairer processing system; transparency and accountability are long overdue. There will be no hiding behind the non-compellable power of ministerial discretion. There must be a justification to parliament if the minister refuses the recommendations of these reports. We should avoid unnecessary and prolonged detention and we should have a system that is humane; the system is necessary but it should not be punitive. There is a solid case in what we have seen for strong intervention, strong oversight and strong checking up on this department and, more particularly, on detention. The situation came to a head when Justice Finn said that the government, the department and the contractor had all lamentably failed in their duty of care to these people in detention. Australian citizens with psychiatric problems have been detained-and not on one occasion, as the minister said earlier; this has been demonstrated publicly on at least two occasions. We have to have protection in a system where it has been revealed that there have been 200 unlawful detentions and where there is the possibility that some 928 further cases will be referred. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr MCGAURAN
Title: NOES
text: Gippsland-Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs) (1.00 pm)-The opposition's amendments to the Migration Amendment (Detention Arrangements) Bill 2005, before us now, would change the government's proposal for ombudsman assessments of a detainee every two years and then every six months to, instead, assessments by the Ombudsman every 90 days and then every month. This is a matter of judgment more than a matter of opinion. We believe that our system of assessments every two years and then every six months-and, in the interim, the interdepartmental committee chaired by the Secretary of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet reporting fortnightly to interested government members-is the more practical and reasonable system. To have the Ombudsman reporting on detainees every 90 days and every month thereafter, quite frankly, is an administrative nightmare that will quickly become unworkable. Consequently, we do not accept the opposition's amendments. We will properly resource the Ombudsman. I find an inherent contradiction in the opposition's presentation of its amendments. It puts forward a proposal for a new inspector-general who has the responsibility of overseeing the detention arrangements. Therefore, what does the ombudsman do? The inspector-general and the ombudsman will be crossing each other's paths in and out of detention centres basically doing the same thing. Then on top of that you have the judicial assessor. The layer upon layer of bureaucracy is frightening and not in the interests of detainees, let alone in the interests sound immigration and detention policy. It smacks of the opposition trying to find points of difference and separation from the government. It is a game of one-upmanship to the opposition. That is why we are getting these new bodies, these new people, and these new powers. Let me state categorically-and I know I speak on behalf of every member of the government-that we do not want people in detention, let alone for prolonged periods. But the simple fact of life is that when you are running an immigration policy there are people in detention. That is unavoidable. The House will be interested to know that at present 75 per cent of all people in immigration detention are compliance cases, such as overstayers, most of whom are in for short periods. Fifteen per cent of detainees are unauthorised boat arrival people and the remaining 10 per cent are mostly people awaiting deportation, a number of them for criminal offences. Only a minority of children, nine per cent, or women, 20 per cent, found to be unlawfully in Australia are detained. In the vast majority of cases DIMIA works on removal arrangements while the women and children remain in the community. We have heard Labor members talk about Stalin and say that Saddam Hussein has more rights than detainees. We have heard the word ‘gestapo' from the opposition-all exaggeration. But when you look at it clinically and objectively, we have a fair and necessary detention system which we are improving very substantially as time goes on. Senator Vanstone has announced reforms and improvements in past months. Administratively she has done a great deal and now, legislatively, the government is doing even more to make the system flexible and softer. Let us face it-in a minority of those cases where detention is the only option it is because parents or other individuals are not cooperating of fully in removal arrangements. So in summary, there has been a detailed consideration of the opposition's amendments. They bring nothing to the table except political posturing. Their amendments are either impractical or unworkable. They cannot walk both sides of the street on this. They cannot be strong on border protection and then weaken mandatory detention to a point where it becomes unworkable. Instead, the government has fair and sensible reforms brought about by the considered deliberation of all government members, reforms which will be endorsed widely throughout the community.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: NOES
text: I rise to again acknowledge that progress has been made on the Migration Amendment (Detention Arrangements) Bill 2005, but it does not go far enough. That is why I am supporting this amendment, moved by the member for Reid, along with the other amendments. This issue could have been dealt with by the parliament more than two years ago. Labor gave this House the opportunity to vote on the more expeditious processing of people in detention facilities. We came to that position because we had an extensive process of consultation around the community. For over 12 months the member for Lalor, and then the member for Reid, conducted seminars and discussion groups around the country to try to work out the best way in which we could advance this policy area so that we got the balance right between secure borders and a more compassionate system. One of the conclusions that came out of those consultations, not only with community groups but also with experts in the field and with the department, was that it was possible to process nearly every asylum seeker within 90 days. We accepted the need for detention to establish the question of health checks, security checks and citizenship, but we said it should not go on endlessly. We took advice and we were told that this could be done within 90 days. In fact, we were given an assurance that 90 per cent of cases could be dealt with in 90 days. This, I note, is a fact not disputed, not demurred from, by the government members. So what we are dealing with here is what happens after the 90 days. It is not just a question of judgment, as the minister at the table, the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr MCGauran, talks about. This goes fundamentally to whether we want a fair system for dealing with people after the 90 days has passed. Let us understand the contrast between what Labor's amendment proposes and what the government proposes. We say that after the 90 days the onus of proof should shift. It should essentially come back to the government or the independent assessor to say why the person needs to be kept in detention facilities after 90 days. That is an exercise that needs to be made public. We say that there should be a requirement on the part of the independent body to report on a monthly basis and for that to be made public. What does the government say? The government's bill effectively says that the Ombudsman, the independent body, does not even start to look at these people for two years. And then it has a review only every six months. In other words, instead of our system, which would put the onus back on the government to say why after 90 days the person could not be released, we are stuck with this system which says the person can still be in detention for another two years and then only get a six-monthly review. That is not judgment-that is deception. You cannot masquerade in this place talking about 90 days and fairness if the truth is two years plus six months. That is the contrast. That is the difference between the amendments we are putting forward and what the government bill proposes. The government's process could take 10 times longer than the process we have been advocating. This is not the first time Labor has put type of amendment before the House. I might say again of the four members that have been claiming credit for pursuing these changes: where were they when we put these proposals to the chamber before? They did not vote for us. I think that, importantly, has to get on the record. I have congratulated them on what they have achieved. But, if they really believe in their heart of hearts what they have been talking about, they should be supporting our amendments. As for leaving the discretion ultimately in the hands of the minister: what a joke. This is a person who has shown no indication of compassion, no ability to really judge the circumstances. Yet after the Ombudsman reports to her it is up to her as to whether anything is done. That is not good enough. If we want a system that is going to improve, we need to accept Labor's amendment on this case as well as on the other initiatives that are before the chamber.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: NOES
text: We need to analyse what the Labor Party is proposing here with these amendments. The amendments propose that the period of two years before a re-examination is made be substituted with 90 days and then every month thereafter. This is not confined to asylum seekers; it applies to everybody in detention, of which at 27 May there were 973. These amendments are proposing that for each month after the 90-day period 973 cases be re-examined. In every instance-right through the government's bill-‘two years' would be substituted with ‘90 days', with a follow-on of one month thereafter. On a rough calculation that would require the Ombudsman to look at 263 cases a week, approximately eight minutes per case. Is that a review? Do you think that will get bogged down, Madam Deputy Speaker Bishop, in bureaucracy? I am sure it would and you would agree with me. So how is it going to this work? It is impractical. The proposed amendments to the act mean that in 973 cases there would be this monthly review. I am sorry: it will not work. The intention may have been good, but it is impractical if you add together the cumulative impact of all of these amendments. This is why the proposals of the Australian Labor Party are so flawed. The first amendment they moved was to get a grand inspector to go into the whole array of detention centres to inspect them and to take submissions from anybody the inspector-general would want to take submissions from. That is one review. The next review would be by the assessor-the judicial assessor would do another review of children and families in residential detention. So that is a second review and a second person doing their stuff. Then of course independent medical and media representatives would be able to go and see whomever they liked at any time. On top of that, the amendments confine the minister's discretion so the minister cannot really have much say except to grant permanent residency. Finally, to cap it all, there would be another survey of every individual in detention, giving them 8½ minutes per month every month, 12 months of the year. The impracticalities of three reexaminations plus access by media and medical advisers, along with confining where the minister can exercise judicial discretion to make worthwhile decisions, is topped off by this 8½-minute examination by the Ombudsman. It just shows how out of touch the Australian Labor Party are with policy in general but immigration policy in particular. They have been running a line that was hopeless for them in government. It took them six years to decide they were going to ditch that policy. Then when the policy was continued for a little longer by the shadow minister he had a private talking to and was told to pull his head in. Finally we have these silly amendments today. It just shows you how out of touch they are.

Speaker: Mr BEVIS
Title: NOES
text: Brisbane) (1.20 pm)Clearly consistency and statistics are not strong suit of the member for Mitchell. Elsewhere in the government's contribution to this debate they have claimed that they will process most cases in 30 days. I am not quite sure how that factors into his quick piece of arithmetic, nor his analysis of the work of the Ombudsman's office, who I take it he assumes has a total staff allocation of one individual. The simple fact is that involved in dealing with these amendments there is a fundamental principle that all members of this chamber cannot escape. It is whether we think people should be detained, effectively without review, for up to two years in what amounts to mandatory sentencing or whether there should be an obligation built into the system to process most people within 90 days. As the member for Hotham pointed out earlier, Labor in 2002 made it clear that our policy would be to have 90 per cent of these people processed within 90 days. As bona fides, to ensure that the system operated properly-because we understood in 2002, as has become tragically clearer since then, that this department has failed to conduct affairs in a way which most Australians would regard as proper-we would build in the transparency and accountability mechanism of having, after 90 days, an external review for each of those cases. That external review would be conducted on a monthly basis and the minister of the day would be required to provide a response to that independent review. That provides a transparency and a process of accountability that the Australian people demand as fair and reasonable. Contrast that with the government's bill and the position which government members have sought to defend in this debate, which is that people should be put away and locked up for two years before there is an external accountability and review process. After the those two years, there is then a review only every six months. In practical terms, the contrast is this: Labor's amendment would ensure that if someone was detained compulsorily in a detention centre for two years, they would have had something in the order of 18 to 20 reviews by the time they got the first review under this government. Someone on the government benches might like to explain why that is fair. I have listened to the debate today as a number of government members have complained that Labor members have tried to take some moral high ground on this. A number of people on the government benches have indicated their personal commitment to similar principles. I accept that a number of government members do share similar principles on this. The test of those principles and their bona fides is in dealing with these amendments. There is an opportunity for government members who claim to be concerned about these things to demonstrate that, not in press releases, doorstops or stunts, but in real activity by a vote in this parliament which makes a difference. There its is an opportunity for them to put their feet where their mouths have been for the last few weeks and actually support what is by any measure a fair and proper system. We think that to detain people for 90 days is a fair period in which the system can determine identity, health and security risks for the great bulk of people. That was a decision we took in 2002. I am glad that the member for Hotham spoke prior to me on this because when he was the Leader of the Opposition, he gave the commitment on Australia Day 2002, on behalf of the Labor Party, that changed our policy to say that we would remove children from detention centres. At the time, that was a pretty courageous stand to take. The member for Hotham did that with dignity. It is something that those of us on this side of the House are proud of. Since that time, we have argued for a policy that embodies these principles of fairness. We have moved amendments in this place to that effect in the past and government members have done their best to prevent the parliament debating them. Here they have an opportunity to vote on the substance of the issue-no tactical games, but a vote on the substance of the issue. Do the government members who claim to be concerned about these things want to see people detained as a matter of practice for two years or do they think that 90 days is a fair time to process them? Here is the test to those opposite. We will wait to see whether they can measure up to that test. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr BARRESI
Title: NOES
text: I thank the member for Brisbane for coming out and finally telling us what the motivation for these amendments is all about. The motivation for these amendments is to see whether or not there are members of the government who will cross the floor. That is what this is all about. It is pure and simple: this is politics. I understand that; it is the fession that we are in. But do not disguise it behind some concern about the existence of immigration detention at all. This is about politics. The bells will ring and let us see whether or not people are going to cross the floor. These amendments, more so than any of the other amendments, basically outline a new ALP policy-that is, the dismantling of mandatory detention. Mandatory detention would cease to exist if we have in the legislation the ability for reviews to take place within 90 days and then every month afterwards. People out there will know that they are going to get a decision within 90 days and after that every month. Mandatory detention is dead. This is a new ALP policy and let them come out and say it. Is it dead or is it politics? It is one of the two. It is either a new ALP policy of making mandatory detention dead or it is all about politics. I will get back to the amendments because our changes do address the issue of people who will be in detention for exorbitant periods of time. I spoke in the main debate about my concern for Peter Qasim and how much I was touched by his story when I met him. We do not want situations like Peter Qasim's to slip through the system. That is why we are making changes so that after two years, and then every six months afterwards, the Commonwealth Ombudsman will review each case. That is a fair system. Within that two-year period, we will also allow the applicant the ability to go through the primary application, including the tribunal, the Federal Court, the Magistrates Court and the High Court. So the legal avenues will still be available to the detainees. On the other hand, what the ALP is doing is mixing two systems-an administrative system and a legal system. If you do not understand that, it is because this has nothing to do with addressproing the issue; it is all about the politics that you are playing at the moment. There is another thing that we need to understand. I think it was the member for Hotham who spoke about the onus of proof shifting onto the government to prove the case. At the moment we have a situation where someone applies to be an asylum seeker. Surely it is reasonable to expect that, if you are going to make an application for something, your application should demonstrate the veracity of your case. It is up to that individual, not the government, to demonstrate the veracity of the case. Even beyond that, the United Nations guidelinesand you would know this, Member for Reid, as after all you carry the portfolio on behalf of the opposition-allow within that system, where there may be a benefit of the doubt, that that also be taken into consideration and go in favour of the applicant. The application of the United Nations guidelines currently allows the benefit of the doubt to be applied. But we know what this is about. This is about politics; this is not about your concern for mandatory detention. If it is, then you have outlined a new ALP policy of dismantling the entire thing. What is it? State which one it is, and let us get on with it.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: Flinders-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage) (1.51 pm)-I move: That this bill be now read a second time. The purpose of the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 is to make amendments to the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act 1989 and to the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust Act 2001. Australia's Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act 1989 has made a significant contribution to the global effort to phase out ozone depleting substances, and is now also contributing to minimising Australia's avoidable emissions of synthetic greenhouse gases. Through cooperation between government and industry, the legislation has reduced Australia's consumption of ozone depleting substances by 80 per cent since 1989, resulting in estimated savings to the Australian economy of some $6.4 billion by the year 2060. This bill proposes to amend the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act 1989 to rectify a small number of operational anomalies and unintended consequences of drafting. The proposed amendments will ensure the consistent and effective operation of Australia's legislaWales. tion for the management of ozone depleting substances and their synthetic greenhouse gas alternatives. These substances have very significant impacts on the global climate tem and the ozone layer, and appropriate restrictions are essential to ensure that substances are managed consistently and used sustainably within Australia. Specifically, this bill will make two changes to the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act 1989. Firstly, it will confirm that importers or exporters of recycled or used methyl bromide or hydrochlorofluorocarbons are only required to hold a used substances licence. This approach is consistent with that taken for other ozone depleting substances-such as chlorofluorocarbons and halonscurrently controlled under the act. Secondly, the bill will ensure that reporting obligations for synthetic greenhouse gases manufactured in Australia are the same as those for synthetic greenhouse gases imported into, or exported, from Australia. The proposed amendments to the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act 1989 contained in this bill demonstrate the government's determination to further advance its practical and effective approach to managing ozone depletion and climate change. In relation to the amendments to the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust Act 2001, the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust is responsible for preparing and implementing a plan for the future uses of former defence and other Commonwealth lands on or near the foreshores of Sydney Harbour. These are historic lands. They tell the story of European settlement in Sydney and trace the patterns of defence, industry and population growth in the fledgling colony of New South The lands are Macquarie Lightstation on South Head; the former Artillery School at North Head; Woolwich Dock and Parklands; sys- Cockatoo Island; Snapper Island; Defence lands at Middle Head-Georges Heightsthese Chowder Bay; and the former marine biological station at Watsons Bay. The Sydney Harbour Federation Trust's comprehensive plan for these sites was approved by the Minister for the Environment and Heritage's predecessor, the Hon. Dr David Kemp, in September 2003. The plan was some years in preparation and involved wide community consultation. It is fair to say that consultation by the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust in the preparation of the plan was a hallmark of the planning process. A community advisory committee, established under the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust's legislation, was instrumental in reflecting community interest in the sites and providing advice and recommendations on site outcomes. I particularly commend the work of the member for Warringah and the member for North Sydney in assisting with the community consultation. The Sydney Harbour Federation Trust has begun the challenging task of implementing the comprehensive plan. Former Defence lands at Middle HeadGeorges Heights-Chowder Bay are being transformed into a headland park. The park will link all the elements of these disparate defence bases and bring them into accord with the great natural and cultural assets of the Middle Head plateau. A network of walking tracks, lookouts, revegetation and interpretive signage will underpin compatible uses of buildings and facilities and highlight the Indigenous and military history of this beautiful headland. The Sydney Harbour Federation Trust Act 2001 provides for the sale, subject to environmental and heritage considerations, of 19 residential lots listed in schedule 2 to The residential lots are at Markham Close, Mosman. Other trust lands are listed in schedule 1 to the act and are to remain in public ownership. To date 12 residential lots at Markham Close have been sold by auction. The effect of the proposed amendments contained within this bill will be to enable the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust to more effectively bring to the fore the natural ridgeline of Middle Head peninsula and add to the character of the headland park. This entails transferring three residential lots in Markham Close from schedule 2 to schedule 1, thus allowing them to be incorporated into the park and in exchange transferring the land on which a disused scout hall is located, currently included in schedule 1, to schedule 2 permitting its eventual sale. This land swap, which has strong community endorsement, is consistent with the trust's comprehensive plan and the fundamental objective of making its lands accessible to the public. The scout hall land does not have any significant environmental and heritage value and the scouting association has relinquished its lease on the land. The scout hall land, comprising around two-tenths of a hectare of trust lands, will be sold to private funds to enhance trust sites. The trust's preparation of the management plan for Markham Close included the proposal to swap land in the interests of highlighting the ridgeline of Middle Head peninsula and contributing to the creation of a spectacular headland park. The proposed land swap was overwhelmingly supported by the community during the exhibition of the draft management plan. The proposed amendments contained in this bill will enable the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust to fulfil the objectives of the the act. comprehensive plan and to open Middle Head peninsula for the benefit of the community. I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.

Whaling

Speaker: Mr LINDSAY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Would the minister inform the House of the outcomes of yesterday's meeting of the International Whaling Commission.

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for his question. The International famWhaling Commission held its second day of meetings in Ulsan, Korea, yesterday. At that meeting Japan proposed an amendment to the convention that would have allowed the resumption of commercial whaling. I am pleased to inform the House, and of course it has been in the media in any case, that working closely with quite a number of likeminded countries we were successful in voting down this measure by 29 votes to 23. The fact that a majority-a good majority in the circumstances-were opposed to the resumption of commercial whaling is something that we particularly welcome. This was a vote that built on our earlier success in blocking Japan's attempts to alter the procedures and the agenda of the International Whaling Commission to suit pro-whaling nations. I make the point that this excellent result was the product of patient diplomacy, and I congratulate Senator Ian Campbell, the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, on the excellent job he has done. I think we are all very grateful to him for his hard and effective work and to the officials of his department and my department. This is an example of patient diplomacy that has spanned many years. This is not an issue that has cropped up in the last three months; this issue is ages old. We have had very effective but quiet cooperation with our partners. There will be further votes in coming days, including on an Australian motion that the International Whaling Commission not consider Japan's expanded scientific whaling program until a review of the original program has been completed. The outcome is hard to predict and, again, it will be very difficult to get a majority. It is possible we could, but it is possible that we will not. But in the end we will do our best to try to achieve that outcome. In conclusion, some members and commentators have argued that we should abandon this process, that it does not amount to much, and, instead, we should just go to the International Court of Justice. The government have always said that we do not rule in or rule out any options. We obviously keep our options open, but we would need to consider any measure like that very carefully. That is the sort of measure that needs to be thought through. Bringing legal action in the International Court of Justice is a process that could take a decade or more, so we would not get very quick results there. Also, the doctrine of abuse of rights, which is the basis on which we would take action in the International Court of Justice, has not succeeded so far and so that is a case that would have to be argued. A third consideration is that, even if we were successful after a decade or so in the International Court of Justice, it would be open to Japan to circumvent the impact of the court's decision by simply withdrawing from the International Whaling Commission. It is better that Japan remain in the International Whaling Commission, where its whaling activities can be supervised and regulated. We would not want to overreact by dealing with this issue in such a way that it might be to the benefit of a decent headline one day but in fact be entirely counterproductive the next. That is the sort of issue that not just the government but the parliament needs to think through very carefully. Whaling

Speaker: Mr BALDWIN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Would the Treasurer outline to the House recent partial data on the state of the economy? What does this data indicate about Australia's economic outlook?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Paterson for his question. The Australian Bureau of Statistics today released information on sales of new motor vehicles for May. That showed that sales were down by 1.2 per cent on the previous month. One would not want to overstate this, because 2003 was a record year, 2004 was a record year and 2005 is in excess of 2004, but the fact that sales are increasing at a slower rate compared to 2004 does show that consumer demand may well be slowing a little, as I have indicated through other data. Also, the skilled vacancies index was released today, which showed that skilled vacancies fell by 0.5 per cent in the June quarter and are 3.2 per cent lower over the year. That is consistent with the budget forecast showing a moderating domestic demand and employment growth slowing to 1¾ per cent in 2005-06. That is slower than in previous years but it would be sufficient to maintain the unemployment rate at around 5 per cent, which is at a 29-year low. The partial data released today, I believe, is consistent with other data such as we have had from the housing sector, which indicates a slowing in consumption in the domestic economy. We have had very large price rises in relation to exports, and a rebalancing of growth from domestic to external sources would certainly be welcome. This moderation of consumption may well be consistent with households rebuilding their balance sheets. Again, that would be a welcome development for the economy. Credit Card Security

Speaker: Mr FITZGIBBON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is also directed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer advise the House on what date the government first became aware of the credit card security breach which has exposed 130,000 Australian cardholders to fraud?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: No, I cannot advise what date the government became aware of that. I understand that Senator Ellison has been answering questions in relation to this in the Senate. Mr Crean interjecting

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Order!

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I am interrupted by the sound effects man down there! I can inform the House that data was stolen in America from CardSystems Solutions through computer hacking in the United States. I am informed that any person involved in using credit data stolen from CardSystems within Australia to access funds, credit or other financial benefits will be subject to offences under the Criminal Code. I am also informed that the code of practice between the Australian banks provides that, where somebody has suffered a loss because of fraud by a third party, the banks will make good and individuals will not be responsible for any loss. I am also told that the banking industry is forming an information security customer response task force, led by the Australian Bankers Association, which will be in place by 1 July. As far as I am aware, those banks that became aware of this credit card fraud in the United States took immediate steps to replace the cards. I am not aware that there has been any loss by any Australian user of those cards, because the banks have made that good. I believe that Australian law enforcement authorities are cooperating with their American counterparts. Mr Fitzgibbon- Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I invite the Treasurer to get back to the House at a later hour with advice on exactly when the government became aware of the fraud.
