Speaker: Mr FAWCETT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is also addressed to the Treasurer. Would the Treasurer inform the House of new tax schedules that are due to take effect in July 2005? Are there any impediments to these schedules taking effect?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Wakefield for his question. I can inform the House that the good news is that all Australian income tax payers will receive a tax cut in nine days time on 1 July. The legislation to enact those tax cuts, unfortunately, has been blocked in the Senate by the Australian Labor Party, but schedules, which take effect and can be relied upon, have not been disallowed by motion in either house. They have now been in this House for 11 days and in the Senate for six days. There is only one more day of sitting for anyone to move a disallowance motion. Provided that no-one moves a disallowance motion tomorrow, those schedules will go ahead and every Australian will receive a tax cut on 1 July 2005. Labor's campaign to stop taxes being cut on 1 July 2005 has failed. The good news is that the public recognises that Labor's campaign against income tax cuts was a misguided campaign. A large proportion of the Australian Labor Party also now recognise that the decision by their so-called brains trust to oppose the income tax cuts in the budget was misguided-and the poor Leader of the Opposition is living with that. But, as I constantly say to the House, do not hold him solely responsible; he was advised by the member for Lilley, the member for Swan and Senator Conroy-the three wise roosters. This morning the member for Lilley was asked about the tax schedules. I will read the question and the answer, because I think the question is a bit of a corker. The journalist that approached the member for Lilley asked this question-and I ask the House to listen to it: ‘Wayne, are the roosters worried that Kim Beazley isn't coming through?' Answer: ‘No, we're not worried at all.' The good news is that the roosters are not worried. The line from rooster central is that there is no need to panic. Everything is going according to plan. There is a cunning strategy and all will shortly be revealed. Let the backbench of the Labor Party know that this particular strategy is under control-under rooster control. Situation normal at rooster command. We on this side of the House believe that taxes should be cut because, if you can fund your services, if you can balance your budget and if you can reduce your debt, income taxes should be as low as possible for the Australian public. We have a plan to cut income tax rates at the lowest marginal rate and to increase thresholds at the top rate. After these schedules go through and after the legislation goes through in August, only three per cent of Australians will be bothered by the top marginal tax rate. That will put incentive back in the Australian taxation system and encourage growth and the continuation of a strong economy in this country. Comcar: Employees

Speaker: Mr SECKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Would the Deputy Prime Minister update the House on how government policies have contributed to the development and growth of the Australian aviation industry? What further challenges does this industry face?

Speaker: Mr ANDERSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for his question. I am delighted to be able to report to the House that there is very clear evidence that the government's aviation policies are working. There is strong growth in both the domestic aviation sector and the international aviation market. The combined domestic and regional aviation industry is operating now at record high levels, with almost 38 million passengers carried during the year ended December 2004. That was an increase of 14 per cent on the previous year. At the same time, passenger traffic on Australian international flights has also grown very strongly. Over the 12 months to December 2004, we saw a record high of 1.93 million passengers internationally-an increase of nearly 10 per cent on December 2003. International activity reached a record high of 10,000 flights in December 2004, which was 16 per cent higher than December 2003 and 48.4 per cent higher than the low recorded in June 2003 when activity was negatively impacted by SARS. The figures are very buoyant and very encouraging. They come off the back of the sharp downturn of two or three years ago, which no-one could have foreseen; but, nonetheless, they are remarkable figures. It is worth bearing in mind-and we must never forget it-that the aviation industry operates in a very volatile climate. It is particularly susceptible to sudden shocks. Unfortunately, the international aviation industry is highly corrupted with many airlines enjoying not only natural geographic advantages over us-that is all strength to their right armbut also the protection of government ownership and support, which we no longer supply and should no longer supply in Australia. I make the point that, while the airlines themselves have to do everything they can to be internationally competitive-and we encourage them in that-there is also a vital need for international reform. There are too many airlines internationally because there are too many governments that prevent sensible rationalisation-a point well made by Rod Eddington recently. He is a well-known and respected Australian who headed up BA for a long time. Unfortunately, our carriers still face unreasonable restrictions on access to other countries. For example, in my view there are still unrealistic and unfair limitations on our access to the important UK market. On the domestic front, it is worth making the point that there are those opposite who would still want to saddle the aviation industry in Australia with the cost of a white elephant-namely, a second airport in Sydney. Mr Murphy-Nonsense!

Speaker: Mr ANDERSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Nonsense. He wants a second airport but cannot justify it. I think it would, by demonstrable indicators, be a white elephant that would cost the aviation industry a lot of money. The fact is that total passenger numbers at Sydney airport have more than recovered, but the number of actual aircraft movements is significantly lower than it was back in 2000.

Speaker: Unknown
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Opposition members interjecting

Speaker: Mr ANDERSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: A lot of policy thought has gone into this by those opposite. You can tell that. They are all over the place. There is a certain sense of aircraft drift here, aviation drift. What has happened is that there has been a rapid move to having fewer aircraft carrying more people-more rapid than anyone might reasonably have foreseen. Indeed, it is worth making the point that the Sydney airport master plan, approved last year, indicated that the airport would be able to cope with Sydney's air traffic needs for at least 20 years. I think that is a very good outcome indeed. Accordingly, I say to the House that the government has formed the view that a second Sydney airport will not be needed in the foreseeable future and, consequently, the government has no plans to impose a white elephant on the aviation industry in Australia. Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Fisher for his question. I can indicate to him and the House that the government's workplace reforms will protect minimum wages, they will protect collective bargaining and, indeed, they will protect the right of individuals to join unions. It is against this backthe ground that we see this continuing misleading campaign from the unions and the ACTU. Just recently they have been joined by some ALP MPs-namely, the member for Canberra; Senator Lundy, the Labor senator for the ACT; and the member for Fraserwho have sent out a letter to residents in the ACT, including a copy of an ACTU brochure which contains a number of misleading and deceptive statements. It would seem that, in return for the $47 million which the unions have donated to the Australian Labor Party, what they have bought for themselves is a junk mail delivery service, as this letter from the member for Canberra and the member for Fraser indicates. We have had an increasingly desperate campaign from the ACTU as the days have gone on. Yesterday, the Secretary of the ACTU, Greg Combet, said that this government proposed to abolish federal awards. That is what he said-we would get rid of federal awards. That is absolutely wrong. It was made clear in the statement which the Prime Minister made to this parliament, it has been made clear in numerous other statements and it has been made clear in all material which has been sent out that this government proposes to retain federal awards, yet we have this increasingly desperate campaign from the ACTU and Greg Combet, just saying things which are simply misleading and deceptive-a desperate campaign from a desperate union movement. Speaker: Mr NEVILLE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is also addressed to the Minister for Health and Ageing. Would the minister inform the House how the government is providing country people with better access to medical services?

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Hinkler for his question. As he knows, as members of this House know, and as the Prime Minister and the state Labor premiers all recently agreed, Australia has a good health system. One of the reasons we have a good health system is that the Howard government does not just talk about Medicare; we invest the real money needed to make a good system better. I can say to the member for Hinkler that we have heeded his message about medical services in the bush. We have listened to people like the member for Hinkler and we are delivering. Under the policies of the Howard government, some 2,000 longserving country doctors are receiving bonus payments of up to $25,000 a year to keep practising in country areas. We have put nurses into 1,100 rural practices and we have got 600 allied health professionals working with country GPs. There are now 11 rural clinical schools, including an excellent rural clinical school run by the University of Queensland in the town of Bundaberg in the electorate of Hinkler. There are 10 university departments of rural health. Twenty five per cent of medical students are required to do at least 50 per cent of their clinical training in country areas, because the more you train them in the bush the more likely they are to stay and practise in the country. Since 2001 there have been 346 additional medical student places at our universities, every single one of them bonded to country practice or practice in areas of work force shortage. Since 2000 there have been three new medical schools in the great state of Queensland, with 150-plus publicly funded places. Can I make it very clear to the member for Hinkler and everyone else in this House: Medicare matters. Medicare matters to the Howard government, and since the election I have answered 37 questions about Medicare from coalition members. I just had my fifth from the member for Lalor. I ask this question: what has the member for Lalor done to upset the Leader of the Opposition so much? What has she done? Let us face it: she is not the only one who leaks out of shadow cabinet. That is what you get from a bunch of dills: leaks out of shadow cabinet. Or it may be that the Leader of the Opposition has got the message that the member for Lalor has not got-that the Howard government is the best friend that Medicare has ever had. Drugs

Indian Ocean Tsunami

Speaker: Mrs DRAPER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. As we approach the six-month anniversary of the tsunami tragedy, would the minister update the House on how the government has helped populations in affected countries through its emergency assistance?

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Makin for her question. I appreciate all the work she does and her interest in the way that our support for Indonesia and other countries in response to the tsunami is unfolding. This Sunday marks exactly six months since the tsunami tragedy, and it does provide an opportunity to outline both the timeliness and the effectiveness of the government's response. The government has now spent over $75 million on relief and rehabilitation assistance to help people rebuild their lives as a result of the tsunami. Indonesia, over $40 million has been spent on projects in Aceh and North Sumatra. Over 1,000 tonnes of humanitarian aid to Aceh has been delivered, medical services are being assisted in their re-establishment, essential pharmaceutical supplies have been given, schools have been re-equipped and essential infrastructure, including water and sanitation, has been repaired. And we provided over 100 Australian medical staff to assist. As the emergency assistance phase draws to an end, as it obviously is-and we provided initially $60 million for that, all of which has been spent-and people return to their homes, we are beginning the task of assisting them to meet their longer term needs. In addition to what I have already described, the House well knows that the government has committed a billion dollars to the five-year Australia-Indonesia Partnership for Reconstruction and Development program, and progress on this is already pretty strong. Over $175 million worth of activities has already been agreed, including the $50 million Aceh rehabilitation program. We are helping, for example, with the rehabilitation of the Banda Aceh hospital; we are training doctors and nurses to take the places of some who were killed as a result of the tsunami. In conclusion, there has been some suggestion in one of the newspapers today, the Australian Financial Review, that this program was not unfolding. It is and it is unfolding at a good and effective pace. It would be folly indeed if we tried to spend all of the money at once. That does not just apply to the government but also to the nongovernment organisations which have raised over $300 million. They have spent about 20 per cent of that, but it needs to be spent over a period of time, not spent all at once. This program by both the government and the non-government organisations is progressing In very successfully. I think all Australians will be pleased to hear that, because all Australians have supported the response by both the government and the non-government organisations to the tsunami. Drugs

Speaker: Mr TICEHURST
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Education, Science and Training. Would the minister inform the House of further progress on the government's efforts to introduce national literacy and numeracy tests and plain English report cards?

Speaker: Dr NELSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Dobell for his question. He is working hard to get those toilets fixed at the Tuggerawong Public School in his electorate. As I informed the House last week, the government, before handing over $33 billion of taxpayers' hard earned money for schooling over the next four years, has for the very first time put conditions on the funding. The states, before they receive that money, will be required to agree to a number of things, which include that by 2010 there will finally be a common starting age for schooling in Australia. We will from next year have not only testing of our children in years 3, 5, 7 and 9 in literacy and numeracy but reporting to parents. Principals will have a say over who actually teaches in the school. The performance of the school must be published at the school level. In other words, parents have a right to know how many students are passing literacy and numeracy in years 3, 5 and 7. They have a right to know the qualifications of the ers, the participation of teachers in their going professional learning and how much money governments spend on the support of teachers at the school level. One of the other requirements is career leaver destinations: how many kids got apprenticeships, how many went to TAFE, how many got a job and how many went to uni. That information needs to be published. Another requirement, which is long past due, is that of plain language reports to parents. As parents, we are sick and tired of getting politically correct language neutered reports at home about our kids. If you are told that your child is almost achieving, what does that mean? If you are told that your child is consolidating or performing sometimes or not yet performing, what does that mean? We have only one state government left to sign this agreement, and that is the Victorian ernment. The Victorian government has eight days to sign up before it will lose more than $1 billion in funding for schools. The plain English report cards will describe student performance as A, B, C, D or E. As parents, we know what A, B, C, D and E mean. They will also be required to tell parents which quartile, which 25 per cent, of the class their child falls in. So, taking the typical Australian primary school report which has gone to the states, for example looking at mathematics, the student will be graded A to E. So, for example, with a D in mathematics, Mr Speaker, you would know exactly what that meant if your child came home with that or was in the bottom 25 per cent. Then the teacher is required to explain in plain language what it means. So the grades are from A to E and then the parents must be told in which quartile of the class their child falls. If your child is in the bottom 25 per cent-somebody has to be there-you would want to know about it. For example, the report might say: ‘Wayne is trying hard teach- in maths and attempting his homework. onHowever, he is not doing as well as last year and I would like to discuss further work he could do at home. Please contact me.' This is what parents are going to get over the next 12 months. Plain language reporting is a condition of funding, and I table an example of a plain language report. Drugs

Speaker: Mr SCHULTZ
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I will just take a moment to focus, Mr Speaker, so that I do not mess up like yesterday. My question is addressed to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. Would the minister update the House on recent developments with the government's increased assistance to Australia's drought ravaged farmers.

Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Hume for his question. He represents some of the worse drought affected farmers in New South Wales and he has been a strong advocate, providing timely and effective assistance to the farmers in his region. The member for Hume will welcome the good news that yesterday the Farm Household Support Amendment (Exceptional Circumstances Relief Payment) Bill 2005 passed through the Senate. That means that all of the elements of the government's enhanced drought assistance package can now be implemented on time and in full. The legislation means that there will now be a $10,000 concession on off-farm income in assessing the eligibility of farmers in drought stricken areas for the exceptional circumstances relief payment. That will mean that a lot more farmers will be eligible to receive this essential help for them and their families. Other parts of the package include the more generous EC interest rate subsidiesup to 80 per cent in second and subsequent years of a drought-and the easier off-farm assets test associated with those benefits. Additional counselling and support services are being put in place. The new drought Envirofund round will be called very soon. And yesterday the Prime Minister and I were happy to ceremonially hand over a cheque for $3 million to the CWA so that they are able to commence their role in providing additional assistance to farmers and their families who are especially in need. Last week I provided to the state rural adjustment authorities revised guidelines for the implementation of the interest rate subsidies, which again will mean that more assistance will be available and that it will be provided under more generous terms than has been the case in the past. These benefits will certainly be encouraging to farmers facing the difficulties of drought. There is no doubt at all that the Howard-Anderson government has been the best friend that drought affected farmers have ever had. I guess there is only one thing better that we could deliver, and that is rain right across the nation. We have made a reasonable start on that, although I know we had a bit of assistance from above. There is one thing better than drought assistance that farmers can get, and that of course is rain across the country. I am encouraged by recent falls but, as the honourable member for Hume knows, there is going to have to be a continuation of this improved weather for some time before the drought is broken. In the interim, this government will stand beside farmers so that they are able to take advantage of better circumstances when they come.

Speaker: Mr CAMERON THOMPSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer. Would the minister advise the House on progress in giving choice in superannuation to Australian Drugs workers. Are there any barriers to greater choice?

Speaker: Mr BROUGH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Blair for his question and his interest in superannuation and the workers of Australia. On 1 July this year, in just nine days time, some five million Australian workers, for the very first time, will get the choice of determining where their investment, their superannuation, is to be invested. This is something that the coalition has been fighting for since 25 May 1995, when it was first announced as coalition policy. In November that year, the then shadow Treasurer, now the Treasurer, told the ASFA conference exactly what the coalition intended to do with choice and how we were going to empower Australian workers. We took it to the Australian public in 1996 and won an overwhelming mandate. Here we are, nine years later, with nine days to go before finally Australian workers will be able to choose where their money is invested. It certainly has been a marathon. To people listening, to the Australian workers out there, it must seem incredible to believe that the Labor Party is still seeking to obstruct the introduction of super choice. There is just one sitting day left in the Senate and the Labor Party is yet to support the government in passing the final superannuation choice legislation. That is creating confusion for small business and unnecessary uncertainty just because the Labor Party refuses to make a decision. People need to understand what it is that we are trying to achieve. For nine years the coalition have been fighting to give workers the right to be able to choose where their money is invested-not so some union through a union backed award agreement decides where your money goes, not so an employer decides where you should put your money, but so you as the worker who has earned that money decides where it goes. If an employee moves jobs they are required to set up another fund in many cases and have another set of fees. The Labor Party seems to think that is all right in 2005. That is the status quo that the Labor Party wants to maintain. Ms Macklin interjecting

Speaker: Mr BROUGH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I hear the member for Jagajaga interject. In the same way, the member for Watson yesterday tried to tell the House that employers would face jail terms. I would like to tell the member for Brand, who is a Western Australian member-it may come as some surprise to him-that Western Australian employees have had the right to choose where they put their superannuation investments since 1998. I did not see at the last state election the Labor Party in Western Australia trying to remove that right. In fact, the very charge that was levelled in this place yesterday was that employers would go to jail. How many people have gone to jail? How many people have ASIC thrown the book at in Western Australia, where they have had the right of choice since 1998? One hundred? Ten? Zero. It is another lousy scare campaign and last-ditch attempt by the Labor Party to try to roll back choice. It is not going to happen. I read in the Financial Review today that the Labor Party will release its own super plan closer to the next federal election in 2007. I implore the Labor Party to make a decision today-not in 2007, not 12 years after we put choice into this place, but today-and once and for all support super choice in the Senate. Let Australian workers have the choice to determine where their biggest investment for their retirementtheir superannuation-should be.

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: ADDITIONAL ANSWERS
text: It has been reported that there was a security breach in an Arizona based credit card transaction processing company. The vast majority of cards vulnerable to the breach are held by US customers. Of the MasterCards affected it is thought that less than two per cent were issued by banks in the Australia-Pacific region. The following information comes from Visa. Visa has informed the Treasury that it was the National Australia Bank that uncovered this fraud out of all the domestic and international banks of the world and reported it to MasterCard and Visa in September 2004. The FBI was notified and commenced an extensive investigation and on 1 June 2005 declared it a crime scene. During this investigation organisations were told by the FBI not to say anything publicly and the FBI only allowed public comment on Thursday or Friday of last week. I am told by Senator Ellison that he was aware of the matter when it was reported in newspapers in Australia, as was I, which was some time this week. Mr Fitzgibbon-What about the department?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: ADDITIONAL ANSWERS
text: You want answers; I am giving them. You ask when the government was aware. I am telling you that I was aware when it was in newspapers and I am told-I would not know myself-that Senator Ellison became aware of it when it was published in newspapers this week. The electronic funds transfer code of conduct administered by ASIC protects account holders from liability in respect of unauthorised transactions where they have not contributed to the loss. Visa and MasterCard have similar internal rules. The government encourages all credit card users to review their statements on a regular basis and report any suspicious transaction to their financial institution. Australian banksand they have done this publicly-are urging credit card customers who have travelled to the United States or used their cards to buy goods from a US based online merchant to check their statements and report any unauthorised transactions to their financial institution. I again state that this was believed to be a breach of security in Arizona in the United States. NA Parliamentary Committee Reports: Government Responses

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: ADDITIONAL ANSWERS
text: I was asked a question by the member for Perth about some negotiations between the department of finance, as it is, and Comcar over their collective arrangements. I am advised that the department of finance met with the two relevant unions, the TWU and the CPSU, on 2 June to discuss negotiations of a section LJ collective agreement-that is, one with the unions-and that in the course of those discussions the department of finance gave the unions a list of 10 possible productivity measures that could offset any pay increases that the unions may seek in the negotiations. It is therefore wrong to assert that we were stripping entitlements. The 10 proposals, I am advised, are purely options for the unions to consider and are completely dependent on the size of any wage increase sought by the employees. It is open to the unions, as is usual, to accept or and reject some or none or all of the optionsthey are not final. Indeed, the department of finance has sought for three weeks to arrange a meeting with the unions to get a response to the proposals made at the earlier meeting, on 2 June, and the unions only agreed yesterday to meet on 28 June. This is a beat-up by the Labor Party to portray negotiations as though they were outcomes and to scaremonger about productivity improvements in the absence of referring to any offsetting pay increases. More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: That was a very wise selection indeed, Mr Speaker; thank you very much. There is a brand of politics that causes more disgust towards politicians and governments than any other. Many people in this parliament were fans of the American television show The West Wing in which the press secretaries would gather on a Friday afternoon and talk about ‘putting out the trash'. What they meant by ‘putting out the trash' was that they would put out the bad stories on Friday night-put them out deliberately too late for Saturday's newspapers but by Sunday's newspapers they were too old. That was how they would clear out the stories they did not want anybody to know about. It is clever, it is tricky and it is that brand of politics that causes the community to reel back in horror. Unfortunately, it is a brand of politics in which the Minister for Health and Ageing fundamentally believes, because it is that kind of trickiness that has actually characterised his interaction with the public across the sweep of his public life. This is the minister who in 1998 denied any involvement in the Australians for Honest Politics slush fund, only to be caught out spectacularly on TV on 27 August 2003 on the 7.30 Report. This is the minister who got caught out so amazingly on Lateline denying and then confessing in the one interview that he had met with Cardinal George Pell. This is the minister who went out and gave the community a rock solid, ironclad guarantee before the election, with every ounce of his credibility and every fibre of his being in that guarantee-with his word, his honour and his integrity on the line in that rock solid, ironclad guarantee-only to smash it immediately after the election. This is the minister who practises that sort of mean, tricky politics by doing things like putting out the private health insurance premium increase notifications on the same day that interest rates go up, hoping against hope that one storythe big interest rates story-would come over the top and exclude from the public glare the story about the mismanagement by the Howard government of private health insurance premium increases. Last Wednesday we saw the minister back at it again when at 6.30 that night-when, as Leader of the House, he would have known that Douglas Wood had been released and that all of the nation was going to be rejoicing that Douglas Wood had been released and was going to be returned home safethere was the minister sneaking out under the radar, hoping no-one would notice the fact that he is turning our Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme into a two-tiered system. There is a reason I started with an allusion to The West Wing. I did so because this is the Americanisation of our health system-the creation of a two-tiered system for pharmaceuticals. Perhaps the Australian community would forgive Minister Abbott his meanness, his trickiness, his bit of manipulation here and slipping out of a press release there and his not-quite-frank statement on TV-maybe they would forgive him those things-if they thought he was competently running our health system. In fact, Minister Abbott is either nowhere near our health system or near those bits that are a complete shambles. Let us look across the sweep of the Howard government. Who is looking after the biggest issue when it comes to the health sector's medical work force? The Treasurer is-that is who is looking after that. Who is looking after reviewing the PBS? The Treasurer is, and, when the minister for health was asked, he did not even know about the review. Take a huge issue like mental health. Who is looking after that? The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Ageing, who is leaving the chamber now. Take something as important to the future of medical science as the stem cell review. Who is looking after that? The Minister for Ageing is. Then of course there is the question of the sale of Australia's biggest private health insurer, Medibank Private-government owned at the moment-that most Australians rely on for their private health insurance products. Who is looking after the sale of that? Senator Nick Minchin, as Minister for Finance and Administration, is. And when asked about the scoping study for the sale of Medibank Private, the minister for health did not even know anything about it. So all of these enormous health issues are being dealt with elsewhere in the Howard government. One might imagine that his closest colleagues know something about his competence that they do not let the rest of the Australian community into. When you look at the things that the minister for health is ally managing, you see they are a shambles all round. I am going to go out and buy a Tattslotto ticket on the strength of the fact that I put in this MPI before the most recent shambles in health even emerged in the public domain. But it has emerged today with the Pharmacy Guild basically putting up their hands and saying: ‘We want to deliver medicines at a reasonable price to Australian consumers. We would like the Prime Minister to honour his word, the word he gave us when he wrote to us on his letterhead'-a prime ministerial letter on prime ministerial letterhead, and John Howard's signature down the bottom, which is something you would think would actually count a little bit. ‘We would like the Prime Minister to honour his word to pharmacists. We are trying to negotiate a new five-year agreement with the minister for health and we just can't do it because the minister for health cannot competently conclude these negotiations.' That is the most recent shambles in health, which emerged today in between me putting in this topic for the matters of public importance debate and the debate actually coming on before the parliament. The pharmacy agreement-a five-year agreement about the delivery of pharmaceutical products and medicines across Australia at reasonable pricesis expiring on 30 June. And this minister, who knew that it was expiring on 30 Junebecause everybody knew that was the end date-and who has had every day since he first became minister for health on 29 September 2003 to competently conclude a new agreement with the pharmacists, has been unable to do so, jeopardising Australians' access to pharmaceutical products after 30 June this year. Everything he has ever touched in health has become a shambles. But the very particular matters I questioned the minister about today show that the very thing he slipped out last Wednesday, actuhoping no-one would notice-this new twotiered structure for the PBS-is, as of today, in a shambles too. Let us talk about this in some level of detail. What has happened here is that in the federal election campaign, after the Prime Minister had gone out on the Sunday, done his campaign launch speech and spent billions and billions of dollars with not one dollar specifically directed at older Australians, by the Monday and Tuesday in the second to last week of the campaign the headlines and the newscasts were all saying that there was an adverse community reaction to Prime Minister Howard's freespending policy announcement speech. On the Wednesday we had the Labor launch and it contained a very big policy for older Australians-Medicare Gold. By the Friday the Howard government, which had obviously wanted to coast through the election campaign not saying a word about older Australians because they were taking their votes for granted, thought they had better respond. But they knew they had spent too much money. What were they going to do faced with this conundrum: they needed a policy for older Australians but had spent too much money? ‘Oh,' they go, ‘we need a savings measure. Where are we going to get a savings measure from across the whole sweep of government? Where are we going to make a cut when we are desperate? I know-the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.' They had a small problem: they had spent two years corresponding with Labor denying savings could be made on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme-denying such savings were possible. But let me tell you: while they bleat about the Charter of Budget Honesty process as it applies to the opposition, they never apply anything that sounds like the same discipline to themselves-never once, not ever. So, with complete disregard of anything like transparency in fiscal policy, quick 48-hour cycle, they cobbled together a cut on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. It is very important to remember that the money generated from this cut was not going to go to PBS sustainability; it was not even going to go to the Health portfolio. It was going out of Health to other portfolios to fund an older Australians policy that they cobbled together at the last minute. The Department of Health and Ageing has admitted at Senate estimates that it had nothing to do with the costing of this savings measure. Why should that surprise us? Mr Abbott-It was in the caretaker period.

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: If it was a responsible measure, you would have been working on it before the caretaker period, my friend. Putting that to one side, why should it surprise us that the Minister for Health and Ageing did not know anything about this savings measure? It would not surprise us at all because, on his own admission, at a press conference he said he is ‘not very good with figures'. For a minister with a multibillion dollar spending portfolio, his depth of knowledge about expenditure in health is limited to the statement, ‘Peter will provide; he always does'-a reference to the Treasurer. The minister's intellectual hold on the financing of the single biggest expenditure area of the Commonwealth government-his complete encapsulation of this challenge for modern Western democracies where inflation and balancing the health account keep public policy specialists and academics fully engaged-is ‘Peter will provide; he always does.' The problem is that Peter has a tendency to provide six months before an election and a very startling tendency to cut back six months afterwards. When Peter could have salvaged

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: It is a direct quote as to how the Minister for Health and Ageing refers to the Treasurer. The Treasurer is known to refer to me by unusual titles, but I will respect your ruling, Mr Deputy Speaker. The problem for the Minister for Health and Ageing is that the Treasurer provides in the runup to elections, but he does not provide afterwards. The Treasurer could have salvaged this minister's future and credibility and allowed him to keep his rock solid, ironclad guarantee to the Australian public for an expenditure of $200 million-the difference between the Charter of Budget Honesty figure of $1.3 billion and the $1.5 billion the Treasurer said he had to cut back. He decided not to do that. Peter does not always provide, does he? Let us come to the details of the savings measure this government cobbled together during the election campaign and the consequence it has had. The government want to cut the price of generics by 12½ per cent. That is not a bad thing, but because it is badly designed policy it has a lot of knockon consequences for newly listed, innovative drugs. The minister has no hold on the interconnection between these two things. He wanders around saying, ‘It all doesn't matter because I know my policy has caused four drug companies-and four drugs-to say that they will not accept the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme listed price. I know that means that patients will have to pay a contribution, but it does not matter because there are chemically equivalent drugs available on the PBS.' Wrong, Minister: there is no chemically equivalent drug to eclipta, which is taken for lung cancer; there is no chemically equivalent drug to keppra, which is taken for epilepsy. Doctors say you cannot substitute. The Minister for Health and Ageing comes into this place and says, ‘If you can't substitute, then you can have it at the PBS price.' My question to you, Minister, is: what is this special patient contribution which announced ever going to do for these two drugs? If there is no chemical substitute, if every patient who is taking that drug needs only that drug and you say they do not have to pay the special patient contribution, that means that no-one will ever pay the special patient contribution, but you cannot have it both ways. You should get up to the dispatch box and say that you announced a mythical policy last Wednesday and that no-one will ever pay the special patient contribution, or you should say that in truth you know some people who need that drug and will pay the special patient contribution despite all of your words of comfort and guarantees. There are only two possibilities, there is no third choice: patients are going to end up paying that special patient contribution, even though it is the only drug they can take, or your special patient contribution is a myth and you can guarantee that no-one will ever have to pay it. But I know what is going to happen: people with lung cancer who cannot take any other medication will have to pay $500 out of their pocket. That is a disgrace equal to where we started this session with you breaking your rock solid ironclad guarantee. It is an absolute disgrace. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: So much special bitterness and bile in one person! Mr Crean-What about yourself?

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Hotham is on thin ice. Ms Gillard interjecting

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I wish the Australian people could see that. That would be interesting. Today, the member for Lalor has made a rare prime time appearance. The incredible, disappearing shadow minister for health has, advisedly, been kept under wraps for the last you six months by the Leader of the Opposition. Mr Crean-Where have you been?

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Hotham will remove himself from the House understanding order 94(a). The member for Hotham then left the chamber.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Until today, all she has been allowed has been four questions. In the face of what she keeps saying is a collapsing health system, chronic incompetence and maladministration, the Leader of the Opposition has allowed her just four questions until today. She got three questions today. Good on her! Obviously, the little touch-up that she got yesterday has worked.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The minister will refer to the member by her seat or title.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I am delighted to think that I still have the capacity to get under her skin. This bile, this anger transference from the Leader of the Opposition-who has advisedly kept her under wraps for the last six months-is quite unbecoming and demeans her. It certainly does not enhance the standards of this House. If our health system is the disaster that the member for Lalor keeps telling us it is then why, when the Leader of the Opposition went out yesterday to reverse his collapsing poll standings and revive the spirit of his demoralised troops, did he nominate three areas he was going to focus on for the rest of this term? He was not going to be distracted by the concerns of voters, he was not going to have anything to do with suggestions that his front-bench are a bunch of dills-oh no, they are all brilliant, as has been demonstrated time after time in question time over the last 10 days-and the three areas they are going to focus on are Telstra, IR and debt. Where is health? Ms Gillard interjecting

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Lalor is in a difficult position. She has been warned.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The Leader of the Opposition either does not think that health is very important or, more likely, he does not like his shadow health minister and does not trust her competence to deliver a substantial message. I was quite interested to hear on Sky News on Monday, 13 June the opposition signalling that it wants to shift the focus to health and land some blows on Minister Tony Abbott. I was quivering with fear and apprehension! I was so nervous I could hardly eat my cornflakes on Tuesday morning! I had to wait all this time to have three or four questions, which are all essentially the same, to which there is a clear answer. Since the member for Lalor made her announcement on Sky News, we have had four press releases and four doorstops but, until today, not a single question on health. We constantly get from the member for Lalor a string of hysterical press releases and a succession of shrill doorstops saying that the sky is falling in and we will all be destroyed because of the evil of the Howard government. Obviously I do not believe her, because I am presiding over the health system. The Australian public do not believe her. According to Newspoll, more and more Australians believe that the Howard government is best placed to handle the issues of health and Medicare. The Leader of the Opposition does not believe the member for Lalor. If he did, he would give her more questions in question time. When the Leader of the Opposition took office, he was asked: Have you given thought to how Labor will change its approach, will need to change its approach to meet that challenge in the Reps? The Leader of the Opposition replied: Yes, I have and totally new significance will come around our tactics committee in the House of Representatives and the role that Julia Gillard plays … A lot of new significance has come in: she now has almost no role! Under the former Leader of the Opposition, the member for Lalor would do a doorstop every day and then ask a question in the House of Representatives. Under the current Leader of the Opposition, she does the doorstop every day-the same shrill, hysterical attacks on the Howard government-but almost never asks a question. It is not just that I do not believe her, it is not just that the Australian public does not believe her and it is not just that her own leader does not believe her; it is that the premiers do not believe her. If the health system were as chronically mismanaged as the member for Lalor keeps telling us, why is it that the premiers and the Prime Minister said in the communique that came out of COAG last week that Australia has one of the world's best health systems? How can it be one of the world's best health systems if, in the words of the member for Lalor, it is suffering from ‘ongoing mismanagement'? The member for Lalor is on her own. She is isolated among her colleagues, unpopular with the Leader of the Opposition and scorned by the premier-those successful and responsible Labor politicians. She is on her own. Let me take a few moments of the House's time to talk about some of the precise issues that the member for Lalor has raised. She says that I denied involvement in the Australians for Honest Politics Trust. I ask: what has that got to do with health? I have never denied involvement in the Australians for Honest Politics Trust. For the record, let me say that I have never denied that. If the member for Lalor is going to come into this House and make statements, as a former partner in a law firm she should at least get right, tell the truth. I think she is suffering from TDD-truth deficit disorder! The next statement she made was that I denied a meeting with Cardinal Pell. Ms Gillard-That is true. I have got the videotape!

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I did not deny a meeting with Cardinal Pell. I said, when asked, that I had no recollection of a meeting. The member for Lalor then said that we had denied that savings were possible in the PBS. Again, that is not true. What we saidMs Gillard-Well, get your letter out!

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: This caterwauling is unbecoming of the House. This shadow minister will treat other members of this House with the same courtesy she received when she made her contribution earlier.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The chair will ensure that, Minister.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I am sure you will, Mr Deputy Speaker. The member for Lalor said we had denied that savings were possible in the PBS. That is not true. We said that savings could not be included in the forward estimates if they were merely speculative or hypothetical; in order to be included in the forward estimates they had to be the result of a change in government policy. When she finally dropped the personal abuse and the litany of untruths and tried to talk about health, she came up with two criticisms. The first criticism was that the 12½ per cent mandatory price cut policy means that patients will allegedly have to pay hundreds of dollars more for necessary drugs. I have already said this several times in the House today, but let me say it again for ‘Madam Slow Learner': if it is clinically necessary in the opinion of the treating doctor that a patient should get a particular drug, all the doctor needs to do is seek an authorisation from the Health Insurance Commission and that it drug will be available to that person at the standard copayment. Please, let us not hear any more of this furphy, this scare tactic. Let us have the member for Lalor tell the truth for once and properly describe the policy of the government as I have repeatedly explained it today. Her next statement about health was that negotiations with the Pharmacy Guild were not going particularly well. Has the member for Lalor ever had negotiations with the Pharmacy Guild? What is the proposal of the member for Lalor? How does the member for Lalor imagine that we are going to get savings out of the PBS through the use of generics? How does the member for Lalor imagine that we are going to get savings out of the PBS through more effective management of the supply and distribution chain? It behoves responsible politicians not just to come in here like Chicken Little and cry day in, day out that the sky is falling in but to come up with some policies of their own. The current Australian Labor Party has two policies. The first policy is Medicare Gold. That policy was described by Michael Costello, the former Chief of Staff to the Leader of the Opposition, as a strategic disaster. It was described by Peter Botsman, a genuine Labor intellectualMr Laurie Ferguson interjecting

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I note the laughter and the scorn coming from the member opposite-as a policy that had the body of a wombat and the head of a donkey. It was described by former President of the Australian Labor Party, former respected member of this House and former minister in the Hawke government, Barry Jones, as a turkey. This is policy No. 1: Medicare Gold-a strategic disaster, a turkey with the body of a wombat and the head of a donkey. What a monster! But it is the conception of the member for Lalor. The other policy of the member for Lalor is to totally abolish the Howard government's Medicare safety net. The member for Lalor comes into this House regularlywhen she is allowed. It is not normally in prime time, but it is in the adjournment and grievance debates and in debates on second reading speeches. She comes in and talks about how terrible it is that the thresholds of the Medicare safety net have been adjusted by the Howard government to what we originally proposed. This terrible crime is that we now have the same safety net thresholds that we originally proposed in November 2003. With all these buckets of crocodile tears, the gallons of indignation and the selfrighteousness dripping out of every pore, what would she do to the threshold? She would abolish it altogether. There would be no safety net. There would be 1.6 million Australians who would totally miss out on the additional help from Medicare that they need and deserve, and $1.1 billion would be ripped out of the Medicare budget because these people are Medicare vandals. That is what members opposite are. That is what they would do if they got the chance. I really do invite interested members of the general public who do take health seriously, who might be following the discussion here this afternoon and who want to figure out who is serious about health, to look at the work of the Howard government: look at the $11 billion more that we have invested since October 2003 in the forward estimates for the Health and Ageing Portfolio; look at the fact that we have got bulk-billing rates up from 66 per cent to 73 per cent; look at the fact that bulk-billing rates for kids are now at an all-time high; and look at the fact that we have settled down the crisis that was enveloping our public hospital system. Compare that with the web site of the Australian Labor Party. These people, who think that health is so important, have devoted just 323 words to health. It is pathetic. It is a disgrace. It is a comment on the fact that the member for Lalor has no standing with her own leader, no standing with her own party and increasingly less standing with the general public that she is forced to come into this House and make the kind of shrill, hysterical and false attacks that we have seen today.

Speaker: Mr BYRNE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: On reflecting on that very passionate contribution by my friend the Minister for Health and Ageing, Tony Abbott, I was very concerned that he was talking about messages of hate, messages not benefiting his career. What I would like to do in light of the blow that he suffered at the hands of the Treasurer, the mentor of the member for Casey, that savage blow trying to destroy his good career, is give him some advice in the spirit of love and friendship with respect to where he is going wrong with the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and the changes that he has proposed. Please read the Hansard, Minister, because I am concerned about your career. I am going to try to put it back on would but take notice of the very constructive suggestions that the opposition will make. My good friend the Minister for Health and Ageing has left the chamber, but at least you can report back to your mentor, member for Casey, now that the minister has gone. You always worry in politics when an announcement that tastes like a specific sort of sandwich and is a specific sort of sandwich gets delivered when you are least likely to see it, particularly at a time of national rebution (SPC). joicing. I have seen some pretty underhandedMs George-Sneaky.

Speaker: Mr BYRNE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: sneaky, mean and tricky press releases put out in the timing of them. Few would match this press release put out just after 6.30 pm, when the nation was rejoicing, under the cover of darkness. I think the minister has got a good career in the SAS after this, quite frankly. He has done an traordinary thing under the cover of darkness that would make the SAS proud. This press release should be of great cern to the least advantaged in our community, who have borne the brunt of a lot of Howard government reforms. It is a very innocuous press release, but it is the hole the dyke. That is what it is and, contrary to what the minister for health has actually said, I think the shadow minister for health is making a very constructive suggestion. As we know, in a number of his public statements the minister for health was quite clear. When he was negotiating that 12.5 per cent cut in prices for generic medicines on the PBS, he said, ‘There won't be any more price rises.' Something happened on the road to Damascus, because very shortly after he said that he issued a very innocuous press release. I am trying to help the minister for health, so I will read some of his press retrack if you lease into the record: The Government is now in the process of implementing 12.5 per cent price cuts for 10 brands of PBS medicines where generic equivalents have applied for listing on August 1. Unfortunately, four companies have not agreed to accept lower prices. As a result four brands of medicines listed on the PBS will be subject to a Special Patient Contribution in addition to the normal PBS co-payment. For these medicines the difference between the existing price for the drug and the new benchmark price will become a Special Patient ContriDr Emerson interjecting

Speaker: Mr BYRNE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I know that this government has taken ‘user pays' to a new level, but this is a very Orwellian-I thank the member for Rankin for saying it as it is-use of language. This is the government that basically said that the Medicare safety net was going to be set at a level and it has increased. This is the government that tells people who have ex- paid their taxes that they should be paying more to see their doctor. Now we have the government basically saying to people, ‘We conscrewed the negotiations with the pharmaceutical companies and now we are going to the screw you by passing this on.' It would be bad enough if these were well-off people or in people who did not necessarily need these drugs, but try telling someone with mesothelioma that they need to pay $460 to get their medication. It is interesting-as in my view this is a hole in the wall. Let us look at some of the antipsychotic drugs, because one of the pharmaceutical companies that refused to accept that 12.5 per cent cut was a company that dealt in antipsychotic and antidepressant medication. The problem is that there are a number of new generation drugs coming on stream which are quite expensive. What will happen, for example, when you have someone with schizophrenia who requires risperidone, which costs $423.96 for 25 milligrams and $632 for 375 milligrams, and this patient needs to have an injection every two weeks? As they are about to receive the injection, will they be asked: ‘Sorry, I've just got to check. Can you pay the difference before we administer this?' This leads to my broader concern with respect to the health minister-a concern that has been constructively raised by the shadow minister for health: there are very scant tails about this policy and the mechanisms and process under which it will operate. No official figures have been released, such as how many people are going to have to access this. What about the number of people who are going to be affected and what is going to happen with the Health Insurance Commission? Very interestingly, who did the health minister consult with before he announced these changes through this press release? I am afraid I cannot find any record, and I have checked with the shadow minister for health about whether or not the health minister has consulted with the Australian Medical Association. If you had brought in a change with substantial ramifications for the future of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, wouldn't you consult with the AMA before you put out a press release? No consultation occurred. That tells me that there is something very rotten in the state of Denmark I said, when it comes to this proposition. In fact, according to the Sydney Morning Herald, the new President of the AMA, Mukesh Haikerwal, said that the new measure was ‘a chink in the armour of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme'. The report stated that, according to Dr Haikerwal: Although doctors would have to play a pivotal role in declaring where patients should be exempt from the additional cost, the medical profession had not been consulted about the move. What sort of change is this? We in the electorate of Holt are used to some funny things happening, I tell you. Mr Anthony Smith-I bet they are with you as their member!

Speaker: Mr BYRNE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: As the member for Casey would know, when we were lobbying for a Medicare office-and my good friend the health minister did in fact come and open it-it took 10 years and a petition with 22,000 signatures to get it. This was the largde- est shopping centre in the Southern Hemisphere and it did not have a Medicare office. It took 10 years and 22,000 signatures. In Cranbourne, where the government has funded a new Medicare office, it took 10 years and 4,500 signatures. So the message is: you pay your taxes in the south-east but you basically have to get a sledgehammer for the government to deliver a service. What do these changes mean to the least well-off, to those with psychotic disorders, to those many Australians who rely on antidepressants and to those dying of lung cancer? The health minister has not made a statement in this place-unless the shadow minister for health has not told me; I certainly have not heard anything. He has done this by stealth. He has slipped a substantial change into the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme under the door while the Prime Minister was addressing this House on a matter of national importance. It is not just us who believe this. I have quoted the President of the AMA, Mukesh Haikerwal. There is a very appropriate headline to an article written about this by Annabel Stafford in the Australian Financial Review. It sort of summarises the minister for health's approach to life. The headline is ‘This is going to hurt'. I think that is very appropriate. It is not just the opposition being critical. For the member for Casey's edification, I quote from the article: Health experts ... have slammed the government's plans to make patients pay for drugs on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, saying it's a dismantling of the cheap medicines scheme by stealth. Someone who I think would be of great importance to the minister for health is the Chief Executive Officer of Catholic Health Australia, Francis Sullivan. I would hope that the minister for health would take notice of him, given his very strong faith. Mr Sullivan said this about these changes: We should make no mistake that these measures, along with the recent cuts to the PBS [safety indicate that the government is looking at every opportunity to shift costs to patients and this in turn erodes any benefit low-paid people receive from the tax relief. So a good friend of the minister for health, the Chief Executive Officer of Catholic Health Australia, Francis Sullivan, has belled the cat-the health minister is not present in the chamber-so it is not just us who are belling the cat on this issue. This is a serious breach in relation to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. When we tried to have a debate on this, it was gagged. I was here. I watched people such as the member for Casey vote against having a debate of substantial importance to this country. If the government want to continue to do this, that is fine; but they should not stand up in here time after time and just repeat the Crosby Textor polling-‘We're the best friend of Medicare'-because this minister is destroying Medicare by stealth. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY SMITH
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: After listening to the contributions of those opposite-the member for Lalor and most recently the member for Holt-it is quite obvious that the motive behind, and the reason for, this matter of public importance is not a concern for health policy. This is not about health policy at all. Both of those members sketched out an elaborate conspiracy theory that reflects either their particular political outlook at the moment or a vivid imagination, or a combination of both. At the outset, I would like to address in some detail why the conspiracy theory, outlined so vividly by the member for Lalor, and to a lesser extent by the member for Holt, simply does not stack up. The motive for proposing this MPI is something entirely different. It is not about the concern of those opposite for health policy, as they would pretend. I will concede that the member for Lalor is far better at pretending that she benet], lieves in something passionately than is the member for Holt. What this MPI is about-and the reason it has been proposed today-has nothing to do with health policy; rather, it is a desperate and irresponsible act by those on the other side to cover up policy and political calamity on issues far away from health. It is to cover up other issues that are quite obvious and which are not at all the subject of a conspiracy. But they do appear in the Australian, where members opposite are being quoted on their views regarding the Labor Party's approach to so many other issues.

Speaker: Unknown
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Opposition members interjecting

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY SMITH
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Among those opposite who are interjecting is my good friend the member for Melbourne Ports, for whom I have high regard. Having a high regard for the member for Melbourne Ports means that I know him well. I know that he will always interject when he is sensitive about a subject-always. The member for Lalor outlined with vivid imagination her conspiracy theory based on an episode of The West Wing. The problem is that her conspiracy theory runs like this: last Thursday a press release went out at a terribly nasty time and, therefore, this was something of great concern to those opposite. The member for Lalor and the member for Holt said they were so concerned about this issue that they wanted to propose an MPI. The only problem is that, if they were so concerned, they would have proposed an MPI at the first available opportunity. If were so concerned, they would have proposed this MPI yesterday. Instead of putting forward an MPI on this matter yesterday, we had an MPI on small business, which was proposed by a shadow minister who is, I think, about 32nd in line. The shadow minister, who is 32nd in the Labor team, got precedence over the member for Lalor. Say she missed out on the MPI in the tactics group yesterday; you would have thought that she would have got a question, that she would have come in here on Tuesday morning

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Casey will refer to members by their title.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY SMITH
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Because the member for Lalor cares so deeply about this issue and has proposed an MPI, she would have come in here and asked the first question. But, no, we had 10 questions without the member for Lalor getting a guernsey, without her asking a question. Today, there were five questions on subjects that had nothing to do with this MPI. The first question from the Leader of the Opposition was on petrol. The second question from the member for Grayndler was on whales. The third question from the member for Hunter was on credit cards. The member for Perth asked the startling question about Comcar drivers. Then we had a question on voluntary student unionism. Finally, after last Thursday, the member for Lalor got a guernsey and asked her first question on health. As I said, if those opposite were really concerned about this issue, if they were deeply of the belief that this was such a critical policy issue, we would have had an MPI yesterday. We would have had questions on Monday and Tuesday. We would have had questions today. The member for Lalor had 25 opportunities to ask a question and she they took the 26th question today. She asked the sixth question in question time today. So we know that deep concern is not the reason she has proposed this MPI-and we know that because she could have done so yesterday. We know that the member for Lalor could have asked the first question, not the 26th. So there must be another reason why this MPI has been proposed. The motive for proposing the MPI is obvious. Those opposite know it. It is another episode of The West Wing that the member for Lalor is acting out, and that is the great diversion from their own policy and political catastrophe. Since the member for Lalor raised American politics, it reminded me of another great political figure who had a vivid imagination-that is, former President Lyndon Johnson. To paraphrase, he said that if you have a relative who has one eye and it is in the middle of their forehead, you do not keep them in the front living room. I am grateful that the member for Reid is in the chamber, because he is that person in the Labor Party. The great problem for the Labor Party is that he is not just in the front living room; he is at the doorstops every morning describing a policy that is completely at odds with his backbench and that has led the leadership of the Labor Party into total policy catastrophe throughout this week. He has announced, I think, three separate positions. Two were identical. The first one was followed by a total reversal a point of order. I appreciate that an MPI discussion should be wide ranging, but this is getting well and truly off the subject matter of the MPI.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Casey should come back to the point of the MPI.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY SMITH
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I am more than happy to. In following the member for Lalor, I thought I should be equally wide ranging. I do appreciate the role of the Whip to cover the uncoverable. I appreciate what the

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Casey will come back to the MPI.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY SMITH
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: That is why this MPI has been proposed, as the Minister for Health and Ageing outlined quite clearly. The MPI is in the following terms: The Government's failure to be accountable for its ongoing mismanagement of Australia's health system. After the Premiers Conference, I would not have thought that any other Labor figure in Australia believed that. As the minister for health points out, Australia has a good health system, and the Labor Premiers agree with that. Whilst those opposite will criticise health system-and the minister for health outlined just what an irresponsible furphy it was that they ran today in question time-we must ask: what is their alternative? When you look back over the last nine years, you see a doubling of the spending on health policy. You see the introduction of a private health insurance rebate, which never existed before, of 30 per cent for the general public, 35 per cent for those aged over 65 and 40 per cent for those over 70. You see the introduction of a Medicare safety net that is now paying benefits for out-of-hospital expenses that Medicare never paid in that form. You would think that if those opposite were criticising the health system they would be offering to increase spending in those areas. But, far from that, the past for those opposite will actually be the future health policy if Labor ever gets its way. If Labor had its way, what health system would we see? Let us go to the substance of this MPI. You would see a health system with no private health insurance rebate. The member for Holt spoke after the member for Lalor about the deep concern for health in his electorate. He obviously has no concern for the more than 40 per cent of people in his electorate who have private health insurance. That is obviously something they have picked up which would explain his result at the last election. Not only would we have no private health insurance rebate; as the minister for health pointed out, we would have no Medicare safety net because, whilst the member for Lalor will criticise the safety net, what she does not publicly outline is that her policy desire is not to alter it or tweak it but to totally abolish it. What is her alternative-Medicare Gold? It has been called fool's gold. I would call it for what it was: ‘Medicare gold tooth'. That policy, amazingly, is the one policy the member for Lalor still sticks to today, in the spite of opposition from those on her own backbench and inside the shadow cabinet. As the minister for health rightly pointed out, Labor figures have called it everything from a strategic disaster, ‘something with the head of a donkey and the body of a wombat', a hoax, to something that proved to be a turkey. Lindsay Tanner, the member for Melbourne, said it would be a very substantial burden on future budgets. This MPI is a furphy. It has been put up to cover up a policy catastrophe on the other side and it should be dismissed for the irrelevancy that it is. (Time expired)

NA Public Works Committee Report

Speaker: Mrs MOYLAN
Title: COMMITTEES
text: On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the sixth, seventh, eighth, ninth and 10th reports for 2005 of the committee relating to the Australia House defence and light wells refurbishment, Australian High Commission, London; the midlife upgrade of the existing chancery at the Australian High Commission in Singapore; new Consulate-General building in Bali, Indonesia; construction of a chancery in Vientiane, Laos; and the Reserve Bank of Australia business resumption site. Ordered that the reports be made parliamentary papers.

Speaker: Mrs MOYLAN
Title: COMMITTEES
text: by leave-The committee's sixth report of 2005 addresses the refurbishment of light wells and defence office accommodation at Australia House in London. The works, referred by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, are intended to ensure compliance with current occupational health and safety standards, provide an acceptable level of amenity for tenants, ensure ongoing viability of the property in respect of income generation and redress degradation of the light well areas. Having investigated the proposal, the committee is satisfied that the works will improve the amenity of the 90-year-old building in a cost-effective manner and therefore recommends that the works proceed at an estimated cost of $11.98 million. The committee's seventh report of 2005 examines the midlife upgrade of Australia's existing chancery building at its High Commission in Singapore. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade reported that the chancery in its current form has significant deficiencies in meeting current occupational health and safety and Building Code of Australia standards. It is dysfunctional and noncost-effective in layout and does not present an appropriate image of Australia in its representational and reception areas. To redress these deficiencies, the department proposes to upgrade building services, access, security and communications systems and reconfigure and refurbish tenant office accommodation. The committee was satisfied with the department's responses to its questions and recommends that the work proceed at an estimated cost of $12.7 million. The committee's eighth report of 2005 deals with a proposal, also by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, to construct a new Consulate-General building in Bali, Indonesia, at an estimated cost of $7.15 million. The department reported that the former Consulate-General building in Bali is no longer suitable to fulfil its consular and representative role, with significant deficiencies in respect of occupational health and safety, floor space and functionality, building structure and services and particularly security. Since the terrorist bombing in 2002, the Australian Consulate-General in Bali has been accommodated in leased premises-a situation that is not sustainable in the long term. The committee is in no doubt as to the requirement for the proposed work and recommends that it proceed. Further, the committee is pleased to note that the proposed work will provide a permanent site for, and improve access to, the memorial garden and anniversary pond erected to victims of the Bali bombing. A further proposal by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade-namely, the construction of a new chancery in Vientiane, Laos-forms the subject of the committee's ninth report of 2005. The proposed new building, estimated to cost $11 million, is intended to replace the existing chancery, which was acquired and refurbished in 1961 and no longer maintains modern standards in respect of services, layout, building codes occupational health and safety requirements. The committee has given detailed consideration to this proposal and it recommends that the works proceed at an estimated cost of $11 million. The 10th report of 2005 presents the committee's findings in relation to the proposed construction of a dedicated business resumption site for the Reserve Bank of Australia. The purpose of the proposed work is to provide a facility that, in the event of an emergency, will ensure the continuation of functions critical to the operation of Australia's financial systems. During the course of its inquiry, the committee investigated the revenue to be generated and/or saved by this project, issues relating to relocation and commodation of staff, the use of the facility, electricity supply, energy consumption and green building initiatives. The committee was particularly impressed by the range of energy and water conservation measures proposed for the new facility and was pleased with the high quality of the evidence submitted by the Reserve Bank, which assisted greatly in the speedy completion of inquiry. The committee has no hesitation in recommending that the proposed work proceed, at the estimated cost of $38 million. I would like to take this opportunity to thank my committee colleagues and all those involved in the five inquiries, and I commend the reports to the House. Public Accounts and Audit Committee Report

Speaker: Mr BALDWIN
Title: COMMITTEES
text: Paterson) (4.01 pm)On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit, I present the following report: Report No. 403-Access of Indigenous Australians to law and justice services. Ordered that the report be made a parliamentary paper.

Speaker: Mr BALDWIN
Title: COMMITTEES
text: by leave-On behalf of or the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit, I have just presented the committee's Report No. 403, Access of Indigenous Australians to law and justice services. The terms of reference were adopted and the inquiry commenced in the previous parliament, when the committee was capably chaired by Bob Charles and his deputy, the member for Sydney, Tanya Plibersek.
