Two ongoing members of the sectional committee, the current deputy chair, Sharon Grierson, and Senator John Hogg, provided important continuity to the inquiry over the two parliaments. The committee's inquiry examined the delivery of legal services to Indigenous Australians from the perspective of providers and actheir clients. Of particular concern to the committee was the access that Indigenous Australians have to family and civil law services in cases where the safety of individuals is threatened by criminal activity, such as family violence. This report makes 17 recommendations for the government to consider that build upon programs already in place. The comthe mittee has recognised the government's doubling of resources to the Family Violence Protection Legal Services program over the last financial year as an important response to family violence in Indigenous communities and has recommended a further expansion of these services to people living in ban areas. While the committee is in no way opposed to the holistic response to victims of family violence, incorporating services such as counselling, it has recommended that family violence protection legal services be recognised primarily as providers of legal representation and advice to persons at risk of violence, who must be assured of their full rights to protection and compensation under the law. The importance of expert staff in providing legal services to Indigenous Australians should not be underestimated. To this end, the committee has recommended an investigation into and review of comparative rates of remuneration for staff of Indigenousspecific providers of legal services and of publicly funded mainstream providers. There is also room for increased cooperation and coordination between Indigenous-specific and mainstream service providers to promote mutual benefits to staff in both types of organisations. In conclusion, I would like to express the committee's appreciation to those people who contributed to the inquiry by preparing submissions and giving evidence at public hearings. I particularly want to thank the people of the community of Yuendumu in the Northern Territory for their hospitality and their frankness. It was an example of how cultural law and common law can work together for outcomes in the community. I wish to thank all members of the sectional committee involved for their time and dedication in conducting this inquiry. I commend the report to the House.

Speaker: Ms GRIERSON
Title: COMMITTEES
text: by leave-As Deputy Chair of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit, I am also pleased to draw the attention of the House to our recent report No. 403, Access of Indigenous Australians to law and ur- justice services. This report's recommendations give government clear direction for the future provision of Indigenous law and justice services. The report strongly recommends the acceptance of separate and specific requirements for the three main areas of legal services-family, civil and criminal law-matched of course by adequate funding. It draws attention to the tendency for legal representation services to be directed primarily at those facing criminal charges and possible incarceration. In the interests of women and children, the family violence prevention legal services so needed in both urban and rural Indigenous communities must be consistently accessible and available. The committee received evidence that from 1991 to 2001 the number of Australian women in custody increased by 147 per cent. Indigenous women were included in that figure. The corresponding increase for Indigenous women alone was 225.8 per cent. To us, it was very evident that services are needed. In my own region, the Many Rivers Aboriginal Legal Service explained that the increase in the incarceration of Indigenous women was a response to high incidences of family violence and child sexual assault. They said: ... we are starting to see the flow-through into older ages of a lot of child victims of sexual assault, physical assault and systems abuse from having been made state wards and left high and dry. We have much to achieve in providing for women and children and in healing the harm that past policies have done to the Indigenous people in this country. No stronger evidence of that was presented than that at Dubbo, where sadly we were part of the grief and despair around a death in custody at that time. For the committee members, it was a very poignant and certainly pointed reminder that we have much to do in representing Indigenous people. Ways for government to adequately respond to the problems of staff recruitment and retention were identified in the report. Comparable pay rates, exchange programs, scholarships bonded to regional service, and assisted training and development plans for paralegal community support workers were all recommended, as were the better coordination of legal services and the sharing of resources. I draw particular attention, as the chair did, to some wonderful initiatives towards multiagency policies and policing in Western Australia, and I thank those involved for their initiative, their innovation and their commitment. Many service providers strongly expressed their concerns that the government's new tendering system may compromise Indigenous ownership of legal services and Indigenous participation. But, pleasingly, it seems that the government has heeded those concerns, with successful tenderers thus far in Queensland, Victoria and Western Australia all being Aboriginal legal services. It was truly a privilege to be invited people of Yuendumu to visit their community. Life experiences reinforce that local solutions work best, and the self-determined initiatives to overcome petrol sniffing, domestic violence and antisocial behaviour by youth that the people of Yuendumu have devised are exemplary. There is no place in government for programs of paternal benevolence such as the recently endorsed petrol for parenting measures, but there is a real place for taking notice of Indigenous communities when they pose local solutions to problems that eat away at their community's prosperity. I thank the people of Yuendumu. I was touched by their wisdom and by their commitment to their kin and community. Recent media articles have raised concerns amongst the community that committees do not achieve real effectiveness in shaping government policy. I am proud to say that this report and this inquiry have already been effective. This report is a tribute to the committee's secretariat, particularly Dr Glen Worthington, and to all those who submitted to and supported the committee in its deliberations. I would also endorse the chair's acknowledgements and appreciation. I can say that this was perhaps one of the too few experiences that we have in this House that motivate us to achieve more through our work here as parliamentarians. I commend the report to the House. Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Crime Commission Report

Speaker: Mr KERR
Title: COMMITTEES
text: On behalf of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Crime Commission, I present the committee's report on the examination of the Australian Crime Commission's annual report 2003-04 together with the evidence received by the committee. I move that the by the report be made a parliamentary paper. Question agreed to.

Speaker: Mr KERR
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I seek leave of the House to make a short statement. Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr KERR
Title: COMMITTEES
text: On behalf of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Crime Commission, I present the committee's report on the examination of the Australian Crime Commission's annual report 2003-04. The Australian Crime Commission's annual report was presented out of session on 21 December 2004 and was tabled in both houses on 8 February 2005, in accordance with section 61 of the Australian Crime Commission Act 2002. The duties of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Crime Commission are prescribed under section 55 of the Australian Crime Commission Act 2002. These duties include examining each annual report of the Australian Crime Commission and reporting to the parliament on any matter appearing in or arising out of any such annual report. In the course of its scrutiny of the Australian Crime Commission report, the committee held a number of hearings in Canberra on 17 March and wrote to a number of individuals and organisations, inviting them to comment on the annual report. We received seven submissions as well as a number of letters that expressed satisfaction with the operation of the Australian Crime Commission. This year's Australian Crime Commission report is significant in that its reporting period covers the first full year of the commission's operation. It gives the committee, the parliament and the electorate the opportunity to evaluate the progress of the Australian Crime Commission towards its stated objective of ‘reducing incidence and impact of serious and organised criminal activity'. The committee draws the House's attention to a number of recommendations made in the report that are designed to provide more public information about the Australian Crime Commission's operation. They include a recommendation that the Australian Crime Commission consider the release of public versions of key research, including a declassified version of the informative picture of criminality. The committee has also recommended that the Australian Crime Commission review the legal and administrative arrangements governing information on its intelligence networks and that it brief the committee on the results. To make some of the performance indicators more informative for the committee, the parliament and the community, the committee has included recommendation 4: ... continued refinement of the performance measures, including an explanation of the significance of quantitative and qualitative indicators. Recommendation 5 also concerns performance indicators. The committee has recommended that those performance indicators relating to criminal intelligence operations include, subject to reasonable security considerations, how priority is given to matters submitted to the Australian Crime Commission board for consideration. In making these recommendations, our committee is acutely aware of the necessarily confidential nature of the work of the Australian Crime Commission; there is a fine line to be drawn between information which must be kept confidential for operational reasons and that which can be released for general use. However, the committee considers that the recommendations made in this report will not compromise the Australian Crime Commission in any way and will provide a greater understanding of the work and achievements of the commission. In conducting its evaluation of the annual report, the committee acknowledges the assistance of the chairman of the ACC board, Commissioner Mick Keelty, the CEO, Mr Alistair Milroy, and officers of the Australian Crime Commission. Throughout the reporting period, the ACC has provided considerable assistance to the committee through written reports and briefings as well as through verbal presentations. The commission's willingness to assist the committee has been of great assistance and has contributed to a transparent and cooperative relationship. The committee would like to acknowledge also the considerable assistance of Professor John MCMillan, the Commonwealth Ombudsman, and his staff. I also take this opportunity to thank the secretariat staff for the consistent support they have given to the committee. Finally, I take this opportunity to inform the House that, following discussions with the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Ellison, the committee has agreed to conduct a statutory evaluation of the operation of the Australian Crime Commission Act, pursuant to section 61 of that act. This inquiry will call for submissions in the near future. It will be an excellent opportunity to examine the adequacy of the act to provide a practical working framework for the Australian Crime Commission in a criminal environment, which is not only national but also transnational in character. NA NA BILL 2005 Second Reading Debate resumed.

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Title: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: Grayndler) (4.15 pm)When I began my speech prior to question time, I did not get through to the completion of my amendment, so I might start at the beginning again. I move: That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: “whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House: (1) notes that: (a) the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Amendment Act 2003 received bi-partisan support as it built constructively on the Ozone Protection legislation of the Hawke and Keating Governments; (b) the licensing process for the air tioning and refrigerant industry being undertaken by an industry board (appointed by the Minister) is the keystone of the proposed ozone and synthetic greenhouse gas emission minimisation program; (c) the licensing regime for 50,000 tradespeople commences on 1 July 2005; and (2) is concerned that, as a result of unnecessary delays caused by the Minister for the Environment; (a) the national industry board for the air conditioning and refrigerant industry was belatedly appointed on 31 May 2005, six months after it was expected to be announced and only one month before the new licensing regime begins; (b) there was widespread frustration and confusion in the industry because the reforms proposed by the Act were delayed; and (c) the environmental improvements which are the rationale for the 2003 Act have not been achieved”. I note that a very similar second reading amendment was passed by the Senate without any dissent being recorded. Clearly, there must be some concern amongst the minister's own Senate colleagues over his handling of this issue; otherwise, the government would have argued against the minister being criticised for causing unnecessary delays in the appointment of the industry board. Also, you would have thought the government would have supported the minister against criticisms that he had not achieved the environmental improvements which are the rationale for the 2003 act. Clearly, the criticisms are well founded, and that is why the Senate voted as it did. The Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 proposes amendments to two acts: the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act condi- 1989 and the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust Act 2001. The proposed amendments to the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act are relatively uncontroversial and are of a housekeeping nature. They ensure that a person importing or exporting used HCFC or methyl bromide has either a used substances licence or a controlled substances licence-not both, as could be the case under the existing act. It also applies the same controls and reporting requirements to anyone who sets up a synthetic greenhouse gas-SGG-manufacturing operation in Australia as those applying to SGG importers. The amendments to the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust Act 2001 permit the sale of a disused scout hall in Mosman and a land swap to replace the lost public space. These are uncontroversial and have the support of the New South Wales government. The Sydney Harbour Federation Trust legislation is legislation that I spoke on when it was introduced. The harbour is the jewel in Sydney's crown, and I, as someone who was born there and loves Sydney Harbour, certainly believe that Sydney is the jewel in Australia's crown. Anything we can do to protect and enhance the Sydney Harbour National Park and the public space around the harbour is to the benefit of all Australians. On this side of the House, we support these minor changes to the act. I want to confine my comments today primarily to the changes that are effected by the amendments to the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act. The main industries affected by the amendments to this act are the refrigeration and air conditioning industries and the fumigation industry. In Australia, the regulation of the fluorocarbon gases used in the refrigerant industry started when the Hawke Labor government introduced the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act 1989 to phase out CFCs and implement the Montreal protocol. CFCs, as everyone came to know, were causing global ozone depletion or, to put it another way, a hole in the ozone layer. International action on this important issue was urgent, and the Hawke Labor government acted quickly and decisively to phase out the import and manufacture of CFCs by 1 January 1996. Recently I had the pleasure, at an Australian-Israel Chamber of Commerce function in Sydney, to hear Dr David Suzuki talk about climate change and the challenge that it presented to us. He drew parallels with the issue of CFCs and their impact on the ozone layer and how, originally, it was thought that these revolutionary consumer items were going to bring great benefit to us. It took time for the danger that CFCs were causing to the ozone layer and the threat that they posed to the global environment to be recognised. There is a parallel with the current debate on climate change and the danger that greenhouse gases are causing to the climate and, therefore, not just to our environment but also to our potential economic future. I am very pleased and proud to say that the Hawke Labor government's decision to phase out CFCs by 1 January 1996 was achieved with strong community support and without significant disruption to industry. It is a great practical example of taking action that is necessary, rather than finding reasons not to take action as a global community. The Hawke Labor government's actions are in stark contrast to the complacency of the Howard government when it comes to climate change. In 1995, the Keating Labor government continued this good work and introduced the Ozone Protection Amendment Act 1995, which included controls on HCFCs, reflecting their inclusion in the Montreal protocol. HCFCs are also an ozone-depleting gas, albeit considerably less so than CFCs. They will be phased out by 2020 at a rate considerably in advance of Australia's international obligations. This great result was achieved because the Keating government worked with industry to do the best that it could, not merely just the minimum. Again, the Keating Labor government's actions are in stark contrast to the abject complacency and incompetence of the Howard government when it comes to taking action on climate change. The Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Amendment Act 2003 included controls on HFCs and was seen as a useful step by the industry. It received biparminister tisan support. The legislation will minimise emission of HFC gases which are controlled by the Kyoto protocol but previously uncontrolled in Australia. HFC gases are mainly used as refrigerants. These gases do not deplete the ozone layer but do have a significant greenhouse warming potential. End use controls-that is, minimising the emissions of these gases to atmosphere through sound industrial practices-are contained in the regulations dated 16 December 2004. The controls are put in place by improving training and other standards in the industry, fying tradespersons and inspecting associated work. Without an appropriate licence a tradesperson will not be permitted to purchase refrigerants. Companies buying and selling refrigerants or using refrigerants manufacturing process will also have to be appropriately licensed, abide by agreed standards and be subject to inspection. This licensing process is a keystone of the act's emission minimisation program and is to be undertaken by an industry board to be appointed by the minister. The board was to be directed by the Department of the Environment and Heritage. This approach received strong industry support and emerged from a consultation and review process held over a number of years. Somewhat scandalously, the minister did not appoint the industry board until three weeks ago-on 31 May 2005. With nobody to put the program in place until three weeks ago, the legislation passed way back in late 2003 has not, up to this point, produced a tangible environmental benefit. According to ABC news reports in February, the appointment of a national industry board was derailed after lobbying from a small section of the industry in Western Australia. After achieving bipartisan support for such important legislation and also getting industry support for national regulation, the backflipped and wanted to rewrite the whole thing. This step was taken without consultation with industry, and the minister refused to meet with industry representatives. The minister stated that he wanted to take in ‘regional and sectoral' considerations. I think everyone here knows what that is code for when this minister and other ministers in the Howard government speak about ‘sectoral' considerations. The minister delayed the whole licensing regime for six months while he tried to find a way to accommodate these parochial interests. Not certisurprisingly, the minister's approach was severely criticised by the industry. Senior people in the refrigeration industry could not hold back their anger and frustration with the minister. The editorial in the in a April 2005 edition of Climate Control News stated: The Minister's decisionnot to proceed with a single national boardhas left a broad cross section of the Aussie refrigeration industry in varying degrees of anger, frustration and confusion. What an editorial-anger, frustration and confusion caused by government inaction. But the editorial had a bit more to say than that. It went on: But the real loser in all this is the very thing the whole process was set up to save-the environment. ... Despite being millions of dollars and four years down the track, not a single gram of carbon dioxide equivalent has been saved from entering the ether. Like Nero all those centuries ago, the earth is burning while Campbell fiddles. Ms Julie Bishop interjecting

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Title: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: The Minister for Ageing laughs at the predicament that the minister finds himself in. Ms Julie Bishop-I laughed at the Shakespearean overtones.

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Title: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: Minister, that was an editorial from the April 2005 edition of Climate Control News. It is not from the Labor Party and it is not from the trade union movement; it is from the main industry newsletter-people on the ground who know what the impact of this government's inaction has been. Also quoted in the April edition of Climate Control News was Rod King, president of the Air Conditioning and Refrigeration Equipment Manufacturers Association-note: the association, not the union; this is the industry. He said: There have been press reports that the Minister is considering establishing multiple boards-but we can find no justification or rationale for this proach. We have just spent years getting to the point where we have comprehensive national regulation of refrigerants and now there seems to be a move to implement accreditation on a state basis. But Mr King went on to say a bit more as well. He said: This approach is completely inconsistent with other Federal Government reforms, such as the move towards a unitary industrial relations system. But who could expect consistency from this government? They have been up at the International Whaling Commission arguing that secret ballots are a bad thing, and yet in industrial relations, when it comes to workers having control over their own environment, they are pro secret ballots. So it is consistency that is needed when it comes to the environment, just as on the issue of the Kyoto protocol we have a different position from that which we had on the Montreal protocol. By our not being a part of the most significant global effort on the most important environmental challenge facing the global community, that of avoiding dangerous climate change, we are undermined when we talk to the international community about issues that everyone here would agree with-everyone except the parliamentary secretary for tourism-which is that whaling is a practice that should be consigned to the dustbin of history. We need consistency when it comes to the environment if we are going to be able to achieve real gains. Alan Woodhouse, the CEO of the Australian Refrigeration Council, another industry body, stated: We are all very disappointed. The Government called for tenders to fulfil a single national industry board. We responded with a very thorough tender that complied with all the specifications. Now, nearly 12 months later the Department of Environment and Heritage is abandoning the original tender and the structure and outcome apfrom work put in over the last three years. Why? Alan Woodhouse then noted he was ‘understandably bewildered and upset' by the minister's actions. In attempting to overturn the national approach and protect parochial interests at the expense of a consistent national approach, the minister has threatened the underlying philosophy behind this important legislation, which enjoyed bipartisan support in this House. The delays in appointing the industry board exposed the air conditioning and refrigeration industry to severe consequences as the industry board issues the licences which will be required by law for 50,000 tradespeople after 1 July 2005. So you have got a system that is going to apply to 50,000 people in 10 days time being debated in this House now, when the board was appointed at the end of last month, on 31 May. This is an extraordinary performance even by the minister's own standards when it comes to taking decisive action on issues of environment and heritage. And that is why Labor is moving the second reading amendment today. It is also possibly why the Senate carried the second reading amendment yesterday without the government members even calling for a vote or expressing opposition to our amendment. Ms George-Amazing. Embarrassed, were they?

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Title: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: As the member for Throsby, the parliamentary secretary for environment and heritage for the Labor Party, says, I think they were embarrassed by this performance, because the whole purpose of the licensing regime is to minimise ozonedamaging gases and other greenhouse gas emissions. There has been widespread frustration and confusion in the air conditioning and refrigeration industry because the reforms proposed by the act have been delayed by the minister. More than 50,000 tradespeople in the air conditioning and refrigeration industry have been frustrated and confused as to what the industry's licensing regime It is a scandal that the environmental improvements which are the rationale for the bipartisan 2003 act have not been achieved. Once again this shows the minister and the Howard government are just not serious about taking practical steps to avoid dangerous climate change. The Howard government is slow, it is reluctant and it is complacent when it comes to tackling the issue of climate change. National leadership is needed to avoid dangerous climate change, but instead Australia has a lethargic, tired approach. Climate change caused by the burning of fossil fuels and greenhouse gases is changing Australia's climate right now. Australia is one of the most important crossroads in its history. What we do in the next 10 years about these issues will determine the fate of our economy and our environment for the rest of this century and beyond. The extended four-year drought gripping Australia is the most dramatic example of climate change to hit our continent. Experts predict Australia is going to get progressively drier over the coming century because of changes to our climate caused by greenhouse pollution. According to the CSIRO, climate change will only worsen drought conditions. The Prime Minister's decision not to ratify the Kyoto protocol-having had the former Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Hill, sign the Kyoto protocol in 1997 and declare it a win for the environment and a win for jobs-is an outrage. Mr Lloyd interjecting

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Title: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: The member for Robertson, sitting opposite, proclaims confusion about jobs and the Kyoto protocol. But I was quoting the Prime Minister from 1997that is what he said. He was right then but he is wrong now when it comes to taking decisive action, because the decision not to ratify is. the Kyoto protocol is stopping new investment in technology which would reduce greenhouse gases, create jobs and move Australia to a cleaner, more secure energy future. The Kyoto protocol is not perfect, but it is an essential first step and shows what can be done when the international community works together. It is a global solution to a global problem. Not ratifying Kyoto means Australia cannot contribute to how the world is dealing with the climate crisis. One hundred and forty other nations are having a say, but we are not. We have no credibility in the discussions over emission reductions in future international agreements, which will take effect after 2012. Quite clearly much at deeper cuts will be necessary. In a passionate speech in Britain recently, the international Chairman of Shell, Lord Oxburgh, stated: We have roughly 45 years. And if we start NOW, not in 10 or 15 years' time, we have a chance of hitting those greenhouse gas reduction targets. But we've got to start now. We have no time to lose ... The boat is sinking, and we have to everything that we possibly can. It is extraordinary that companies such as Shell and BP are so far ahead of the position taken by someone like the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, who thinks that climate change is not really happening. People in industry, including those industries which have contributed greatly to climate change, understand very well that the world has to change. Certainly the frustration of the refrigeration industry is another example of the overwhelming frustration felt by those who recognise the dangers of climate change and want to do something about it. That is what the second reading amendment that we have moved today is about. My colleague the member for Throsby will second it. It is a fair and balanced amendment, and I ask members to join with the Senate in supporting it.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: Is the amendment seconded? Ms George-I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

Speaker: Mr LAMING
Title: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: Bowman) (4.39 pm)This afternoon is a timely moment to reflect on Australia's achievements with greenhouse gases. Obviously, the Montreal protocol pertains to the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 that we are debating today and the amendments to the legislation which, as we can see, have support from both sides of the House and are relatively minor. The Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act 1989 needs to be amended in three or four ways. It will bring licensing of domestic producers into line with importers and exporters. I think that is appropriate. not be the complexity of requiring both used and controlled substance licences. I think that is also appropriate. Finally, the process of reporting to the minister on when these use products are imported and exported will now be brought into line for domestic producers and manufacturers. I think that is all relatively non-controversial. Right now is an excellent time to remember exactly what has been achieved by Australia in reducing the use of these gases. The gases have important roles in industry. The most obvious one is their quarantine application. I experienced that myself when we brought material back from a recent visit from Papua New Guinea which was fumigated. There are quarantine uses for these heavy gases. There are the non-quarantine applications which pertain to the Montreal protocol. That protocol only pertains to nonquarantine uses. In the areas of refrigeration, use in the manufacture of foams, use as solvents and air conditioning, we have seen significant reductions. The point I make today is that had we simply stuck to the bare bones of the protocol we would be importing today 240 tonnes of methyl bromide. But, no, we have done significantly better at 160 tonnes and I think that should be acknowledged. If we hung purely and simply on the symbolism of signing to a protocol and doing not an ounce better, then we would be performing significantly more poorly than we actually are today. I would point out that it is not always government, whether we are in power or opposition, that should be congratulated for those achievements but industry themselves that go out there and go one step better than the protocol. I think that is a fine allegory for the debate we are having around Kyoto where our reductions and emissions are in line with achieving the 2008-2012 objective There will of being as George-So why don't you ratify it?

Speaker: Mr LAMING
Title: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: Because we are doing it and industry is doing it without that ratification down to 108 per cent of emissions in 1995. These gases also have applications in medicine and science. Heavy gases are used in eye surgery where a millilitre of heavy gas is used to reattach retinas. I do not see that one as threatening the ozone layer, but it is important to remember that there is still, as we reduce the use of these substances, a notable but very small tail where they will still be used. The HCFCs I hope will be phased out within a year or two, but methyl bromide which has some more essential applications one would suspect will be used perhaps early into the next decade. I have made my point already about the use of HCFCs being 160 tonnes of importation. Methyl bromide is at 145 tonnes and that is predicted to fall next year to 66 and the following year to 42 tonnes. That is a substantial reduction and a credit again to industry and also to two bodies that have been running now for some time. I refer to the National Halon Bank, which has been responsible for collecting about 1,985 tonnes of halon. While a small amount of that will be required to be saved for aviation use, the rest is being cleaned up and either preserved or destroyed. The Halon Bank has been a very effective way of avoiding around 160 million tonnes of ozone being destroyed in the atmosphere. The other body is Refrigerant Reclaim Australia, which has been responsible for collecting refrigeration gases-around 1,000 tonnes. Some of these are extremely ozone damaging. We are talking about one kilogram of these gases being able to destroy up to 50 tonnes of ozone. When you think that this molecule is only present in perhaps three or four molecules per million and has such an important role in blocking ultraviolet C and effectively in important health applications, there are very good reasons for keeping ozone intact. What you have effectively done with that reclamation is to avoid around six million tonnes of CO² going into the atmosphere. They are two very good success stories for the work that has been done over recent years. I turn my attention to the member for Grayndler, who spent most of the time allotted to him focusing on effectively cobbling together some opinions of individuals who are unhappy with the speed of the process. And there was a great fixation on board appointments. But what is far more important than anything is the fact that we have had significant reductions-among the best in the world-and have got the use, the importation and the collection of some of these heavy gases to be world standard. That is really where the action is. The action is not what tonnes has been signed and what has not been signed, but what is happening on the ground. For that reason, I believe that industry itself deserves an enormous amount of credit. Industry itself is now finding alternative heavy gases to use. In some cases that is very difficult, and the federal government has set out some critical use exemptions which are very important. This again speaks to the fact that, if you have a government prepared to work with industry rather than using a protocol in a punitive way, you do not need to have that luxury of sitting back and saying, ‘We have signed and that was enough. We have achieved what was signed off on a protocol, and that is all we intend to do.' That a constructive approach goes much further than what one would sign up to in a protocol is evidenced here with Australia's achievements in relation to these heavy gases. That is analogous to the situation with the Kyoto protocol. We now have significant reductions. There is still HCFC reliant equipment and machinery that will be using heavy gases-in small amounts-until the end of its lifespan. That is an important concession made so that industry is able to comply, to go about finding alternatives. But it is not done in a punitive way; it is done with a discrete allocation of time for industry to be able to respond. That is really important. About 5,100 ozone-depleting potential tonnes of material are being prevented from being released into the atmosphere. Again, that is a significant improvement on what is happening in a number of situations around the world in a number of economies. The achievements of the Halon Bank, as I have pointed out, are impressive, as is the reclamation of refrigerant gases. Industry is supportive of all of these three amendments. There is no doubt that, of these ozonedepleting substances, some also have greenhouse impacts, but we have seen a movement from some of the highly ozonedamaging substances, with an ozonedepleting effect of about 0.4, down to some HCFCs that are in the realm of about 0.05. That is a significant improvement, and we are seeing that in the outcomes for Australia in being well in front of its obligations due the Montreal protocol. I believe it is industry that should be congratulated for those achievements; it is the government that has continued to tighten up legislation as required. For each of those reasons, I speak in support of the amendments today. We have excellent end use regulations, so there is provision there for industry, and industry appreciates the flexibility, but end I would say that it is not the small arguments that are contained in these amendments that are important. What is truly important is the eventual emission reductions from Australia, for they are world class.

Speaker: Ms GEORGE
Title: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: I thank the member for Bowman for his contribution to the debate on the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2005. It was quite an erudite scientific and technical explanation, some of which went over my head as I do not have that level of detailed knowledge about the science of the issue and its impacts. But what I did find rather surprising in his contribution was that he failed to respond to the essence of the argument of the member for Grayndler, which was to compare and contrast the international action, with Australia's support, to deal with the impacts of the depletion of the ozone layer-how Australia really led the way in that debate and the actions that have subsequently flowed-with the total inactivity over the newest global threat that is confronting all of mankind, and that is global warming. The shadow minister was making the point that Australia supported the ratification of the Montreal protocol. But, unfortunately, and much to the regret of people on this side of the House, the Australian government continues to fail to ratify the Kyoto protocol. The Kyoto protocol, as members know, has now been ratified by about 140 developed to nations. Only Australia and the United States stand outside the ratification process on an issue that many Australian citizens believe is the greatest threat facing not just our own country but the global community. That was a profound point made by the member for Grayndler. People on this side of the chamber take great pride in the fact that it was under the in the Hawke Labor government that this nation took steps to fall into line with the calls that were being made to ensure that we phased out the use of substances that depleted the ozone layer. At that time, the data that was being collected revealed a general thinning of the ozone layer over most of the globe. This included a five to nine per cent depletion over Australia since the 1960s, and it was having very severe impacts over Antarctica. The ozone hole in 2000 was the largest on record. At that time, it measured 32.9 million square kilometres-more than three times the size of Australia. It is not surprising that the Australian community at large was very concerned about the impacts of that depletion and the far-reaching consequences for human health. As the member for Bowman rightly said, governments around the world began the phasing out of CFCs, halons and other ozone-depleting chemicals. Those chemicals had been widely used as refrigerants, aerosol propellants and foam-blowing agents. The success of the action under the Montreal protocol is now evidenced by the fact that eminent scientists now believe that the prospects for the long-term recovery of the ozone layer are improving. Non-essential consumption of major ozone depleting substances did in fact slow down during the early 1990s, and if we continue to give this issue our best efforts some estimate that the hole in the ozone layer could be fully recoverable by around 2050. Interestingly enough, had we not taken action as a nation in concert with the rest of the international community, studies seem to suggest that by 2050 ozone depletion would be 10 times worse than current levels and UVB radiation would have resulted in an estimated 19 million additional cases of nonmelanoma skin cancer, 1.5 million more cases of melanoma and 129 million more cases of eye cataracts. The seriousness of the situation compelled an international response at that time. I am very pleased that our country was part of that international effort. It is much to the shame of the Howard government and the Australian nation that the same commitment to solving another international and global crisis is not being made by this government. The member for Bowman rightly acknowledges-and I want to say a little more about this-that the substitute gases, the more ozone benign gases, are in fact themselves contributing to the greenhouse impact. I recently read a UN report which was headed ‘Safeguarding the ozone layer and the global climate system'. You would assume that the substitution of ozone friendly gases would not cause any irreparable harm and any consequent flow-on effects. But in fact what this and other reports are suggesting is that in phasing out CFCs, halons and other ozone depleting chemicals we have replaced them with alternatives that are having a marked impact on global warming. Like CFCs, some of the alternatives, such as the group referred to as HCFCs, HFCs and PFCs, are themselves powerful greenhouse gases. In the words of the Secretary-General of the World Meteorological Organisation: Although climate change and ozone destruction are essentially different issues, our use of certain chemicals links them together. He goes on to argue: We must continuously monitor, undertake research and improve how we manage this group of extremely useful substances, which is implicated in not one, but two of the major environmental problems we have ever known.' To limit their damaging effects governments have included two of the CFC alternatives in the 1992 UN climate change convention and in the Kyoto protocol, under which signatory countries must reduce their emissions from a basket of six greenhouse gases by the period 2008 to 2012. This basket contains the alternative HFCs and PFCs. The contribution that CFCs and their replacements and other ozone-depleting substances currently make to global warming is estimated to be about five per cent of humanity's total greenhouse gas emissions. I raise this issue because the major concern in the public debate is with the contribution of carbon to greenhouse warming. In fact, the substitutes that we are now using to continue to protect the ozone layer are themselves partly contributing to greenhouse gas emissions and global warming. This report went on to recommend some simple and common sense practices that should be put in place to minimise the impact of the ozone friendly chemicals on global warming. The report says that containment can be improved to prevent leaks, evaporation and emissions of unintended by-products. About 65 per cent of today's total emissions from this group of chemicals still comes from CFCs, mainly from existing refrigeration and air conditioning equipment. Reducing leaks from these sources could cut greenhouse gas emissions, benefiting both the ozone layer and climate change. Amounts of the chemicals needed in equipment can be reduced and there should be more end-of-life recovery, recycling and destruction of HFCs and PFCs. Since virtually all ozone depleting substances and their replacements are now used in closed systems, they are not emitted until years or even decades after being produced. Large amounts of CFCs still exist in current refrigeration and air conditioning equipment and in insulating foams from which they can leak or evaporate. Later, as the report indicates, when the equipment is finally decommissioned, these gases can be released into the atmosphere. While I commend the bipartisan approach that we have seen in the past in phasing out ozone depleting substances, many of the alternative gases that are now being used, whilst ozone benign, are potent greenhouse gases contributing to the greenhouse effect. I point out, as the member for Grayndler did, that there was a concerted international effort led by our national government on the ozone layer, but on the issue of global warming this national government is missing in action by its failure to ratify the Kyoto protocol. So, that context, we have to be even more vigilant that there are systems in place to monitor the impact on global warming of these ozone benign gases. On the specifics of the legislation, the member for Grayndler went through the lead-up and the details contained in the amendments so I do not want to dwell on the detail for too long, other than to say that the implementation of the proposed licensing regime and the creation of the new council has been another example of a botched effort on behalf of the minister who has overall responsibility for protection of Australia's environmental conditions. The new refrigeration licensing system is to replace existing state systems and, as the member for Grayndler rightly pointed out in moving his amendments to the bill, the industry has experienced a litany of delays and frustrations in getting the system into place. There is no doubt this has caused concern and frustration in the industry, and the comments the member for Grayndler made, drawing on a number of industry sources and industry bodies, I think make that very clear. Here we are today in parliament debating a piece of legislation that is supposed to come into effect on 1 July. I do note, though, that there are now transitional arrangements under the licensing regime because there is no way that people are going to have their licences properly in place by the operative date of 1 July when something like 50,000 tradespeople are going to be incorporated as part of this new regime. There are also many in the industry who are querying the cost of the licences-$320, I think it is, for a twoyear licence. And some who may not have the requisite trade qualifications are going to go through transitional arrangements that will recognise prior learning, however illdefined that is at the moment. So it has been quite a botch-up in terms of in administrative arrangements. That botch-up is most clearly revealed in the delays that the member for Grayndler outlined in relation to the creation of the Australian Refrigeration Council, the body that was supposed to operate as a service provider under contract to the government. Its main role is to issue the licences and authorisations and to undertake compliance audits. Quite clearly, there was a lot of parochial and sectional pressure on the minister, most notably by the Motor Trade Association over in the west which attempted to derail the national system that was originally outlined in the bill. One has to ask about the special privileges this industry body had in applying the kind of pressure that has seen the new council announced only very recently-on 31 May. So here we have a totally new body announced at the end of May that is supposed to oversee a process to license around 50,000 tradespeople between now and 1 July, and yet this legislation has still not being carried by this liament. It would be hard to find a clearer example of maladministration and botch-up than in the arrangements for the new licensing regime that is to apply. We do support the essence of the bill, while our amendments clearly note the failures of the government and refer to the problems that these delays and pressures are causing in the industry. There is a clear parallel between the action Australia took when the world's community understood the impacts of the thinning of the ozone layer around the world, when we were at the forefront of the international action that has seen the damage to the ozone layer being held at bay with the possibility of the damage being reversed, and the lack of action by this government over a similar global crisis, the crisis of global warming, where we do not have the courage to go along with the rest of the developed nations and ratify the Kyoto protocol. When this bill is passed I look forward to being reassured by the government that we will have proper monitoring in place to look at the impacts that the more ozone friendly chemicals are actually having on global warming and climate change. There should be no trade-offs in my opinion between saving the ozone layer and minimising the very negative impacts of climate change. They are two global issues of equal importance and you cannot have any trade-offs between saving the ozone layer and minimising climate change. Lastly, I ask the members of the government to think seriously about the benefits that would flow to the Australian economy, to the Australian environment and to the health and well-being of our communities if the government were to do the right thing and accept the challenge put forward in the member for Grayndler's private member's bill, which had a second reading in the House the other day. It is a bill that would parsee this government belatedly recognising the impact and the negative consequences of climate change and actually doing the right thing and ratifying the Kyoto protocol. I think the Montreal protocol showed that the international community working together can have a major influence on serious global environmental issues and I think ratification of the Kyoto protocol would show this government belatedly accepting the need for Australia to join again with the rest of the international community in dealing with a major environmental issue confronting mankind today.

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: It is widely recognised by the Australian community that the coalition government is the greenest government in Australia's history. Ms George-You have got to be joking!

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: I am not joking, my friend. Since 1996 we have spent an unprecedented amount of money repairing the impact of 200 years of European settlement in this country. We have had the Natural Heritage Trust and an enormous range of other objectives, and the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 is yet another way that the Howard government is doing what it can to make sure we appreciate collectively as a country that we do hold our nation in trust for future tions. Australia is performing strongly in moves to phase out the use of hydrochlorofluorocarbons-HCFCs-as set out in the internationally accepted standards of the Montreal protocol. It follows our commendable results in phasing out other more harmful ozonedepleting gases. Chlorofluorocarbons, the propellants that were so talked about in the 1980s, have not been in use in Australia since 1996, the year that the Labor government was swept from the Treasury benches and a year ahead of the time frames of the Montreal schedule. The almost as equally damaging gas, halon, once used as a coolant in refrigerators and fire-extinguishing systems, has not been used in this country since 1993, also a year ahead of the Montreal timetable. I am not, however, suggesting that side of politics has a monopoly on interest our environment. I believe that one of the important steps forward in recent years has been that everyone, both in the political arena and more generally, has appreciated that as a nation we simply could not go on as we were and that we had to look very closely at our environment and appreciate that obviously we must make sure that the environment is appropriate for succeeding generations of Australians. Methyl chloroformused as a solvent for adhesives and for metal degreasing-was phased out completely by 1996. These three examples give some indication as to how serious Australia is to end use of ozone-depleting gases for the good of the environment. The Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 will further help Australia's efforts by improving the licensing and administration of the guidelines for importers and exporters of hydrochlorofluorocarbons or used methyl bromide. The bill proposes to amend the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Mangeneraagement Act 1989 by modifying the requirement of importers and exporters of these two gases so that they only require a used substances licence. This mirrors similar actions taken for chlorofluorocarbonsCFCs-and halons, which I mentioned earlier and which are both now out of circulation-quite appropriately-in this country. The bill will effectively have the licensing requirements for importers of HCFCs and methyl bromide gas. Those who may be wondering about the impact of the amendments can rest easy knowing that the environmental protection afforded by the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act 1989 will not be compromised in any way by the amendments currently before the House. The bill will help fix what is largely a numthis ber of anomalies that were overlooked durin ing the drafting of the legislation in 1989. I honestly do not know why so many mistakes have been made in the drafting of legislation over the years. I know that our parliamentary draftsmen do have a very high degree of skill, but it is frustrating to see that it is necessary on so many occasions to dot the i's and cross the t's and finetune the provisions of legislation which has been enacted in earlier times. The bill will also ensure reporting conditions for synthetic greenhouse gases that are manufactured in Australia come into line with reporting conditions currently required for imported and exported synthetic greenthe house gases. Hydrochlorofluorocarbons have between one per cent and 10 per cent the ozone-depleting effect of the CFCs that they replaced one decade ago. Usage in Australia of methyl bromide, which is mainly used as a soil fumigant, has been cut back dramatically, by about 70 per cent of 1991 levels. Australia is continuing to investigate alternaa tive gases that have no detrimental environmental impact; however, for some purposes there are regrettably still no viable alternatives. The use of these two gases in limited amounts and in controlled situations is, sadly, presently unavoidable. While the government recognises the environmental impacts of these substances, there is also an economic advantage in their usage. HCFCs are still the most commonly used refrigerants, as well as being widely used in foamblowing, fire protection and aerosols, while methyl bromide is used as a solvent and, as I have mentioned, in the fumigation industry. However, the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 encourages the usage of recycled or used HCFCs and methyl bromide to further reduce the detrimental effect that these gases are acknowledged to have on the environment. Importing of these used or recycled gases is an important factor in the ongoing phasing out of the use of these substances altogether. The second part of the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 ensures that part of Sydney's valuable historic past is conserved and enhanced. Several landmarks on the harbour reflect the colonial history of the area. They map out the growth of the region in terms of our defence and industry, and the population growth of the young fledgling colony of New South Wales. The areas targeted in this bill include Macquarie Lightstation on South Head, the North Head former artillery school, Woolwich Dock and the adjacent parklands, Snapper Island, Cockatoo Island, the once-bustling marine biological station at Watsons Bay and the defence lands at Middle Head, Georges Heights and Chowder Bay. The amendments put forward in the bill will help enable the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust to continue to develop its plans for beautiful parkland. I understand that local residents have already overwhelmingly voiced their support for a proposal that will see a 2,000 square metre block of land owned by the trust-the site of an unwanted scout hut-allowed to be subdivided and sold off to private purchasers. In some communities, a grand plan such as this might ordinarily attract widespread condemnation, but the Sydney community is an understanding one and it will receive other benefits that balance the sell-off that might appear to outsiders looking into be of somewhat limited value. In return for the scout hut land sale, three houses will be purchased in Markham Close, with the houses to be removed and the land then incorporated into a spectacular headland park. The cooperation of the community and its support for the insightful plans of the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust will enable the development of an attractive parkland that is both practical in terms of sensible land use and a great place for families to enjoy. I listened to the political rhetoric of the honourable member for Throsby when she claimed that the government should ratify the Kyoto protocol. It is not in Australia's interests to ratify that particular protocol. We are meeting the targets which would have been set out in that protocol, so Australia is actually playing its part. We are simply not going to react to some knee-jerk requirement by members of the opposition that we should ratify a protocol that is clearly not in Australia's interests. At the outset I said that the coalition government are the greenest government in Australia's history. We do have a proud record. The environmental situation of this nation is infinitely better now than it was when we were elected to office in 1996 and the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 adds to that excellent environmental record. I am pleased to be able to commend this bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr JENKINS
Title: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: It is a pleasure to speak to the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2005. As has been outlined, the purpose of this bill is to amend the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act 1999 and the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust Act 2001. Amendments to the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act are of a housekeeping nature. They ensure that a person importing or exporting used hydrochlorofluorocarbons or methyl bromide has either a used substance licence or a controlled substances licencenot both, as could be the case under the existing act-and apply the same controls and reporting requirements to anyone who sets up a synthetic greenhouse gas manufacturing operation in Australia as those applying to synthetic greenhouse gas importers. Amendments to the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust Act will permit the sale of some land Mosman and a land swap to replace lost public space. This is an opportune time to review some of the matters that surround the phenomenon of ozone protection. During my time in this place, I have had a number of opportunities to speak on various bills. Sometimes it is worrying to go back over previous speeches - you may be a little concerned that you did not keep a consistent line. Having had the opportunity to speak on ozone protection legislation in 1988, 1992, 1995 and 1998, there was a great risk that perhaps I had not been consistent. One thing that has happened when reviewing pieces of legislation is that at each step we, as legislators, have had to react to the developing body of scientific knowledge to do with this phenomenon. Sometimes I think that is not understood. Scientific investigation is very dynamic. Tonight I wish to go through some of the things that continue to develop our understanding of ozone depletion in the stratosphere which have led to this body of legislation, culminating in the Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act 1989 that is to be amended by the bill tonight. Governments of both political persuasions have come to grips with this over the last 17 years. When these environmental phenomena are tackled by global cooperation and in an international way we can have great success. This phenomenon came to light in the 1980s. Fortunately, we have seen the global community come together and, through the Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer, followed by the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer, set down a timetable of achievement, cutting out the production of gases identified as being ozone depleting. I am not going to go over the successes because they have been indicated by a number of people already in this debate. Even if we take the poin sition that the honourable member for Bowman put quite strongly-that industry had cooperated and should get a pat on the back-it should be realised that industry is important and has done its part. If we were to look only at Australia's success in isolation, like any global phenomenon, we would do an injustice to the way in which we are attempting to protect the planet. On this side of the chamber we say that through Kyoto we could achieve for climate change and the greenhouse phenomenon what has arisen through the Montreal protocol. It is incongruous that we have this dichotomy where there has been bipartisan support right throughout the 17 years of the Montreal protocol and the 20 years of the Vienna convention. It was never questioned that we should be doing this in an international way through the cooperation we have seen. Regrettably, when we have seen bipartisan support, we do not really want to go into this territory. But on some of the reviews of the Montreal protocol, this government has tended to side with the United States over, for instance, the Europeans in the way in which implementation timetables have been placed. Traditionally these have been seen to extend the timetables. When Australia decides, it is usually not to go with the earlier target placed on removals by Europeans but to fall into line with the Americans. This is a little disappointing. The Chinese have made considerable strides in meeting their targets and are likely to meet them many years ahead of requirements in the Montreal protocol. The points I want to make today have been touched upon in other contributions. Back in 1988 we were endeavouring to set in place a timetable which countries could sign up to and which industry was comfortable with. Industry had started on the development of replacement gases. At that stage there was not much discussion about which gases might replace the ozone-depleting gases. As things have developed and as alternatives have come on board, we have studied those alternatives and realised some of the phenomena that occur with the release of those gases into the atmosphere and then their percolating up to the stratosphere. We saw industry developing the alternatives: hydrochlorofluorocarbons, or HCFCs; hydrofluorocarbons, or HFCs; and perfluorocarbons, or PFCs. We now know these are powerful greenhouse gases. We are now tackling ozone depletion by taking measures leading to ozone protection where it intersects with the phenomenon of climate change. It is very important that we realise there is an interconnection. It makes even more important for the government to understand that, even though this is only one grouping of greenhouse gases, these are important environmental phenomena that are the result of mankind's use of the planet and they have to be tackled in an international and global way. We have to make sure we understand the phenomena created by synthetic greenhouse gases and that we look at the replacement of those gases with more benign substances which can have the same effect. Ammonia has been suggested as an alternative for refrigerants and mineral wool has been suggested as an alternative to plastic insulating foam. There is a further intersect about which I was a little surprised. As reported in the Sydney Morning Herald on 28 April this year, it has been suggested, in the monitoring of the Arctic ozone layer, that ozone depletion was at its worse recorded levels as a result not just of the percolation of ozone depleting gases but also of climate change itself. It is known that the stratospheric clouds that are over both poles in winter have some involvement in the phenomenon of ozone depletion. It is now being suggested that, because of climate change, the concentrations of stratospheric cloud are greater, and therefore ozone depletion is greater. It is now being suggested that ozone depletion is the result of not only greenhouse gases but also climate change. Increasing ozone depletion is not only caused by the greenhouse gases that are used to replace ozone depleting gases but is also a direct result of climate change. In fact, the European Union is investing $27 million in a five-year project to try to understand this phenomenon. Returning to where I commenced tonight, I repeat that understanding of this phenomenon requires continuing scientific study. As we go forward, the overlap is getting greater. Given the stage we find ourselves at, in it terms of our cooperation with the international community over matters to do with climate change, Australia must understand that it is better for us to be in the international cart that is represented by the Kyoto protocol than outside it, because these are cooperative efforts going forward. There is no reason to suggest that a phenomenon that happens in the Northern Hemisphere, which is increasing ozone depletion and creating ozone ‘holes'-which, of course, are not holes but areas with a reduced level of ozone-would not be happening in the Southern Hemisphere. Mr Deputy Speaker Quick, as a Tasmanian you would be aware that the so-called ozone hole in the Antarctic is stretching across not only Tasmania but also mainland Australia. The cost to Australia of not doing anything over the last 17 years would have been astronomical. The direct cost to human health is high, and the cost of the change in habitats and biospheres throughout Australia is also high. We only have to think of the effect of UV rays on plankton in the oceans, and the fine balance in the food chain for aquatic animals, which starts with plankton, to realise that this is a very important area public policy. It is not often understood and it has not been repeated in this debate that what we are talking about in the reduction of the production of the gases is one step. The next step is to realise that there are still a lot of CFCsfor instance, in old refrigerators-which continue to be refrigerants. All lations developed recognise that and have put in place proper procedures for the appropriate removal and storage of these gases from obsolete equipment. But it is often not recognised that some of these gases have very long lives when they reach the stratosphere. It may take anything from months to years for the gases to percolate, but once they get there their lives are over tens of years to hundreds of years. So we are taking action now to attempt to get back to levels measured 40 years ago, which may not happen until the middle of this century. This is an investment to make sure that we are doing things today that will have that longer term advantage. Again, if we contrast this to greenhouse, this is exactly what is being said. These are actions we have to take in our proper stewardship of the environment to ensure that later generations are afforded the protection required. To the extent that these matters require bipartisan agreement I think that, in the main, that has been achieved. The opposition places before the House its concerns, which are set out in the second reading amendment passed by the Senate when it dealt with this legislation before sending it to us for our deliberations. The amendment expresses our absolute disquiet about the length time it has taken to put in place requirements for the appointment of a national industry board, leading to industry regulation and the way in which people working in the industry could be registered to carry out actions under the legislation. If we look at the timeline, we see that it was of not until 31 May that the minister indicated that the Australian Refrigeration Council had been selected to administer the national authorisation and licensing system for the sale, use and handling of refrigerants that are ozone-depleting substances and synthetic greenhouse gases, and it was not until a week later that the details of the licensing scheme the acts and reguwere announced. The opposition acknowledge that transition arrangements have been put in place, but we are reliant on the skills and techniques of those who will be licensed under this act to ensure that we do not have the release of ozone-depleting gases into the atmosphere and then into the stratosphere and that we do not have the release of replacement gases that are now acknowledged as greenhouse gases. That was the point of the 2003 legislation. I think it has been acknowledged throughout the debate that all parties have worked together in this important area of public policy. We understand that we need to solve and ameliorate these problems and acknowledge that the partnership between government and industry will set out these achievements. Many of the uses made of ozone-depleting gases are illustrative of the way our society has developed. Artificial refrigeration and many other uses of these gases have been important to our economy. But it is also an example of the way we have gone about ozone protection that various studies of these pieces of legislation have, importantly, highlighted that this has been of benefit to our economy. So we see yet again an example of where we have the collision of measures being taken that are of benefit to the environment, of benefit to the economy and, because people have an understanding of collective action, of benefit to society. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
Title: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: I rise to address the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2005. I particularly want to focus the attention House on some of the gross mismanagement of vegetation in Queensland through the Queensland vegetation management legislation and on how the Queensland Labor Party through the leadership of Peter Beattie is failing to deliver what he thought he was going to deliver by his punitive measures. He is failing to deliver the positive outcomes to the ozone that could be delivered with good vegetation management laws. The Premier failed to work cooperatively with the key stakeholders-that is, the land-holders and the regional communities-before he brought that legislation forward. Yes, he went out to see them, and I was involved in some of the visits to parts of my electorate. But he failed in that process and, in the end, he just brought his legislation forward with little concern for the impact it would have on local landholders. Our environment is part of our heritage, and it is important that we protect it for future generations. That is undisputed. Australia houses several unique environmental wonders of the world, including the Great Barrier Reef, the Daintree rainforests and, at the back of my electorate, the Simpson Desert-another one of those great unique features of our landscape. Let us not forget the Lake Eyre basin and Lake Eyre itself-what a unique feature that is-the Queensland Mitchell grass plains and the brigalow lands. The Darling Downs is unique as an agricultural land in the Southern Hemisphere because of its features, its soil type and the richness of it. In the west of my electorate is the great Channel Country, where the inland rivers flow, and, of course, there is the Murray-Darling Basin. All have unique vegetation, unique features and unique animal life. Last week we saw the launch of National Bilby Day in this parliament. The bilby is a wonderful little of the mammal that has for many years survived non-native predators like wild cats and foxes that have been introduced into Australia. Thank goodness for those people from my electorate, who were down in Canberra last week, who have done a tremendous job in protecting the bilby and establishing an ecosystem where they can breed in a natural environment. It is a fact that land-holders across Australia have been working since very early settlement to manage our native vegetation. Australia's natural environment and landscape is one of the biggest drawcards in attracting both domestic and international tourists to our wonderful environmental features. The latest figures, for instance-and this demonstrates just how important our environment is-show that tourism contributes substantially to Australia's economy. Tourism is a $73 billion industry, which employs more than half a million Australians, with over 200,000 of those in regional areas. Mr Jenkins- Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order: whilst these matters might be of interest, I do not think they relate to the bill. The long title is ‘A Bill for an to amend the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act 1989 and to make changes relating to the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust, and for related purposes'.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: The parts I heard of the debate referred to greenhouse gas and emissions, but I will listen to the member's contribution. I ask the member to make sure that he refers to the contents of the bill.

Speaker: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
Title: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: I just say to the honourable member that I am demonstrating the uniqueness of some of our environment and how we should protect it, because it does contribute to the ozone layer, and how through protecting our vegetation in our rural areas it will contribute to the protection of the ozone layer. I am just highlighting an issue relating to tourism. The health of the ozone layer is important to tourism as well as to good vegetation management. To complete what I was saying about the tourism industry, tourism earns something like $17.3 billion. Australia earns more export dollars-and this is interesting-from tourism than from the export of coal and wool combined. The honourable member might just reflect on that for a moment, because we know that coal is one of those energy sources that is not a positive on our environment or the ozone. We know we cannot live without it at the moment; it is important. So, when you consider that tourism can replace some of these exports over time, tourism will be a great economic driver for the nation. I just point that out to the House and for the honourable member in the face of his intervention. The government in Queensland introduced into the parliament the Vegetation Management Amendment Bill, which was legislating Act to ban broad-scale tree clearing of remnant native vegetation by December 2006. There were several purposes for that legislation, one of which was to contribute to greenhouse abatement. That was one of the Premier's intentions. It is a known fact that trees contribute to reducing the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere and, hence, the potential to minimise the ozone being further damaged by industry emission sources such as motor vehicles, which we all obviously drive, factories and coal fired power stations. So trees play an important part in the environment and an important part in contributing to greenhouse abatement. The Queensland government's vegetation management legislation-I will be kind and say ‘inadvertently'-is having a detrimental impact on the environmental ecosystems of parts of Queensland. The only reason I can see for the Premier acting in the way he did is that he was after Greens preferences. He was not really considering ozone; he was after preferences. He should have had that foremost in his mind in addition to his being able to work in a positive and cooperative manner with the land-holders of Queensland. Had he been prepared to work with the landholders of Queensland and get suitable vegetation management laws in place, it would have been a win-win for both the ozone layer and the livelihoods of land-holders. If the Queensland government had worked with land-holders, there would have been a positive outcome for the regional towns as well, because they are just so dependent on the jobs created by the enterprises on the farm lands, the pastoral lands, around those towns. On a recent visit to Quilpie in the west of my electorate-I was there with my parliamentary colleague Senator Ron Boswell, the Leader of The Nationals in the Senate-I inspected a property in the mulga lands where the legislation in Queensland is having a detrimental effect. I have linked trees the ozone, so I think I have the right to continue pointing out where bad laws will have a detrimental impact on the ozone. Stephen Tully is a well-respected and knowledgeable land-holder. He is a descendent of some of the first settlers in the Quilpie region. The families of some of the first settlers are there. They have been there since 1874. We toured parts of his property and, of course, as we all know, that part of Queensland is in exceptional drought. It has been in exceptional drought for the last two years. It will have to be rolled into a third year. We would all love to see rain so that is not necessarybut it looks as though it will be. There has been some rain in the region, but not exceptional drought-breaking rain. On Mr Tully's property the grasses have been eaten out and have not been able to regenerate because of the exceptional drought. Mr Tully, his family and a large number of the pastoralists in that region have harvested mulga trees, which are a source of fodder and nutriment for animals in times of drought. A lot of the land in western Queensland has been mapped by satellites.
