These satellites are a wonderful tool for all of us, but they are inaccurately describing some of the vegetation on Mr Tully's property. Some mulga trees are described as ‘bastard mulga' when in fact they are not in that region; they are elsewhere on the property. In order for Mr Tully and other landholders in the mulga ecosystems of western Queensland to sustain their stock, as they have done for more than a hundred yearsthe mulga regenerates in the good seasons and is conserved for the bad seasons-they have to harvest that timber. They would have harvested it in the early days with an axe. Later on it would have been with a chainsaw, and then with a tractor. While in some cases that practice is still allowed under a permit, it is becoming more difficult day by day and to year by year as a result of the legislation introduced by the Queensland Labor government, under the premiership of Peter Beattie. One of the aspects of harvesting mulga is that when the trees or the low branches are laid on the ground they protect the soil. We have only got to look at a mulch system in still our own garden to see that when we put mulch on top of the ground we protect the soil and conserve moisture underneath it. Mr Tully was able to show us that, with the last few years of limited rains, trees have been harvested for their fodder but underneath the branches that remain-which have been acting like a mulch-new green plants were emerging. They had germinated. They were also protected from the livestock. So what you have here is some grass and some weeds coming through. It will grow through the mulch if the tree or its branches are allowed to remain on the ground. The mulch also creates a ground cover, which prevents erosion when the rains come. Mr Tully was able to show us how he and his forebears-his family-have successfully used mulga since the late 1890s. They only harvest it when they want to use it as drought fodder. Another point I want to make in relation to the harvesting of mulga is that, if you do not harvest the mulga, the tree will of course grow to its full height and, as it matures, the leaves become very dry. It cannot produce the same sorts of benefits that a young tree, green grass or crops produce for carbon abatement; it cannot create a carbon sink. So by harvesting the mulga and allowing it to regenerate when the seasons come and by using the fodder harvested to feed drought affected stock, you end up with a win-win situation. To my mind, there is no-one better to determine whether or not mulga should be harvested than the land-holders who have been doing it sustainably for 150-odd years. Why a satellite map should be the only determinant for this outcome, I am not quite sure. It should be used as a useful tool, but it should be used in conjunction with the knowledge of the land-holders and of course the regional bodies who are very involved in the agricultural or the pastoral scene, as in this case. An example of what happens when you do not manage your vegetation was clearly demonstrated right here in Canberra with the bushfires. The national parks were not being managed and we saw the tragic consequences of that with the bushfires. When the wind conditions changed the fires raced towards Canberra and, sadly, people lost their lives and over 500 homes were destroyed. Had the vegetation in the national parks been managed to prevent bushfires, those sorts of consequences would not have occurred. The other element of those fires is that the smoke from them is a net negative for our ozone. If we manage our vegetation-our timber resources and our grasses-we can have a win-win for the environment. I believe that, importantly, the issue is about management rather than about the punitive measures that we have seen introduced into Queensland. The land-holders in Queensland who want to work with government to produce sustainable ecosystems are not in the business of destroying the ecosystem. They are not in the business of wanting to destroy their own livelihoods. It is their livelihood; it is what sustains their families. I know time is short, but I want to move very quickly to the recommendations of the Productivity Commission report which was commissioned by this government in the last term of government. That report, which was brought down in June last year, is titled Impacts of native vegetation and biodiversity regulations. I commend that report to the opposition, because the conclusions are the basis on which I believe we should be looking at vegetation management at a national level. I refer to recommendation 10.3, which reflects what I have been saying about fodder harvesting. It states: Ongoing efforts are required to improve the quality of data and science on which native vegetation and biodiversity policy decisions are based, particularly ‘on-the ground' assessments to test the accuracy of vegetation mapping based on satellite imagery. That is the very point that I was raising in relation to the problems Stephen Tully has been having. That is a recommendation from the Productivity Commission report. All this leads to having a positive outcome on the environment and also on the ozone layer, if we manage our vegetation properly and sustainably. It was found that there needed to be an improvement in the regulatory regimes to enhance the transparency, the consistency and the accountability of decision making. In particular, recommendation 10.4 highlights several possible approaches, and I would commend those to others, because of the limited time. I have here. One of the other recommendations that I believe is particularly important is 10.5. It states: - greater use should be made of the extensive knowledge of landholders and local communities … - some across-the-board rules … could be relaxed and replaced with requirements that meet environmental objectives but which reflect regional environmental characteristics and agricultural practices. That fits in exactly with what I have been talking about in relation to the mulga lands of western Queensland-‘that reflect environmental characteristics and agricultural practices'. Finally, the report also says-and this is important in the vegetation laws of Queensland-that regulations assert authority of ownership over the private property's remnant vegetation. Land-holders are held accountable for the management of the vegetation while being left uncompensated for this ongoing day-today management. Incentives for land-holders to voluntarily manage and conserve native vegetation are therefore undermined. Subsequently, when regulation reduces the private value of landholders or native vegetation, incentives to manage it are diminished. In light of the Productivity Commission report and the comments and the experience of the land-holders of Queensland-and I visited the mulga lands of western Queensland only two weeks ago-I commend to this government and all governments across Australia the work of the Productivity Commission in bringing forward sustainable vegetation management rules. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: Flinders-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage) (5.55 pm)-in reply-In summarising the debate on theEnvironment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2005, I wish to do three things. Firstly, I want to address the points raised by both government and opposition members. Secondly, I wish to address some of the issues more generally in relation to the ozone and synthetic gas amendments. Thirdly, I want to outline some key points in the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust amendments. In looking at this bill-and I wish to thank all of speakers-we have had a series of points from both government and opposition members. I want to address the points raised by the three opposition members: the member for Grayndler, the member for Throsby and the member for Scullin. Their points really fall into two categories, other than a general agreement with the government's policy and approach on ozone protection and endorsement of the actions in relation to the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust. The two criticisms that the members of the opposition have raised fall into these categories: firstly, there has been an attack on the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Ian Campbell, who is currently in Korea having enormous success in leading the international campaign against whaling and getting ready to see his reforms in relation to ozone and synthetic gas come into being. The criticism was that the minister had in some way delayed the appointment of the refrigeration and air conditioning industry board to issue licences for refrigeration and air conditioning. I want to set down that there were two absolutely clear principles which the minister adopted. The first was to make sure that any appointment of a group which would regulate would be contested, that there would not just be a desire but a responsibility to ensure that a critical position such as that was fully and properly contested. The minister was not happy that there was sufficient contestation. He made a very clear, very simple ruling that we had to open it and we had to make sure that there was a proper chance for competition. We had to make sure that that was the case. The second principle which he applied was that he had to be prudent, that we had to see that this was a safe, appropriate body capable of protecting this industry and ensurthe ing that licences were allocated properly. So he had to have the best and they had to be up to standard. For taking time to do that, we make no apology. It is utterly the appropriate thing to do. In the second criticism levelled by our friends in the opposition, they drew a comparison between what Australia is doing in relation to ozone protection-and they acknowledge that it is an outstanding set of activities which go back both to this government and to the previous government; and I recognise the work of the previous government-what it is doing in relation to greenhouse gases. That is the criticism. On both ozone protection and greenhouse gas abatement the Australian government has an outstanding contemporary record. The key thing to remember is that not only is the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act world-leading legislation but also we are achieving our targets in terms of our Montreal and Kyoto protocol obligations in relation to greenhouse gas. Australia is one of the only countries in the world to actually be achieving both our ozone and our greenhouse gas targets. We happen to take exception with the mechanism within the Kyoto protocol because we believe that it could well have a net detrimental effect to the general approach of dealing with climate change and greenhouse gases. But we have met our targets and we are one of the very few Annex 1 or developed world nations to be so doing. We are in an almost unique group to be achieving both our Montreal protocol targets in relation to ozone and the Kyoto protocol targets in relation to greenhouse. That is an exceptional situation. The second point that I want to make today is in relation to the ozone and synthetic gas amendments contained within this bill. We agree and accept that there is a critical need to protect against ozone depletion. That threat is real and tangible, but there is traordinary progress. Australia has performed exceptionally by international standards, and has been progressing very well. The third point is that within the ozone protection element of this bill there are two important amendments. The bill amends and streamlines the licensing requirements for the import or export of used or recycled methyl bromide or hydrochlorofluorocarbons and, in addition, it amends and requires that Australian manufacturers of synthetic greenhouse gases report to the government consistent with the existing requirements for importers and exporters of synthetic greenhouse gases. This brings me to the last part of my summary-the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust amendments. I am delighted to be able to make this summary in the presence of the member for North Sydney, who has fought with absolute ferocity to protect and expand the areas under the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust. When we look at the seven sites of the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust, we apply two key principles to dealing with them. The first key principle is public access-opening these lands to public access for the first time in many cases not just for 10 years, not just for a generation, but forever. That is an extraordinary legacy which will be left by the member for North Sydney, the member for Warringah and others involved in the establishment of the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust. The second principle is in relation to the use of these public areas. This may include use for marine science, marine education and for the community-all of the things for which the community has pushed and which are currently being delivered. The next step is in relation to HMAS Platypus. That submarine base should be turned over as quickly as possible from deex- fence land to the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust. The member for North Sydney has been unstinting. He has set a deadline and we are working to that a deadline. This bill puts forward a practical land swap that is all about protecting the environment, and it delivers on that. Ultimately I thank everyone who has spoken on the bill, both government and opposition. I thank the government speakers, the members for Bowman, Fisher and Maranoa, who talked about the legacy that we leave to future generations. They summarised what we are doing in relation to the ozone amendments and in relation to the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust. It is about leaving a legacy for the next generation, and with that I am delighted to commend the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 to the House and I urge its speedy passage.
