Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: BUSINESS
text: I move: That this bill be now read a second time. The Family Law Amendment Bill 2005 is a part of the Howard government's continuing reform of the family law system. The bill contains a range of amendments to the Family Law Act 1975, designed to improve the operation of the current family law system. Some of these are technical amendments intended to improve the act's operation, such as amendments to modernise the terminology used. Other amendments relate to procedural matters, including appeal processes. These amendments to the Family Law Act 1975 are ongoing reforms, separate from the package of family law reforms that respond to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs report, Every picture tells a story. The government has announced part of its response to that report, and I will introduce an exposure draft of legislative amendments shortly for comment. Following its introduction into the House on 1 April last year, the Family Law Amendment Bill was referred to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, which reported in July 2004. The committee recommended that the bill should proceed, subject to a number of amendments. The bill lapsed with the proroguing of parand liament before last year's election and was therefore reintroduced in the other place in March 2005. The recommendations made by the Senate committee have been taken on board and are incorporated in the bill before you. The bill contains amendments to address the issue of parenting orders not working in practice. A number of parenting orders, particularly those made by consent, are found not to actually work. The bill contains amendments to allow a court of its own motion to vary orders relating to children. is aimed at situations where contravention proceedings have arisen because the original parenting order is unworkable and allows the court to fix the problem before it leads to further contravention proceedings. Another important amendment in the bill provides a right for persons who are determined not to be a parent of a child, through DNA testing or by other means, to recover any moneys paid or property transferred for the benefit of that child under maintenance orders. During its passage in another place, both government amendments and Democrat amendments were made to this section. The government proposes to introduce further amendments to remove the Democrat amendments, to ensure that this provision gives a clear and predictable result-that is, if a person is found not to be a parent of a child, and that person has paid child maintenance under a court order for that child, the person can expect to bring a claim in the court that made the original order, and to recover what has been paid, unless there are exceptional circumstances. A number of amendments in this bill clarify the Family Court's powers in a range of areas, including the court's rule-making powers to support the Family Law Rules 2004 which commenced on 29 March 2004, in relation to the ability of the court to change the venue of proceedings and to clarify the effect of offers of settlement. The bill also clarifies a number of issues relating to the operation of appeals. One amendment removes the power of the full court to issue a certificate that no special leave to appeal is needed from the High Court to appeal to that Court where ‘an important question of law or public interest' is involved. This amendment was made in response to a recommendation of the Australian Law Reform Commission with which This the High Court and the Family Court both agreed. The government accepted the recommendation as it considers that the High Court, through the special leave to appeal process, should be in control of what matters are dealt with by that court. The bill provides for the transfer of family law proceedings from state courts of summary jurisdiction-that is, magistrates and local courts, direct to the Federal Magistrates Court on the state courts' own initiative. Many proceedings instituted in state courts in relation to property with a value of over $20,000 or in relation to contested parenting orders will be appropriate for determination by the Federal Magistrates Court. Currently the Family Law Act provides for transfers in such matters from courts of summary jurisdiction on the court's own initiative to the Family Court but not to the Federal Magistrates Court. The Family Court then transfers appropriate matters on to the Federal Magistrates Court. This amendment will enable matters to be transferred directly to the Federal Magistrates Court and therefore reduce delays. The bill also widens the range of matters which can be the subject of private arbitration. Currently the matters that can be dealt with by a private arbitrator under the Family Law Act are limited to matters which relate to property, spousal maintenance and maintenance agreements. The bill expands the scope to include financial agreements and certain orders in relation to superannuation. Parties must consent before matters can be referred to private arbitration. Also included in part 16 of the bill is an amendment to the Bankruptcy Act 1966 to support reforms recently made under the Bankruptcy and Family Law Legislation Amendment Act 2005 that relate to bankruptcy and family law reform. This amendment will ensure that the Family Court of Western Australia, along with the Family Court of Australia, acquires all necessary bankruptcy jurisdictions in concurrent family law proceedings where a party is bankrupt. Part 17 also supplements the reforms that are made in that bill, reinforcing the role of the bankruptcy trustee as representing the interests of all creditors in family law property proceedings where a party is bankrupt or subject to a personal insolvency agreement. The bill also modernises the terminology of the act to terms which are commonly used and widely recognised, thereby increasing the public's understanding of the act and accessibility to family law. This should be particularly beneficial in aiding self-represented litigants. It will no doubt surprise many that the term ‘divorce' does not appear in the act. The term ‘dissolution of marriage' is simply replaced with ‘divorce'. There are a range of other minor amendments in this bill. The government is committed to enhancing and making more accessible and efficient the family law system and this bill is part of the government's commitment to that goal. Full details of the measures contained in this bill are included in the revised explanatory memorandum to the bill, which I table. I commend the bill to the House. Leave granted for second reading debate to continue immediately.

Speaker: Mr MCCLELLAND
Title: BUSINESS
text: As the Attorney-General indicated, the Family Law Amendment Bill 2005 is very similar to the Family Law Amendment Bill 2004, which was introduced in the last parliament. That bill was examined by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, which made a series of very useful recommendations. Labor is pleased to see that the government has clearly taken on board many of those recommendations in the preparation of the new bill. This has been one of many examples of the Senate committee process facilitating constructive bipartisan work on important policy issues. As with the last bill, Labor welcomes this bill as a positive contribution to improving the existing Family Law Act. This is an omnibus bill dealing with amendments in 16 parts. For the most part this bill is noncontroversial. Many are technical changes that will ease practical difficulties faced by the courts and court users. Part 10 deals with terminology. This may seem trivial, but in fact it is very important that the Family Law Act makes use of plain English. This is, as we note, an area of law that touches more people than almost any other. It is also an area where, as a result of economic circumstances, there are a substantial number of self-represented litigants. If ever there was a case for making an effort to clean up arcane language in our statutes, it is in this act and we commend the government for that. Part 5 would extend the range of matters that can be dealt with through private arbitration. This creates a welcome new pathway for certain cases that do not require the expense and delay of litigation but cannot be resolved through mediation alone. Part 16 cleans up a gap in the recently passed Bankruptcy and Family Law Legislation Amendment Bill to ensure that the Family Court of Western Australia has the same jurisdiction as the Family Court of Australia in the area of crossover between family law and bankruptcy law. There are some parts of the bill that are controversial, and these have been the subject of amendments in the other place. The most important is part 14. This would allow claims for the retrospective recovery of maintenance by a person who finds out later that they are not the child's biological parent. Labor supports the intention of this provision. As I will note shortly, it would have limited application, but we have serious reservations about the sorts of outcomes it could produce if applied too rigidly. In most instances, we are talking here about cases where a mistake has been made as opposed to deliberate deception. That is, we are talking about a case where one person was thought to be the father, and a maintenance order was made requiring them to pay maintenance to the mother to support the child. It is a situation where everyone has shared in the mistaken belief: the mother, the purported father and even the court. The question is really about who should bear the cost of the mistake. A good argument can be made for both sides. The man can rightly say that the maintenance order should never have made and that he should never have been required to pay for a child that is not his. the mother could also argue convincingly that she is incapable of paying all the money back while continuing to support herself and her child or other children in circumstances where a genuine mistake occurred. The Family Court, of course, cannot be required to force a mother and her children into poverty-and should not be required to do soto correct an honest mistake. Labor thinks there is only one fair way to deal with this dilemma, and that is to ensure that there is sufficient judicial discretion to have regard to the entirety of circumstances. In short, every case could be different. In some cases mothers may well be doing it tough, and recovery of the full amount could be disastrous for them and their children. In other cases, the mother might have ended up in a new relationship or in secure employment whereas the purported father may have struggled to find the money to pay the maintenance every fortnight. In some cases it will have been an honest mistake; in others a court would regard seriously circumstances of deliberate deception. In some cases the man will have acted quickly upon finding out that he is not the biological father; in others he may have left it for many years, with the result that recovery will be all the more onerous for the mother. We cannot predict all the permutations that will arise and devise a formula that is fair in all circumstances. We need to trust the authority and wisdom of the courts to closely examine each case and make an appropriate order in the circumstances. For this reason, Labor has been anxious to ensure the bill provides the courts with adequate discretion over the amount that is recovered and how it is to be paid. In the Senate, Labor supported an amendment that would have that effect. It is also important to ensure that, where a mother has been required to repay mainteBut nance under these provisions, she is able, in turn, to recover maintenance from the actual biological father of the child. It would hardly be fair if a mother could be liable to retrospectively repay maintenance when the biological father cannot himself be found accountable. Moreover, in many cases the mother will have forgone other income in reliance on the maintenance. In particular, she will have received less in social security benefits. This makes it all the more important that the mother have a right to retrospectively claim maintenance from the actual father. Labor raised this concern with the Attorney-General's office and we were advised that the Family Law Act already provides the court with the power to award backdated maintenance. We received advice from the Attorney-General's adviser which I will quote for the record and perhaps to assist in some way in the future interpretation of the legislation. The adviser replied: I am advised by our Department that a right for the mother to claim maintenance from the biological father already exists under Division 7 of Part VII of the Family Law Act in respect of children to which the new s66X would apply. Under section 66G of the Act, the court has a wide cretion to make any child maintenance order it considers appropriate against the parent of a child. The period covered and the amount of that order would be a matter for the court, considering the principal object in Division 7 to ensure that children receive a proper level of financial port from their parents. We are satisfied with this explanation. It is the case that section 66G provides a wide discretion for the court to make orders for maintenance, and nothing seems to prevent them making backdated or retrospective orders if that is appropriate. As I said, this goes a long way to easing the concerns that Labor had with this particular provision. I should note here also that this provision does not have as profound an effect as I flagged earlier-to the extent that it is already the case that retrospective repayment of maintenance can be ordered by a court where the maintenance has been paid under the administrative assessment scheme of the Child Support (Assessment) Act, in particular under section 143 of that act. This bill would affect only those cases where the maintenance order has been made under the Family Law Act. We are advised by the Attorney-General's office that only around 2.8 per cent of child support liabilities currently administered by the Child Support Agency arise under Family Law Act maintenance orders-and that figure includes some spousal maintenance orders that would not be affected by this amendment. We are talking about a very small minority of cases that could be affected by this bill. Most of the cases that would be affected by the change are those where the maintenance order was made before 1989. This means that not only does the bill affect a small minority of cases of mistaken paternity but that that minority is clearly defined and ever shrinking. As noted, it is desirable to bring the regime under the Family Law Act into accord dis- with the Child Support (Assessment) Act. Having considered these issues, Labor are inclined to support a change to the Family Law Act that would ensure mistaken paternity cases are dealt with under that act as sup- they are under the child support act. However, where we disagree with the government is on the words used to obtain that objective. We therefore supported the amendment in the Senate because it brings the language of the Family Law Act closer to that of the child support act. In doing so, the court has been given a greater discretion to ensure that mistaken paternity can be dealt with in the manner most just and equitable in the circumstances. In this way, it is an amendment which has improved the bill. The other part of the bill that might be controversial is part 1, concerning the parenting compliance regime. The provision in this part would do two things: provide that the court can order parents to participate in counselling or parenting programs before making orders in enforcement proceedings; and provide the court with the power to amend parenting orders where enforcement proceedings have been brought but either no contravention was found or there was a reasonable excuse for the contravention. With respect to the first of these, it is ready possible for the court to order a couple to participate in counselling or parenting programs in other types of proceedings. This change is extending that power to enforcement proceedings. This is a positive move, as counselling and parenting programs have proven very successful at getting to and resolving the issues at the heart of non-compliance. We as members would have seen many instances of constituents coming in and, in one way or another, expressing their grief about serial non-compliance. It is obviously desirable all round if they can be resolved appropriately. Of course, counselling is not appropriate in all cases, especially where there is a history of violence, but we are isfied that the protections already in the Family Law Act provide sufficient guidance to the court as to when these orders should and should not be made. The second change in this part allows the court to vary parenting orders in enforcement proceedings, even if no contravention is found or there was a reasonable excuse for contravention. This will allow the court to iron out the practical or other problems in parenting orders that gave rise to the complaint of non-compliance. In some cases it will also allow a reasonable excuse for non-compliance, such as an apprehension of violence, to form the basis for a substantive change to the orders. Currently these changes require separate proceedings for variation of orders. It makes a lot of practical sense for courts to be given the power to deal with variation at the same time as hearing enforcement proceedings. The National Network of Women's Legal Services has recommended that this new power be limited to certain cases, such as those where violence is an issue. When this was raised in the Senate committee on the 2004 bill, the Attorney-General's Department aladvised the committee that the court's power would be effectively limited by the considerations the court must always have when making parenting orders: the best interests of the child and the factors set out in section 68F(2). Labor is comfortable with the response provided by the Attorney-General's Department. In summary, although this is a useful bill containing several practical reforms to the workings of the family law system, we did have some concerns with part 14 in its original form. But we believe those concerns have substantially been addressed by the amendment that was made in the Senate. Given that amendment, the opposition will sat- be supporting the bill in the House.

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: BUSINESS
text: Fisher) (6.27 pm)Because of the time frame allocated to this debate it is necessary to reduce at the request of the whips the amount of time taken to speak on the Family Law Amendment Bill 2005 to five minutes. I will therefore have to truncate somewhat what I was otherwise going to say. There is probably no area of Australian law which affects people more significantly than family law. Tragically, many marriages in our country collapse. Indeed, I suspect this is the case right around the Western world. It is incumbent on governments, therefore, to have the very best family law system to endeavour to manage, on behalf of families, in the best possible way a situation which is often less than entirely desirable. The Australian government is committed to doing all that it can to ensure that Australian families are given the best possible chance to live their lives with as few unwanted disruptions as possible. The Family Law Amendment Bill 2005 does back up the commitment of the government to ensuring the best possible outcomes for Australian families, particularly given family breakdown. The bill endeavours to ensure that the most vulnerable during these times of immense stress and hardship, the children, are given the best support and protection that can be provided by a legal system. There is a long list of improvements afforded by this bill to the Family Law Act 1975 and, as has been mentioned previously, a number of these changes have come forward as a result of a Senate inquiry report. The amendments are ongoing reforms, as I think the Attorney has pointed out, quite different from the package of family law reforms which will respond to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs report, Every picture tells a story. There will be a government response to that report and legislation will be brought forward, possibly in the form of an exposure draft. The changes in this bill, however, include clarification of the own motion powers of the courts to modify parenting orders and the courts' power to order parties to attend counselling or post-separation parenting programs. There are changes in the provisions relating to the costings as well as offers of settlement to allow aggrieved parties to settle out of court, thereby avoiding the draining expenses of legal costs and further pressure on family members. The bill includes an increase in flexibility in courts in their dealings with parties who breach parenting orders, giving the court power to order a suspended prison sentence. This deterrent will be a useful tool in encouraging the compliance of some family members and there are provisions for sentences to be revoked at a later date. There is simplification of the processes involved with issuing a warrant for a parent who fails to comply with a parenting order and an expansion of the various matters that can be dealt with through private negotiation and arbitration. This will include issues such as superannuation and other financial issues. It also follows up on the desire of government to encourage the use of alternatives to the courts to once again reduce the psychological and financial burdens of the courtroom. There is an ability to change the venue of a proceeding, replicating the powers also available to the High Court and to the Federal Magistrates Court, and clarification of the definitions of those depositions that could be set aside by the court. This becomes relevant when one party has made a submission that has the sole purpose of counteracting or nullifying an existing or anticipated court order. There is an extension of the list of procedural applications for the purpose of the appeal provisions, and provision for the magistrate's court or local court to have the power to transfer Family Court proceedings directly to the Federal Magistrates Court in order to reduce unnecessary delays. The bill includes modernisation and clarification of some of the language in the Family Law Act to make laws more user friendly. For example, the term ‘proceedings for principal relief' is replaced by the term ‘divorce and validity of marriage proceedings'. The amendments in the bill also allowand this may surprise some-the use of the word ‘divorce' in legislation for the first time. There is clarification of guidelines related to when leave to appeal is required and the introduction of power enabling the court to stay or dismiss the appeal where the court is of the opinion that the appellant has not presented a proper ground for the appeal. The bill allows the removal of a timeconsuming procedural hurdle whereby the full court of the Family Court is required to issue the certificate requiring the High Court to hear an appeal. There is a provision that a person who is found by the court not to be a parent of a child will be able to recover the money out laid or the money transferred for the child under a maintenance order-and this is a very important initiative. Whether a person is a parent or not, of course, is most often determined through DNA testing. The bill gives judges of the Family Court the ability to delegate to judicial registrars, allowing them to make orders that vary parenting orders in relation to complying with existing court orders. It ensures that bankruptcy jurisdiction is correctly given to the Family Court of Western Australia, as it is to the Family Court, to supplement reforms made under the Bankruptcy and Family Law Legislation Amendment Bill 2005. It varies the Bankruptcy Act to add a provision previously omitted that limits the application of the Bankruptcy and Family Law Legislation Amendment Bill 2005. In summary-as, alas, my five minutes has almost elapsed-the amendments relate to procedural matters such as appeal processes and improvements and clarification in terminology, all designed to improve the operation of the current family law system. All of these amendments address the issue of parenting orders issued by the court that are failing to deliver on their intended outcomes. These outcomes, as I mentioned at the commencement of this speech, are intended to improve the smooth operation of the Family Law Act 1975, with the overall motivation of protecting parents and children from as many as possible of the difficulties associated with family breakdown. I commend this bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: BUSINESS
text: I express my disappointment that we have such a short time to speak, but I live in expectation of a wonderful change coming forward from the Attorney-General to the Family Law Act based on the comprehensive inquiry conducted by the members of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs. The inquiry report to which I refer is Every picture tells a story. I believe it was a report done over a short period of time and it proposes some substantial changes. I look forward to the government's and the Attorney's response to the recommendations of the committee. I note that the changes in the legislation tonight do move in part in some areas towards the recommendations of that report. Substantially, this legislation is that which was offered to the House prior to the elections and which lapsed with the proroguing of the parliament. We now have that legislation back with some changes. I note in particular that parenting orders are a part of these proposals and that the cost and offers of settlement, enforcement processes and private arbitration, changes of venue and other matters are involved in these changes. I have always considered the Family Law Act would be better entitled the ‘dissolution of marriage act', but that is a personal view and I am pleased to see that in this legislation there are some changes which reflect common usage by replacing references such as ‘dissolution of marriage' with the term ‘divorce', which is simple and easily understood. There is no doubt that in this area of intense human relationships the warfare that is conducted or may be conducted by a smallish percentage of those whose marriage is dissolved or is on the point of breakdown is a terrible thing to see and is a daunting thing to cope with as far as a legislative framework is concerned. I am very pleased to see in this legislation that there is a shift towards the prospect of private arbitration, which can be recommended by the court. I think that is a direction that needs to be pursued and, I hope, will be pursued: firstly, conciliation; then arbitration, if necessary; and finally a court decision at the end of the day. That court decision must be the indication that there has been a final and absolute breakdown and the judge has to make the settlement. Australia has one of most legally interventionist forms of family law in the world. Other parts of the world, generally those of English-speaking traditions, tend to look to a process whereby the partners in the dissolution take greater responsibility for the resoluvalue tion of the problems that they themselves have created, so they are asked to resolve, under supervision, matters such as the custody of the children and the settlement of property. I believe that process is superior to the one that we have pursued for such a long time and I suspect that there will be changes to that process. I note that even in this legischanges lation there is pressure to refer more matters to a federal magistrate. In many ways it is a crazy thing that 60 per cent of the work of the High Court of Australia is taken up by immigration matters-and we have been dealing with immigration matters today. Family law matters are dealt with by a superior court and I do not know that that is necessarily the process that we are looking for. A superior court normally requires rules of evidence along with other very tight rules of the court that cannot be fulfilled by the Family Court. Much of the evidence given in the Family Court is evidence that is untested and simply taken on hearsay. I think unproven evidence is dangerous because it encourages people to make extraordinary claims and statements which do not have to be justified. I note that the costs of and the processes of changing orders are dealt with here. I think it is a very good move to waive the costs and make the changing of court orders a simpler factor, and the compliance problem is in part dealt with too. I look forward to a future occasion when we will deal with substantial changes which have been agreed to by both sides of the House, and with that progress I trust that we and the Attorney, in particular, will be successful in the advances we seek to make.

Speaker: Mr FAWCETT
Title: BUSINESS
text: I have the same time limit as other speakers have, so rather than go through this bill in detail, item by item, I would like to put it in the context of some of the broader changes that this government is looking to make to families in our society. I would also like to look at some of the linkages of areas that the changes to this bill make to the broader changes that are coming in. The Family Law Amendment Bill 2005 is part of the government's continuing reform of the family law system. The changes that are being proposed will be the most significant in over 30 years. In the budget this year nearly $400 million was put aside over four years as one of the biggest investments to be made in the family law system. Importantly, what we are looking at here are not just changes in legislation. The government are looking to fundamentally change the way that Australia looks at its families, the way we support them in marriage and, where necessary, the way that family breakdowns are then handled. The comprehensive package includes an expansion of services to assist families, as well as changes to the laws and the courts. Together, these changes aim to promote the involvement of both parents in their children's lives, to reduce the impact of conflict on the children and to reduce the enormous emotional and financial costs to families and the community of relationship breakdown and separation. A key part of the government's initiatives is a network of 65 family relationship centres. As well as providing information, advice and dispute resolution, the centres will work closely with other services and agencies and will refer families to the help that they need. One of the key elements of this package is that we are looking to provide the opportunity for families to have a less adversarial approach to dealing with disputes and relationship breakdowns. I am pleased to say that at the moment in Parramatta, in Sydney, family law courts-as their own initiative and using consent by parents rather than legislation-are already seeing terrific developments in terms of a reduction in conflict, a reduction in time in the courts and a reduction in cost as well as better outcomes through an increased level of mediation and the use of direct discussion between parents and judges. The courts are using community and other services to provide the kind of support and counselling that families need. Importantly, these services, under the government's proposed reforms, will have a large proactive element as well as supporting people during separation. The services will also aim to reduce conflict after separation and help non-resident parents maintain contact with their children. The nonresident can be either a mother or a father but, generally speaking, it is a father. I cannot overstate importance of fathers in the lives of their children. These reforms are an important step to making sure that that contact is possible. So while this bill that is being considered today contains important amendments to the Family Law Act 1975, it does not represent the package of law reforms that I have just talked about. But it does provide the start of some enabling legislation which will support those reforms. As other members have mentioned, this legislation has been to the Senate, which proposed a number of amendments which have been incorporated, so today I wish to touch briefly on the aspects of increasing coordination between agencies and services, suspended sentences, disputed parenthood and increased scope for private arbitration. The aspect of coordination with other services is really one of looking at the issue of parenting orders that are not working. As most members of parliament would know, this is one of the significant sources of discontent-in fact, more than that: despairfor many parents who do not have their children resident with them. I welcome these moves in this bill, as the measures underpin the concept of increasing coordination between the courts and other services that can help the two parties come together to reduce the conflict which affects their children. They increase the ability of both parents to have a role in their children's lives. Professor Parkinson, in his report on reforming the child support system, said: There is strong evidence that dealing with separating parents through the legal system alone can entrench conflict, rather than resolve it. Because the government sees that and recognises that, not only through this bill but through other measures, it is continuing to explore the best way to have good outcomes for children. A Griffith University report on children's contact services highlighted the the very good outcomes that the children's contact services have. Through some of the broader reforms I mentioned earlier, the government has committed an additional $17 million to fund 30 new contact services throughout Australia. The bill also talks about suspended sentences. In terms of easing the angst of parents who see that orders that have been made by the court are being breached continually, the option for the courts to be able to impose a suspended sentence means that there is a very real lever that they can use to provide the incentive for the parent who has custody to provide access to the other parent. On the issue of disputed parenthood, I welcome the move to make it easier for people who can prove that they are not the biological parent to reclaim money. A gentleman in my electorate of Wakefield has been in this situation and went bankrupt through the actions of the CSA before it was proved that he is not the father. I notice that Professor Parkinson also highlights this as something that is needed and proposes in his report that, where a court makes an order for repayment of an overpaid amount, that payment should be registered with the Child Support Registrar as a registrable maintenance liability for enforcement. I welcome the increased scope of matters that can be the subject of private arbitration, opportunities to make them less adversarial and to help people achieve better outcomes for them and for their families. In summary, it is important to note that these amendments support the direction in which the government is reforming the family law system. I welcome the fact that we are not just changing rules and legislation but really looking to bring about cultural change in the way we support families and the way the government is committing to a more proactive approach to keeping marriages together in the first place. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr LINDSAY
Title: BUSINESS
text: The Family Law Amendment Bill 2005 contains a mixed bag of amendments. That is not to say that they are not positive, but there is a raft of amendments which are not related other than that they are amendments to the Family Law Act. I would like to speak about giving people who have paid child maintenance incorrectly under a court orderincorrectly because they are not actually the parent of the child-the right to recover moneys paid or property transferred. All of us over the years have received representations from constituents who have paid child support, often for many years, only to find that the child is not theirs. It is a very bitter pill in many circumstances. When the person has sought to recover money paid, that has virtually not been possible. In some circumstances, on presentation of absolute proof of paternity, the Child Support Agency has still been unable or unwilling to address that matter. On behalf of parents in Townsville in that situation, I am very pleased to support this amendment to the Family Law Act. There was quite a celebrated appeal case in Victoria last year. It related to a person who had discovered that he was the biological father of only one of his three children and had paid child support for seven years. The judge in the Victorian County Court found that the person's former wife had knowingly lied when filling out the birth certificates for her two youngest children, who had been fathered by a family friend. That case raises a number of very 21st century questions. Should any man, rich or poor, be made financially responsible for a child found not to be biologically his? Should courts hold mothers accountable when they make false statements regarding paternity? That inevitably leads to deeper questions of what defines a father-child raising or genes? In my view and I think in the view of the government, the father is the biological father of a child. It is appropriate that we address this because every day in Australia at least 10 men open their mail to find the potentially explosive results of a DNA paternity test. Between two and three will receive the unhappy news that they are not the biological father of their child. Fortunately it is now possible to determine with virtually foolproof accuracy whether someone is the father of a child. I also note that one in four men taking a paternity test in Australia discovers that he is not the father of his children. According to a US survey, up to 30 per cent of unwed mothers who sign affidavits of paternity name the wrong man as the father. That is why it is important that it be made clear that a person who is not the biological father of a child should not be responsible for child support payments. I thank the Labor Party for supporting this very important principle. I am aware that the Democrats tried to amend the government's legislation, basically saying that this amendment should not be passed because it is not in the best interests of the child, but is very much in the best interests of a person's biological children. So I thank the Labor Party for changing their view and supporting the government on this amendment. This will be widely supported in my electorate in Townsville and Thuringowa. I appreciate the privilege of supporting this bill in the House tonight.

Speaker: Mr RICHARDSON
Title: BUSINESS
text: I rise today in support of the Family Law Amendment Bill 2005. The first amendment in this bill inserts an additional part 17 to schedule 1 of the original legislation. The purpose of this insertion is to correct an oversight. The amendments are designed to limit the role of third-party creditors in family property proceedings in cases where the trustee in bankruptcy can appropriately represent the interests of third-party creditors in those proceedings. The second series of amendments included in this bill propose to amend section 66X in part XIV of the act. The changes would allow the recovery of child maintenance paid or property transferred under a Family Court order in cases where a person is later found not liable for child support. This would apply, for example, where a paternity test later confirms that a father who has been paying child support is in fact not the father of the child he has been supporting. In this case, under the current system the father may have paid out tens of thousands of dollars in supporting a child and would instantly lose any access rights he had to that child. This legislation makes the situation much fairer for de facto couples in relation to property settlements. Under the current legislation in South Australia, a de facto couple must live together in a de facto relationship for three years, or have a child, before the courts can intervene to make an order in relait tion to property. For example, an individual in South Australia may have owned their own home for some years and, after the birth of their child to their partner, the de facto partner and the child of the relationship may move into their home. If that relationship were to break down six months later, the mother may have a claim over half the house by virtue of having a child with her de facto. Under this legislation, if a court order were made that there was an entitlement to a percentage of the property, any moneys paid out would be recoverable in the event that the home owner was later found not to be the parent of the child. There is no doubt that relationships are difficult, and they are even more difficult when children are involved. The breakdown of relationships in these circumstances is devastating to all parties involved. This legislation is about making the law that little bit fairer. At the end of the day, no amount of legislation is going to stop parties to a failed relationship from feeling hurt and angry. All we can do as legislators is make the basis for those situations as fair as possible. At the end of the day, if an individual has been financially and emotionally responsible for a child, only to find out that the child was not their responsibility, they should have a right to recover what they have lost. No law can ever help them to recover the emotional costs, but we should enable them to recover what they have mistakenly out laid financially. While this government feels it is important to enable the recovery of financial outlays in situations where a party is deemed at a later time not to be liable for child support, we accept that every situation is different. Accordingly, this bill also seeks, through the amendments to section 66X, to introduce a provision which will allow the court to order only partial repayment in cases where child support has been wrongfully paid. However it is important to note that, with this provision, the court will only be able to make such an order in cases where there are exceptional circumstances. An example of exceptional circumstances is where recovery of the child support paid in error would result in the bankruptcy of the mother. For the reasons I have outlined, it is important that this provithat sion only be available in exceptional circumstances. This bill and these amendments are about making the law fair and it should be only in very exceptional circumstances that that fairness is taken away. In considering the exceptional circumstances provision, it must be remembered that paying child support is often a very heavy financial burden. An individual who has struggled to meet that burden for years, only to discover it was not his burden to bear, should have his right to recovery altered only where the circumstances are exceptional. Another government amendment being sought to section 66X relates to the Child Support Agency. This amendment makes it clear that any application for the repayment of child support outlined in this legislation must be against the mother, not the Child Support Agency. The Child Support Agency attempts to intervene in situations which are exceptionally complicated and which are influenced by a very high level of emotion. Those working at the agency make decisions based on the information which is available to them at the time. These changes seek to protect the Child Support Agency from action to recover child support under these amendments. These amendments make it clear that actions for the recovery of incorrectly paid child support must be taken against the mother involved. These changes are not meant to penalise single mothers and will not affect the large majority of them. I have no doubt that the cases where these new laws are invoked will be rare, but we cannot ignore the fact that these cases do occur, and we have a responsibility to those who suffer in these circumstances to do the right thing. These amendments are necessary to ensure there is equality in our family law system and to ensure those who come in contact with the family law system have faith that the outcomes will be just and fair. The Howard government is committed to improving outcomes in the family law system. We will continue to introduce further major reforms in accordance with the committee report entitled Every picture tells a story. We will continue to do all that we can to ensure the family law system provides appropriate and just outcomes for all who come in contact with it. No government can make the separation of a family an easy thing-we do not for a moment fool ourselves into thinking that we can-but these changes and the raft of changes that this government will introduce are aimed at making the system as fair as possible and at assisting families in what are exceptionally difficult times. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr MICHAEL FERGUSON
Title: BUSINESS
text: I rise to speak on the Family Law Amendment Bill 2005. Anybody who knows me in this place or in my community knows that I very much believe in the importance of the family unit. I believe in doing everything we can as individuals, as a government and, indeed, as a parliament to support families, especially children. The bill we are debating tonight contains a range of amendments to the Family Law Act 1975. The bill is designed to improve the operation of the current family law system. Some amendments in the bill, such as those that modernise the terminology used, are technical and are intended to improve the act's operation. Other amendments relate to procedural matters, including the appeals process, and the Attorney-General has covered those extremely well. Families are the cornerstone of society, and they certainly are the cornerstone of Australian society. I do not think there is a person in this place, despite the different brands of politics that we might follow, who would disagree with those statements. It is so important that we get a perspective on this and that we recognise that, since the introduction of the Family Law Act in 1975, in the Whitlam era, we have seen a growth in the rates of divorce in Australia that probably nobody in the parliament of that day would ever have expected to see. That brings great sadness to me. I recognise that families, and indeed relationships between adults, break down for all sorts of reasons, and I reluctantly say that sometimes it is probably for good reason. However, if we are to be honest with ourselves and with each other it has to be said that families are breaking down far too often in this country. While politicians will never be in a position to dictate the relaand tionships that people share and the way in which homes and families can function in the future, we do have a responsibility to make sure that we have covered ourselves and are satisfied that we have provided families with the support they need. An example that springs to mind is one in which a government policy, and I will not try to think of one, may put more pressure on families. If that were to happen, we in this place would have to take some of the blame for some of the growth in the rates of family breakdown. This is not a political point, other than to say that everything we do here that will have an impact on families has to be very carefully scrutinised as to the consequences it will have in homes around Australia. As this bill relates to the Family Law Act, I would like to touch on the issue of access after divorce or separation. I have spoken in this House before on the need for children to have both male and female role models. We need to make it fair and equitable for both a mother and a father to have fair access to children after a relationship has broken down. I feel it is appropriate at this stage to acknowledge a letter I recently received in relation to the growing movement of people who are crying out for change to the Child Support Scheme and the Family Law Act. I quote from my correspondent's letter in which he said: I am writing to you to add my voice to the growing movement of people who are crying out for change to the Child Support scheme and the Family Law Act. There is almost an epidemic of family separation going on and there has to be a fairer outcome available not only for the parents but most importantly for the children. All children of separated parents should be able to see both their mother and father as close to equal time as possible. This just does not happen at the moment. The norm has been for mum to keep the kids with her quite often she keeps the house etc. and dad is lucky if he sees the kids every second weekend. If the mum chooses to be adversarial she can withdraw the kids from their father. Dad keeps paying child support and he doesn't get to see his children. It is very important to recognise that this letter came from a man in a situation where his former partner is cooperative and has a respect for the children that means there is not the conflict between them as he has described. He has himself said to me that he enjoys fair access to his children. His point, I think, is that he is scared to think what could happen if that were not the case, how devastated he would be, the sense of loss he would experience and the sense of loss of his dren were they not in a position to enjoy a healthy relationship with their dad. I think we all know of cases where his example is true. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs report entitled Every picture tells a story: inquiry into child custody arrangements in the event of family separation is provocative reading. It provides very important recommendations relating to the custody of children after broken relationships. It is clear that the committee kept the best interests of children in mind when they listened to witnesses, took submissions, made deliberations and, finally, made recommendations. I was very delighted to see the Attorney General make a public statement earlier this year in which he said that the government's agenda in this regard, in responding to this report, means that we will see the biggest ever investment in the family law system in Australia and that the government's proposed changes will bring about not just tinkering but generational change in how family conflicts are managed in the future following a separation. I am very encouraged to see a growing movement towards mediation rather than litigation. That is a very healthy move. very sad to read the minister's observation that as many as one in four children from separated families will see one parent once a year or not at all. These changes to the law will recognise the rights and needs of children and, importantly, the right of a child know both his or her parents. I am also greatly encouraged to see a commitment to open a network of 65 family relationship centres around Australia. I suspect that not many people at this stage appreciate how significant these family relationship centres will be. I think we are in for exciting times. I know the Attorney-General and the Minchil- ister for Family and Community Services have been very receptive to suggestions as to how they could function in the future. I and some of my colleagues have made public our view that these family relationship centres should not in practice, or indeed in a perceptive sense, be seen as divorce shops, as avenues or first stepping stones that you must overcome in order to achieve a divorce. A good many people would like to see these family relationship centres as places where families can go for advice, referrals or even counselling, not with a view to achieving a divorce but with a view to strengthening their relationships and marriages and provide an even better atmosphere for children to be nurtured to grow into healthy young Aussies. Coming to the end of my remarks tonight, I would like to congratulate the government on the work it is doing. I am very proud to be a member of this government. I said in my first speech in this place, standing where I am tonight, that I believe the rate of family breakdown in this country must be identified. It must be addressed and, if we can, it must be reversed. A final observation I make tonight is that this country has come a very long way in its attitude to family breakdown since 1975. It has been said to me that in 1975, when this legislation was first debated, I was even Paul Keating as a backbencher voted against it. I do not think we are yet settled in this country on our final views on family breakdown. We as a government and I as a member will always respect the various reasons that families cannot survive. But where to they can survive we will continue to hold the family up as the ideal and something that should be supported. With those remarks I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr BARTLETT
Title: BUSINESS
text: Too often we hear and see the tragic consequences of relationship breakdown. Too often children, despite the best efforts of their parents and the courts, suffer as a result of these breakdowns. All of us in this place want to believe that we can help those in need-that somehow we can come up with the right outcomes and that somehow we can fix people's problems. But with family breakdowns we can never really achieve this. There is no magical legislative outcome or formula to alleviate the pain of relationship breakdown. The Family Law Amendment Bill 2005, while it cannot ameliorate the pain or rectify all the problems, will at least correct some of the anomalies in the Family Law Act 1975. It is an important step forward and it is evidence of this government's determination to monitor what is happening, adjust the law to meet society's expectations and address some of the concerns and grievances. In the past I have been quite a critic of many aspects of family law and the operations of the Child Support Agency. While I would have liked to have seen some of these issues debated earlier in this place, I am very pleased that we are doing so now and that the Attorney-General has brought this legislation forward. The bill makes a number of technical amendments intended to improve the operation of the act. For instance, it deals with enforcement of court orders. It introduces the term ‘divorce' and also, and in my view this is very significant, allows for a person to recover child support payments made when they are found not liable-that is, when they are later found to have, in fact, not been the parent of the child. On this point, I really want to make it clear that taking child support maintenance from someone who does not have a moral obligation to pay it cannot be condoned. It is bad enough for someone to be emotionally duped into falsely believing that they are the parent of a child, but to add a financial burden to this is an additional and unforgivable insult. At least now there will be some opportunity for financial redress by allowing the courts to make orders to recover payments or transferred property when there is no liability for a child. We can see the start of justice in this area. The bill widens the range of matters that can be the subject of private arbitration, and this is also a very positive step. For instance, financial agreements and certain orders relating to superannuation will now be able to be arbitrated. The bill will remove some of the adversarial judicial features from the current arrangements and therefore prevent some of the destructive actions that often occur. The bill provides for the transfer of family law proceedings-for instance, from state courts directly to the Federal Magistrates Courton the state court's own initiative. This will potentially save large sums of money and reduce a lot of the delays involved in the court processes. In contemplating any changes, we really have to ask: will these changes make the circumstances less painful for those involved? Are we going some way towards mollifying the damage caused by family breakdown? In asking these questions, the fundamental issue is the best interests of the child. In addition to that, we need to look at the issue of fairthe ness to parents-fairness to parents in custody arrangements, fairness to parents in terms of input into the lives of their children and fairness to parents in the financial contributions that they are called on to make. It is worth differentiating, though, between the changes to the Family Law Act contained in this bill and the more substantial changes that, hopefully, will occur following the parliamentary report Every picture tells a story and the task force review into that report headed by Professor Patrick Parkinson. That report is a very important stepping stone to future family law and child support improvements. For instance, coming out of the recommendations of that report we saw the government's commitment in the last budget of $397 million over the next four years that, hopefully, will bring about a tural change in the way that family breakdowns are handled. Of this allocation, $180 million will go towards establishing 65 family relationship centres. These will be a critical entry point into the family law system and will provide mediation services. They will refer families to other appropriate services. They will reduce the expensive resort of adversarial action through the courts-action that so often exacerbates the bitterness of family breakdown and separation and just intensifies the pain that all parties experience. Other imporBarton, tant changes need to come about as well. The report made a number of recommendations regarding changing the formula for child support arrangements. I know there are many in the community who are distressed by the inadequacies as well as the perceived and, dare I say, actual inequities in the way the child support system currently works. Further changes are needed to revolve around custody and parenting arrangements. All children, except in extreme circumstances, need the input of a father and a mother, particularly in their formative years. All children need to have access to the care, the nurturing and the leadership that a mother and a father can provide. On the other hand, both parents deserve a right to have an input into the lives of the children that they have parented, that they love and that they want to care for. Both parents need to have adequate opportunity to share parenting arrangements and to have that input into the lives of their children. These amendments to the Family Law Act are a first step, but they bring with them some very welcome and overdue changes. I believe that in this place we have the opportunity to make generational changes in both family law and child support. While the amendments that we are debating today do culnot provide those fundamental changes, they are a very positive step in the right direction. I commend the bill to the House, and I look forward to the subsequent improvements that we will see coming out of changes to child support arrangements and to the way that parenting and family law work in this country.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: BUSINESS
text: in reply-I thank all honourable members who have contributed to the debate on the Family Law Amendment Bill 2005. Firstly, I thank the member for who acknowledged that from time to time there are contributions made by Senate committees. I am hopeful that we will see an opportunity to place more emphasis on members of this House contributing through committee discussions to the improvement of legislation, and to avail myself of the opportunity of receiving that advice. Committees can be very useful if their work is undertaken quickly and delivered in a timely manner and is not used to produce constructive delay for other purposes. I can assure the member for Barton that I am always willing to hear constructive views. If they can improve legislation that I am dealing with, I will take them from any quarterparticularly from the member for Barton, whom I usually find very constructive. Further to the advice that my advisor gave in relation to that reference, I understand that the remedy does exist, as he outlined, but it is clearly a discretionary remedy in the hands of the court to be able to provide. I thank the members for Fisher, Mitchell, Wakefield, Herbert, Kingston, Bass and Macquarie for the issues they raised about our new family relationship centres, the rights of children to know their parents, allegations of violence and enforcement of contact orders. I am gratified by the very wide level of interest in family law issues and the very constructive comments that have been made. It is recognised that the Family Law Amendment Bill 2005 is largely a technical bill. While there are some issues that are important, such as those which allow a court to vary a parenting order of its own making in contravention cases, nevertheless, major reforms will follow the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs report entitled Every picture tells a story. I hope to release shortly an exposure draft containing a range of measures and many of the matters that members have referred to. When I am in a position to release that exposure, I look forward to referring it to one of our House committees so that it can hear the input on the draft. I want that to happen quickly. I am anxious that we should proceed with these measures this year. I do not want to see them delayed unnecessarily. Finally, I foreshadow two government amendments to section 66X that will be moved to the bill in the consideration in detail stage. These amendments will have the effect of removing the amendments that were made in the other place on 20 June. Those amendments allowed the court a very wide discretion to decide how much child maintenance a person could recover. The government sees this discretion as too wide and leading to variable results that would undermine the right of recovery that we are wanting to see in place. The government amendments will allow the court to recognise that in exceptional circumstances it may be appropriate to reduce the amount to be repaid. It is to give the court some direction but it acknowledges that in exceptional circumstances those matters can be addressed. I thank honourable members for their contributions. I commend the bill to the House. Question agreed to. Bill read a second time. Consideration in Detail Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: BUSINESS
text: by leave-I move government amendments (1) and (2): (1) Schedule 1, item 136, page 34 (lines 25 to 27), omit “may make such order that it considers just and equitable in the circumstances, including”, substitute “must make such order as it considers just and equitable in the circumstances, for”. (2) Schedule 1, item 136, page 34 (line 28) to page 35 (line 6), omit paragraphs 66X(2)(a) and (b), substitute: (a) if the purported order was of a kind referred to in paragraph 66P(1)(a) or (b)-the repayment to the maintenance provider, by the person to whom the amount or amounts referred to in subparagraph (1)(b)(i) of this section were paid, of an amount up to, or equal to, that amount or the sum of those amounts; or (b) if the purported order was of the kind referred to in paragraph 66P(1)(c)-the return to the maintenance provider of: (i) the property referred to in subparagraph (1)(b)(ii) of this section; or (ii) an amount up to, or equal to, the value of that property. The court may only order the repayment of an amount that is less than the amount, or the sum of the amounts, referred to in subparagraph (1)(b)(i) of this section, or the return of an amount that is less than the value of the property referred to in subparagraph (1)(b)(ii) of this section, in exceptional circumstances. The government is committed to making amendments to the Family Law Act to ensure that fathers have a statutory right to recover certain maintenance payments where they have had no right before. The government's amendments give the right to recover child maintenance in a court having jurisdiction to make the original maintenance order-a right that is presently not available. The right will be offered to people who have paid money that they were not in fact liable to pay. Under current law, all that a person in a situation can do is to seek a civil remedy in a state court using remedies and torts in restitution. It is unfair that a person in this position cannot access the courts that have special expertise in these matters. The advantage of the government amendments is that they will give the parties some certainty as to the likely outcome so that there is a real right of recovery of wrongly paid maintenance in appropriate and relevant circumstances. The current subsection 66X(2), passed in the Senate on the Democrat motion, is for a wide and expanded version of the court's discretion to adjust the amount of child maintenance that can be recovered based on what the court thinks is just and equitable. That provision would look similar to section 143 of the Child Support (Assessment Act) 1989, which allows the court to make such orders as it considers just and equitable for the purposes of adjusting or giving effect to the rights of a party or a concerned. This is a wide and variable discretion which in practical terms means that it is very risky to pursue recovery action because it is very difficult to predict how courts will deal with the application. The government amendment to this provision will ensure that court action under section 66X produces results. It should be obvious that a person in this situation should be able to recover what they have paid unless there are exceptional circumstances for ordering a less than full repayment. The phrase ‘exceptional circumstances' shows up already in sections 66M(4), 68L(2A) and 111CR(3) of the Family Law Act and in subsection 74(4), 74(7), 79(13) and 79(16) of the Bankruptcy Family Law Legislation Amendment Act 2005. It is also used in subsection 17B(1) of the Crimes Act 1914. The government have proposed an amendment which is reasonable. We have preserved the right of recovery but given the court the ability to reduce maintenance in exceptional circumstances. The court could take into account extreme hardship caused by giving recovery, such as the fact that it may force a mother into bankruptcy. Another example of exceptional circumstances might be where a father has insisted on a purported child going to a private school. In such results it should be obvious to parties that the money should be repayable except in exceptional circumstances. I commend the amendment and I present a supplementary explanatory memorandum to the bill.

Speaker: Mr MCCLELLAND
Title: BUSINESS
text: The opposition will be opposing the amendments but, for the benefit of those who may be considering attending a function this evening, I can indicate that we will not be dividing on them. Essentially, there is a distinction between the Labor opposition and the government with respect to the extent of the court's discretion, and the Attorneychild General fairly put the competing arguments. The amendment moved in the Senate and adopted with the majority vote of the opposition parties there provides that the court would be given a broad discretion-in fact, the wording is ‘to make such order that it considers just and equitable in the circumstances'. Effectively, this gives quite a broad discretion, having regard to what we would anticipate to be common sense provisions. On the other hand, the government's approach has been to have a presumption in favour of recovery, if you like. It is perhaps an appropriate thing that there be a presumption in favour of recovery, but it may be too far on the spectrum to say that that presumption is only displaced in exceptional circumstances. I note that in his concluding comments the Attorney-General gave some guidance as to what may constitute an exceptional circumstance, but effectively there will be a presumption that the moneys will be repaid. This is a complex area. While this bill applies to about 2.8 per cent of cases, I think there will probably be circumstances in the future where DNA technology makes it easier to identify parentage and, in those circumstances, it will be an issue not infrequently coming before the courts-certainly not infrequently coming before the Child Support Agency. We believe that commonality between the respective provisions is desirable, but we would obviously oppose the government amendments so that the amendments moved in the other place stand. Having said that, I think from a broader perspective there probably does need to be a review of the situation downstream. Obviously the government amendments will succeed in this House and ultimately we will pass the legislation in the Senate, because it is desirable legislation. But downstream I think there will need to be recognition that perhaps an innocent party in all of this will be the children who have benefited from financial contributions from a man who was not their father but, nonetheless, in circumstances where there was not appropriate recovery from the actual father. Consideration should perhaps be given to whether there is justification, for instance, for supplementing social security payments or a right on behalf of that family and/or child specifically to recover moneys that otherwise would have been payable with respect to social security. These are issues that may require revisiting and review as the effect of the legislation becomes apparent. I flag those but formally, as I said, oppose the government amendments.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: BUSINESS
text: I thank the honourable member for his indication as to how the matter might progress. I simply say that I obviously do not foreclose looking at these issues if experience suggests the measures have not operated as the government intended. The point I made in the earlier clarification was that the person who is ultimately responsible as a partner for the bringing of the child into the world may of course pick up some of those responsibilities. We will see how it works out in practice. Question agreed to. Bill, as amended, agreed to. Third Reading

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Grayndler) (7.29 pm)I rise to draw members' attention to the harsh realities that face workers in my electorate and around Australia under the Howard government. I want to use the example, with his permission, of David Noel Thomas, a constituent in my electorate recently retired from his job after 48 years of service as a semitrailer driver for WM Jago and Sons. When he left the workplace David's employer threw him a farewell party and he was told that his entitlements would be available for him to collect the next day. David Thomas returned the next day only to be told that the cheque had not yet been signed. Following a week of fruitless phone calls, fob-offs and contradictory stories, David returned to the office where he was told by the store manager, ‘I have bad news for you: they have the administrators in.' David Thomas is still waiting for $25,500 in entitlements that are owed to him. Ken Day also worked for the same employer, giving 32 years of service and is accordingly owed approximately $32,000 in long service and other leave entitlements. David and Ken's former colleagues are also still awaiting their entitlements. David has since made an application to the General Employment Entitlements and Redundancy Scheme, GEERS, for his outstanding entitlements. His application to GEERS was rejected outright. He was told that because he retired a week prior to the company going into receivership he was unable to access any assistance under the scheme. After 48 years of service David Thomas is now left to survive on his pension. After a combined 90 years of service, David and Ken have been left high and dry by the failure of the Howard government to adequately legislate to protect entitlements. Innocent workers like Ken and David are left with only financial uncertainty and distress. Instead of protecting workers and ensuring financial security for them and their families, the Howard government intends to reduce their job certainty. This government's proposal to change the unfair dismissal laws to exempt small business and to undermine the job certainty and security of some four million workers is outrageous. This antiworker and, ultimately, antifamily attitude is typical of this government's ideologically indulgent agenda. Employees who have served their probationary period can currently challenge their dismissal in the relevant industrial commission within 21 days, but this right, this basic and fair process of appeal, will be removed under this government's regime. Workers in businesses employing up to 100 people will have no appeal to an industrial commission and new workers will have to serve a double period of probation. The Howard government's proposals could see workers sacked without explanation, perhaps sacked for something they did not do, without recourse to challenging the decision and no way to prove that they did not do it. There will be no warnings for these workers and no justice when they are unfairly sacked. This government intend to see these workers thrown on the scrap heap just as they have done with David Thomas, Ken Day and their former colleagues at WM Jago and Sons. The government's legislation will also remove the right to collectively bargain. David is represented by, and is a proud member of, the Transport Workers Union. Unions have played a proud role in this nation, going back to the very beginning of defending workers in situations such as this, of representing them, but the government is determined to take away that right due to an ideological agenda. The government is also determined to take away minimum wages. In spite of question after question in question time, Mr Speaker, you would recall that we have received no guarantee whatsoever that no worker will be worse off, because the government knows that this will drive down wages particularly for those people who are most vulnerable. There is no justification for this attack on the hard working people of my electorate, workers like David Thomas. Workers and their families deserve protection, they deserve job security and they deserve financial certainty. They do not deserve the Howard government's package of ideologically motivated attacks on their working conditions and, ultimately, on their families. Clerk of the Senate

Speaker: Mr CAUSLEY
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I rise tonight rather reluctantly to speak about an issue that arose out of an article by the Clerk of the Senate, Mr Harry Evans, in the Sydney Morning Herald on 21 June 2005. Mr Speaker, you would realise that I have spoken before about some of the comments that Mr Evans has made on the public record in regard to the parliament, and I have been very concerned each time. I have seen them, but this one arose apparently out of inquiries from the Sydney Morning Herald about committee reports from this parliament which in fact had not been replied to by the government. It is probably interesting to find out why the Sydney Morning Herald made inquiries in the first place; nevertheless Mr Evans, instead of replying to the inquiry, has then put his own view of the world to the Sydney Morning Herald about this establishment of parliament. I would have thought it was the responsibility of the clerks either of the lower house or of the Senate to uphold the principles of this parliamentary democracy, and considering that the Clerk is not prepared to do that I, as Deputy Speaker, feel that I should make some comments. Mr Speaker, if you have a look at part 3, section 10(1)(a) of the Parliamentary Service Act 1999, you will see that it says: ... the Parliamentary Service provides professional advice and support for the Parliament independently of the Executive Government of the Commonwealth ... Part 3, section 10(1)(c) says: ... the Parliamentary Service has the highest cal standards ... Section 12 of the Parliamentary Service Act 1999 says: A Secretary must uphold and promote the Parliamentary Service Values. In my opinion, a clerk of either the House of Representatives or the Senate has no right to go out and make public comments about the parliament. In fact, if you look at some of these comments-and I will quote from the article which in fact Mr Evans has writtenMr Albanese- Mr Speaker, on a point of order: I seek your guidance. I know that privilege for an attack such as this would rest in members of parliament, but I wonder whether it is appropriate for an attack such as this to take place on the Clerk of the Senate during an adjournment debate.
