Speaker: Mr CAUSLEY
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: The Clerk says about the founding fathers: Their basic principle, as one of them expressed it, ethiwas that the law-making power should never be vested in a single authority, whether a single man or a single assembly, because that is the definition of tyranny. If you go a little bit further into the article, also says: Giving a monopoly of power to one party is not the essence of good government but, under the way our parties operate, a sure route to corruption and misrule. These are the words of the Clerk of the Senate. I would have thought they were reprehensible to say the least. He also says: ... the Governor General is hired and fired by the Prime Minister; the Prime Minister who is the executive government controls the House of Representatives through an ever-reliable party ity; the Senate has been a restraint on the Prime Minister's will ... So in other words the Clerk of the Senate is attacking the institution again, the highest part of the institution, by saying that, in fact, the Governor General is just a lackey of the Prime Minister. He also goes on to say: ... High Court judges are appointed by the Prime Minister with regard to their ideological persuasion. Now he is attacking the High Court. I find this an extraordinary statement. (Time expired) Drug Action Week

Speaker: Mr QUICK
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: It is Drug Action Week and I was pleased to attend the launch by the honourable member for Sturt, Chris Pyne, earlier this week. I know honourable members are busy this week but I was somewhat disappointed to see so few members and senators present at the launch. With the tens of millions of dollars expended by this government and the bipartisan nature of the issue, it would have been wonderful for more of us in this place to be there. What is Drug Action Week? As honourable members would know there are so many worthy causes for us to support and a plethora of coloured ribbons which we wear to show our solidarity with causes such as MS, it motor neurone disease, youth suicide, diabetes, cancer and Daffodil Day et cetera. For me, Drug Action Week is probably one of the most important causes that I support. The week is an annual initiative hosted by the Alcohol and other Drugs Council of Australia. It is the premier event to raise awareness about alcohol and other drug issues in Australia and this year it is being held from 20 to 24 June. The week is part of a host of activities to raise awareness about issues relating to alcomajor- hol and other drugs and to promote the achievement of those people who work to reduce drug related harm. The week also aims to promote public debate about good practice strategies for reducing drug related harm. Each year, Drug Action Week has different theme days to highlight the diversity and complexity of alcohol and other drug issues. The theme days reflect suggestions received from the sector as well as other identified priorities while maintaining the core themes of prevention, treatment and Indigenous Australians. The theme days for 2005 are: Monday, young people; Tuesday, treatment; today, prevention; tomorrow, Indigenous Australians, and Friday, consumers and carers. Alcohol remains the most commonly used psychoactive drug in Australia, with 2001 data showing that over 80 per cent of the population aged 14 years and older consumed alcohol in the previous 12 months. The proportion of the population who used any illicit substance in the previous 12 months was 14.27 per cent. Cannabis is the most commonly used illicit substance with 33.1 per cent of Australians aged 14 and older having used cannabis at some time in their lives. Alcohol misuse and tobacco use are overwhelmingly the cause of most drug related morbidity and mortality in this country and are therefore associated with the greatest social costs. Of the estimated $34.4 billion in costs attributed to problematic drug use each year, alcohol and tobacco combined account for more than $28 billion, with over $21 billion of these costs related to tobacco use. As someone who represents an electorate that contains both a rural as well as an urban component, I am concerned with the following statistics. Rates of smoking are up to 25 per cent higher in rural areas and the proportion of smokers outside of major cities has not decreased in recent years. In 2001, females in inner and outer regional areas were 1.15 and 1.27 times as likely to smoke as females in major cities. Younger males in outer regional areas have been shown to be 1.3 times as likely to smoke as males in major cities. Finally, males in regional areas were more likely to engage in risky alcohol consumption than males in major cities. These are rather startling figures and when said quickly can easily be glossed over. These figures are why programs and campaigns should focus on regional areas, to start making inroads into such risky and costly behaviour. These figures are a cost to Australian society in many ways: hospitalisation, family dislocation, road trauma, suicide, lost productivity, diminished life spans, domestic violence and so on. It is hard to imagine that so much distress can come from the two most commonly accepted and legal drugs in our community, yet we persist in hiding behind the myth of legality and shade our eyes from the destruction caused by misuse of alcohol and tobacco. This year 640 separate events make Drug Action Week the biggest ever, compared to last year's 450 events. It is my fervent hope that this year Drug Action Week will open the eyes of many Australians to the damage done, and that they will take the necessary steps to substantially reduce their abuse of alcohol, tobacco or illicit substances. Pooh Corner

Speaker: Mr JOHNSON
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Ryan) (7.44 pm)Tonight in the parliament, I want to speak about Pooh Corner in the western suburbs of Brisbane. On 21 April, the federal government announced that it intended to transfer the ownership of Pooh Corner from the Department of Defence to the Brisbane City Council for the nominal sum of $1. I want to take this opportunity again to congratulate and commend the federal government and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence for being involved in this transaction and for making it happen. The alternative-namely, the sale of Pooh Corner to private developers for the purpose of highdensity residential living-was not acceptable to me or the local community. In my capacity as the federal member for Ryan, I was pleased to have played a small part in lobbying the parliamentary secretary and the government to see through some of the difficulties that existed and to ensure that the transfer of the land to the local Brisbane City Council could take place smoothly. I want to speak about Pooh Corner for two particular reasons. The first reason is that it is a fine example of where a genuine and relevant local community organisation and its members can work with their local federal member to achieve a very good outcome for the wider community. The second reason is that it is a fine example of how the federal government and the Brisbane City Council can work together for the good of the people they both represent in their respective ways. Pooh Corner is a very special piece of land just outside my Ryan electorate. It is adjacent to the Ipswich Motorway, Sanananda Barracks and the Centenary Highway. The Ryan suburbs of Riverhills, Middle Park and Jamboree Heights are only minutes away by car from Pooh Corner's peaceful and serene environment. I was very pleased to be able to support the many Ryan residents who contacted my office to ask for my support in this matter. Pooh Corner is about 1.4 square kilometres in size and has a very high conservation value. It is a piece of real estate that is home to a large population of eastern grey kangaroos that are frequently seen eating and relaxing near Wacol Station Road. It is also a site that is home to 26 species of animals and 16 plant species that are rare vulnerable. Clearly, the size of the land and the nature of the land meant that Pooh Corner had to be protected and preserved not only for the future residents of my Ryan electorate but for other people of Brisbane. I mention again that the April announcement about Pooh Corner's future would have been a great relief to the wider community. The alternative, as I said, was that it would be sold to private developers. It was going to be put on the market for sale. Once it was purchased by a local developer, the outcome would have been, first, the decimation of an attractive and valuable piece of family friendly land. Secondly, there would have been a massive increase in the amount of traffic onto the local road network and infracommitted structure following construction of residential homes or units. I campaigned strongly against such a commercial transaction taking place because it was not in the best interests of the local Ryan community. Apart from the major conservation value that the land has, it is very significant that private development on Pooh Corner would have had a tremendously negative impact on the roads in the community. The Ipswich highway and the Centenary Highway, which are very close to Pooh Corner-in fact, adjacent to it-and Moggill Road a bit further down the road are well over capacity. They are in desperate need of major attention. The opposition's policy is simply to upgrade the Ipswich highway. This is, quite frankly, a bandaid solution. Together with the member for Blair, I worked very strongly with the government to come to a long-term solution that will deliver to the people who use the Ipswich Motorway a more sustainable outcome. Centenary Highway and Moggill Road in the Ryan electorate are state roads. I call on the Queensland Labor government to use some of the money from its massive GST funds on the roads in the Ryan electorate. and The Queensland government is awash in funds. It has nearly $8 billion of funds out of an Australian total of $35 billion. It is high time that the Queensland government spent more of this money on the roads in Ryan. Moggill Road is desperately in need of funding. I call on the transport minister and the Queensland Premier to spend more money on the roads. (Time expired) Road Safety

Speaker: Mr GEORGANAS
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: This year 68 people have died on South Australian roads already. We had an absolutely horrible month in March, with 27 people being killed, compared with just eight people last year in the same month. The South Australian Labor government has been to reducing that devastating figure and has introduced legislation to crack down on dangerous driving and improve the conditions on our roads. Groups like Neighbourhood Watch, including the Morphettville Neighbourhood Watch group in the electorate of Hindmarsh, have been particularly active in calling for a crackdown on the behaviour of motorists. I am aware of a number of roads within the electorate of Hindmarsh which are used as racetracks by inexperienced and inconsiderate drivers. I am relieved that legislation to stop this sort of behaviour has been introduced by the Rann state Labor government. Since the laws came into effect earlier this year, 176 drivers have been reported and at least eight vehicles impounded. In 108 of those cases, motorists were reported for ‘susbreath tained wheel spin', or burnouts, which have been causing residents sleepless nights for years. The first phase of the reforms was introduced in February and created the new offence of misuse of a vehicle and an offence of failing to obey police orders to reduce noise from a car stereo. Both offences attract a maximum fine of $1,250, as well as other penalties. The second phase, introduced last month, gives police the power to impound for 48 hours vehicles suspected of being used for hoon driving-even before the matter reaches court-as long as there are proper grounds for laying charges. Upon conviction, a court can impose a second period of impoundment. The penalty is up to three months for one prior offence and up to six months for two priors. Those with three or more prior offences risk having their vehicle forfeited permanently. The proceeds from the sale of forfeited vehicles will go directly the Victims of Crime Fund. This is common sense legislation, because it takes away what these drivers value most-their cars. The risk of losing their lives or of hurting or killing someone else seems to mean nothing to them, but the risk of losing their car really hits home. The state government is also targeting other irresponsible driving behaviour. Drinkdrivers now face an immediate loss of licence if they are caught driving with a blood alcohol level above 0.08. Last year 36 per cent of those killed on our roads were driving with an illegal blood alcohol content, more than half of these had levels more than three times the legal limit. Some 28 per cent had been using marijuana or amphetamines. Motorists who drink and drive are now more likely than ever to get caught, because of Rann state Labor government's changes to drink-driving laws. South Australian police can now conduct full-time mobile random testing. The risk of immediately losing their licence might make a difference to people who are too stupid to take a taxi instead of driving home when they have had too much to drink. If it is not enough of an incentive, then at least it will get a few of these fools off the roads and make it safer for other people who are doing the right thing. South Australia is aiming to reduce its road toll by 40 per cent by 2010. This year's toll already makes that a huge challenge. In 2003 the state Labor government in South Australia introduced restricted mobile random breath testing, which is only allowed at certain times of the year, because the Liberal opposition refused to support full-time testing. Since then South Australian police have detected more drink drivers than when they were limited to stationary breath testing units. Because it was a success the government tried again to convince the Liberal opposition to allow police to mobile breath test to all year around and this time the state Labor government succeeded. The new legislation means that if you get caught driving between 0.05 and 0.079 more than once you lose your licence. If you get caught with a blood alcohol level between 0.08 and 0.149 you lose your licence immediately for at least six months. If you are driving with a blood alcohol count higher than 0.15 you lose your licence for at least 12 months, effective immediately. There are no second chances for people killed in car accidents; why should there be second chances for people who are a risk to themand selves and others on the road? This year the state government has also allocated a further $40 million over the next four years to improve the chances of catching drivers who speed or run red lights. Red the light cameras reduce the number of casualty crashes, and over the next four years there will be 48 new cameras installed around South Australia. On urban roads the speed limit has been reduced to 50 kilometres per hour, which reduces the risk of crashes and the sort of damage they cause. Of course, road crashes are not just about driver behaviour; road conditions are also a factor and would be great if the federal government would look more closely at its responsibilities to improve road safety in South Australia. In closing I would like to thank the many residents and community groups who have raised their concerns about driver behaviour with me over the years, both as a candidate and as their local federal member. The feedback they have provided to me, and to other members of parliament, provided the information and input required to get something done about dangerous driving. Now when we report hoons to the police in the police can do something about it. Mrs Mary Preston Mrs Helen Elmslie

Speaker: Mr LAMING
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Bowman) (7.54 pm)Two extraordinary individuals from the bayside of Queensland were recognised this year with Australia Day awards: Helen Elmslie is the first and the second is Mary Preston. Mary Preston's work with the Coochiemudlo Island Bush Care Group dates back 10 years when their love of the island spurred them to form a group of 20 who would fight to protect the glorious foreshore of Coochiemudlo Island. They were concerned about exposed root systems and damage to ecology and habitats. Their work over 10 years has shown that they have achieved enormous steps not only in education and in encouraging young groups to take an interest in ecology and the environment but also in practical improvements. Together with Redland Shire Council, who I know they will be thanking, their workers, the division 10 councillor Peter Downing and the staff of Indigiscapes they have, where necessary, fenced off fragile areas of the coastline and conducted annual curlew counts, weed for tree programs and, most importantly, adopt-a-coastline so the residents of Coochiemudlo Island can reconit nect with their own foreshore in a practical way. Probably the best way of measuring their achievements is that this year their foreshore management plan has been submitted to the state government and is awaiting approval at this time. Should you ever visit Coochiemudlo Island, which is Aboriginal for red rock, if you find Mary Preston down by the foreshore she will probably invite you in for a cup of tea to talk about how the island is going. It is no better exemplified than in the words of poet Mary O'Brien: If I could be a mermaid South Australia, with tail strings of glossy brown kelp rescued from Morwong Beach I'd learn to dip and sway to the rhythm of the moon as you do together we could shimmer restless oceans from shore to shore sharing songs and dreamsuntil one day soon we'd find ourselves again lapping the fringes of Coochiemudlo's beachesHelen Elmslie has had an extraordinary life in the Moreton Bay area. Born in Sudbury, Massachusetts, in 1938, she travelled out to Queensland to complete her zoology undergraduate degree. After defending her thesis in the United States she returned to marry her husband, Leo, have four children and live in the historic township of Dunwich on North Stradbroke Island. From there her two great passions were art and the environment-and her life is one of opening the door for hundreds of people to both of those. It was her children, Daniel, David, Virginia and Leona, and their love of the intertidal mudflats, with its shags, cormorants and sea snails, that drew her down to the water to share her zoological knowledge. Soon there were school groups following in their footsteps. She spent a number of years on her passion for art with the North Stradbroke art and craft group. In 1962 she moved across to Ormiston and joined the Yurara art group where they were running Mount Gravatt TAFE courses in art for art and design students. There she met Robert Barnes, an inspiration to her, and she began teaching art and art history. Of course, one of the great disadvantages of teaching art is that you do not have enough time to do it yourself. So in the early 1990s Helen decided to open an art gallery in Manly. From there she became an institution in the area, painting on the footpaths and down by the waterside. She won Redlands Shire Council awards in 1991 and 1992; had a joint exhibition at the Manly Gallery in 1993; in 1994 was featured artist with the Redlands art and craft festival; and in 1995 had a sole exhibition at Manly Gallery and was featured artist for the Manly sailing festhe tival. In 1996 Helen Elmslie was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease. We all know her commitment and energy to tasks throughout her life. This was no different. She joined Parkinson's Queensland and thought about helping those who lived with Parkinson's. She developed a board game called Parkinson's Daily Olympics. It is her hope that that will now be distributed free through Parkinson's Queensland to schools, nursing homes and doctors surgeries around the country. Helen Elmslie is a woman who has shared her love of art and her love of nature with hundreds of people in the Moreton Bay region. She was awarded an Australia Day award, as was Mary Preston with her Coochiemudlo Island Bush Care Group. I congratulate them both for their awards and for devoting their lives to their passions on the bayside. Work and Family Roles

Speaker: Ms LIVERMORE
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I would like to use the time that is left to congratulate the federal Sex Discrimination Commissioner, Pru Goward, on the discussion paper Striking the balance: women, men, work and family, which was released and widely reported today. The paper is about prompting submissions to HREOC's inquiry into paid work and family responsibilities. The paper shows that the balance between work and family is just not there currently and that is especially the case for working women. The paper shows in stark figures that women employed full time are putting in 14.3 hours per week of unpaid work in the home and women employed part time are putting in 20.1 hours per week of work into the home, compared to six hours and 5.2 hours respectively for men employed full time and part time. While this situation continues, it is a serious issue not just for those exhausted families trying to cope with juggling act but for Australia generally.
